If we divide the total amount of juice by 4, we get <math> LaTex dfrac{5}{6}</math>, which should be the amount of juice in each glass. prompt:
Suppose <math>a</math>, <math>b</math>, and <math>c</math> are positive integers such that<cmath> LaTex frac{a}{14}+ LaTex frac{b}{15}= LaTex frac{c}{210}.</cmath>Which of the following statements are necessarily true?

I. If <math> LaTex gcd(a,14)=1</math> or <math> LaTex gcd(b,15)=1</math> or both, then <math> LaTex gcd(c,210)=1</math>.

II. If <math> LaTex gcd(c,210)=1</math>, then <math> LaTex gcd(a,14)=1</math> or <math> LaTex gcd(b,15)=1</math> or both.

III. <math> LaTex gcd(c,210)=1</math> if and only if <math> LaTex gcd(a,14)= LaTex gcd(b,15)=1</math>.
completion:
We examine each of the conditions. 

The first condition is false. A simple counterexample is <math>a=3</math> and <math>b=5</math>. The corresponding value of <math>c</math> is <math>17 LaTex cdot15=255</math>. Clearly, <math> LaTex gcd(3,14)=1</math> and <math> LaTex gcd(5,15)=5</math>, so condition <math>I</math> would imply that <math> LaTex gcd(c,210)=1.</math> However, <math> LaTex gcd(255,210)</math> is clearly not <math>1</math> (they share a common factor of <math>5</math>). Obviously, condition <math>I</math> is false, so we can rule out choices <math>A,B,</math> and <math>C</math>. 

We are now deciding between the two answer choices <math>D</math> and <math>E</math>. What differs between them is the validity of condition <math>II</math>, so it suffices to simply check <math>II</math>. 

We look at statement <math>II</math>'s contrapositive to prove it. The contrapositive states that if <math> LaTex gcd(a,14) LaTex neq1</math> and <math> LaTex gcd(b,15) LaTex neq1</math>, then <math> LaTex gcd(c,210) LaTex neq1.</math> In other words, if <math>a</math> shares some common factor that is not <math>1</math> with <math>14</math> and <math>b</math> shares some common factor that is not <math>1</math> with <math>15</math>, then <math>c</math> also shares a common factor with <math>210</math>. Let's say that <math>a=a' LaTex cdot n</math>, where <math>a'</math> is a factor of <math>14</math> not equal to <math>1</math>. (So <math>a'</math> is the common factor.) 

We can rewrite the given equation as <math>15a+14b=c LaTex implies15(a'n)+14b=c.</math> We can express <math>14</math> as <math>a' LaTex cdot n'</math>, for some positive integer <math>n'</math> (this <math>n'</math> can be <math>1</math>). We can factor <math>a'</math> out to get <math>a'(15n+14n')=c.</math> 

We know that all values in this equation are integers, so <math>c</math> must be divisible by <math>a'</math>. Since <math>a'</math> is a factor of <math>14</math>, <math>a'</math> must also be a factor of <math>210</math>, a multiple of <math>14</math>. Therefore, we know that <math>c</math> shares a common factor with <math>210</math> (which is <math>a'</math>), so <math> LaTex gcd(c,210) LaTex neq1</math>. This is what <math>II</math> states, so therefore <math>II</math> is true. 

Thus, our answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(E) } LaTex text{II and III only}}.</math> 
~Technodoggo

prompt: Each of <math>2023</math> balls is placed in one of <math>3</math> bins. Which of the following is closest to the probability that each of the bins will contain an odd number of balls?
completion:
Because each bin will have an odd number, they will have at least one ball. So we can put one ball in each bin prematurely. We then can add groups of 2 balls into each bin, meaning we now just have to spread 1010 pairs over 3 bins. This will force every bin to have an odd number of balls. Using stars and bars, we find that this is equal to <math> LaTex binom{1012}{2}</math>. This is equal to <math> LaTex frac{1012 LaTex cdot1011}{2}</math>. The total amount of ways would also be found using stars and bars. That would be <math> LaTex binom{2023+3-1}{3-1} =  LaTex binom{2025}{2}</math>. Dividing our two quantities, we get <math> LaTex frac{1012  LaTex cdot 1011  LaTex cdot 2}{2  LaTex cdot 2025  LaTex cdot 2024}</math>. We can roughly cancel <math> LaTex frac{1012  LaTex cdot 1011}{2025  LaTex cdot 2024}</math> to get <math> LaTex frac{1}{4}</math>. The 2 in the numerator and denominator also cancels out, so we're left with <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex frac{1}{4}}</math>.

Note: My solution does not provide an exact probability, but is a good estimate, which is how this problem was designed. Most of the solutions on this page will give a decent estimate. This is due to the fact that the binomial expansions are symmetric for even vs odd. Try experimenting to determine why this is true.

Therefore, the answer is

<cmath> LaTex frac{4  LaTex arcsin  LaTex frac14 }{ 2  LaTex pi} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(E) }  LaTex frac{2  LaTex arcsin  LaTex frac{1}{4}}{ LaTex pi}}</cmath>

prompt: A lampshade is made in the form of the lateral surface of the frustum of a right circular cone. The height of the frustum is <math>3 LaTex sqrt3</math> inches, its top diameter is <math>6</math> inches, and its bottom diameter is <math>12</math> inches. A bug is at the bottom of the lampshade and there is a glob of honey on the top edge of the lampshade at the spot farthest from the bug. The bug wants to crawl to the honey, but it must stay on the surface of the lampshade. What is the length in inches of its shortest path to the honey?
completion:
We augment the frustum to a circular cone.
Denote by <math>O</math> the apex of the cone.
Denote by <math>A</math> the bug and <math>B</math> the honey.

By using the numbers given in this problem, the height of the cone is <math>6  LaTex sqrt{3}</math>.
Thus, <math>OA = 12</math> and <math>OB = 6</math>.

We unfold the lateral face. So we get a circular sector.
The radius is 12 and the length of the arc is <math>12 LaTex pi</math>.
Thus, the central angle of this circular sector is <math>180^ LaTex circ</math>.

Because <math>A</math> and <math>B</math> are opposite in the original frustum, in the unfolded circular cone, <math> LaTex angle AOB =  LaTex frac{180^ LaTex circ}{2} = 90^ LaTex circ</math>.

Notice that a feasible path between <math>A</math> and <math>B</math> can only fall into the region with the range of radii between <math>OB = 6</math> and <math>OA = 12</math>.
Therefore, we cannot directly connect <math>A</math> and <math>B</math> and must make a detour.
Denote by <math>AC</math> a tangent to the circular sector with radius 6 that meets it at point <math>C</math>.
Therefore, the shortest path between <math>A</math> and <math>B</math> consists of a segment <math>AC</math> and an arc from <math>C</math> to <math>B</math>.

Because <math>OA = 12</math>, <math>OC = 6</math> and <math> LaTex angle OCA = 90^ LaTex circ</math>, we have <math>AC =  LaTex sqrt{OA^2 - OC^2} = 6  LaTex sqrt{3}</math> and <math> LaTex angle AOC = 60^ LaTex circ</math>.
This implies <math> LaTex angle COB =  LaTex angle AOB -  LaTex angle AOC = 30^ LaTex circ</math>.
Therefore, the length of the arc between <math>C</math> and <math>B</math> is <math>OB  LaTex cdot  LaTex pi  LaTex cdot   LaTex frac{ LaTex angle COB}{180^ LaTex circ} =  LaTex pi</math>.
Therefore, the shortest distance between <math>A</math> and <math>B</math> is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(E) } 6  LaTex sqrt{3} +  LaTex pi}</math>.

~Steven Chen (Professor Chen Education Palace, www.professorchenedu.com)

f(2a) + f(0) = 2f(a)^2

Plugging in <math>a =  LaTex frac{1}{2}</math> implies <math>f(1)  LaTex geq -1</math>, so answer choice <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(E) }}</math> is impossible.

prompt: When <math>n</math> standard six-sided dice are rolled, the product of the numbers rolled can be any of <math>936</math> possible values. What is <math>n</math>?
completion:
We start by trying to prove a function of <math>n</math>, and then we can apply the function and equate it to <math>936</math> to find the value of <math>n</math>.

It is helpful to think of this problem in the format <math>(1+2+3+4+5+6)  LaTex cdot (1+2+3+4+5+6)  LaTex dots</math>. Note that if we represent the scenario in this manner, we can think of picking a <math>1</math> for one factor and then a <math>5</math> for another factor to form their product - this is similar thinking to when we have the factorized form of a polynomial. Unfortunately this is not quite accurate to the problem because we can reach the same product in many ways: for example for <math>n=2</math>, <math>4</math> can be reached by picking <math>1</math> and <math>4</math> or <math>2</math> and <math>2</math>. However, this form gives us insights that will be useful later in the problem.

Note that there are only <math>3</math> primes in the set <math> LaTex {1,2,3,4,5,6 LaTex }</math>: <math>2,3,</math> and <math>5</math>. Thus if we're forming the product of possible values of a dice roll, the product has to be written in the form <math>2^h  LaTex cdot 3^i  LaTex cdot 5^j</math> (the choice of variables will become clear later), for integer nonnegative values <math>h,i,j</math>. So now the problem boils down to how many distinct triplets <math>(h,i,j)</math> can be formed by taking the product of <math>n</math> dice values. 

We start our work on representing <math>j</math>: the powers of <math>5</math>, because it is the simplest in this scenario because there is only one factor of <math>5</math> in the set. Because of this, having <math>j</math> fives in our prime factorization of the product is equivalent to picking <math>j</math> factors from the polynomial <math>(1+ LaTex dots + 6)  LaTex cdots</math> and choosing each factor to be a <math>5</math>. Now that we've selected <math>j</math> factors, there are <math>n-j</math> factors remaining to choose our powers of <math>3</math> and <math>2</math>. 

Suppose our prime factorization of this product contains <math>i</math> powers of <math>3</math>. These powers of <math>3</math> can either come from a <math>3</math> factor or a <math>6</math> factor, but since both <math>3</math> and <math>6</math> contain only one power of <math>3</math>, this means that a product with <math>i</math> powers of <math>3</math> corresponds directly to picking <math>i</math> factors from the polynomial, each of which is either <math>3</math> or <math>6</math> (but this distinction doesn't matter when we consider only the powers of <math>3</math>. 

Now we can reframe the problem again. Our method will be as follows: Suppose we choose an arbitrary pair <math>(i,j)</math> that match the requirements, corresponding to the number of <math>3</math>'s and the number of <math>5</math>'s our product will have. Then how many different <math>h</math> values for the powers of <math>2</math> are possible?

In the <math>i+j</math> factors we have already chosen, we obviously can't have any factors of <math>2</math> in the <math>j</math> factors with <math>5</math>. However, we can have a factor of <math>2</math> pairing with factors of <math>3</math>, if we choose a <math>6</math>. The maximal possible power of <math>2</math> in these <math>i</math> factors is thus <math>2^i</math>, which occurs when we pick every factor to be <math>6</math>. 

We now have <math>n-i-j</math> factors remaining, and we want to allocate these to solely powers of <math>2</math>. For each of these factors, we can choose either a <math>1,2,</math> or <math>4</math>. Therefore the maximal power of <math>2</math> achieved in these factors is when we pick <math>4</math> for all of them, which is equivalent to <math>2^{2 LaTex cdot (n-i-j)}</math>.

Now if we multiply this across the total <math>n</math> factors (or <math>n</math> dice) we have a total of <math>2^{2n-2i-2j}  LaTex cdot 2^i = 2^{2n-i-2j}</math>, which is the maximal power of <math>2</math> attainable in the product for a pair <math>(i,j)</math>. Now note that every power of <math>2</math> below this power is attainable: we can simply just take away a power of <math>2</math> from an existing factor by dividing by <math>2</math>. Therefore the powers of <math>2</math>, and thus the <math>h</math> value ranges from <math>h=0</math> to <math>h=2n-i-2j</math>, so there are a total of <math>2n+1-i-2j</math> distinct values for <math>h</math> for a given pair <math>(i,j)</math>. 

Now to find the total number of distinct triplets, we must sum this across all possible <math>i</math>s and <math>j</math>s. Lets take note of our restrictions on <math>i,j</math>: the only restriction is that <math>i+j  LaTex leq n</math>, since we're picking factors from <math>n</math> dice.

<cmath>  LaTex sum_{i+j LaTex leq n}^{} 2n+1-i-2j =  LaTex sum_{i+j  LaTex leq n}^{} 2n+1 -  LaTex sum_{i+j  LaTex leq n}^{} i+2j</cmath>

We start by calculating the first term. <math>2n+1</math> is constant, so we just need to find out how many pairs there are such that <math>i+j  LaTex leq n</math>. Set <math>i</math> to <math>0</math>: <math>j</math> can range from <math>0</math> to <math>n</math>, then set <math>i</math> to <math>1</math>: <math>j</math> can range from <math>0</math> to <math>n-1</math>, etc. The total number of pairs is thus <math>n+1+n+n-1+ LaTex dots+1 =  LaTex frac{(n+1)(n+2)}{2}</math>. Therefore the left summation evaluates to <cmath> LaTex frac{(2n+1)(n+1)(n+2)}{2}</cmath>

Now we calculate <math> LaTex sum_{i+j  LaTex leq n}^{} i+2j</math>. This simplifies to <math> LaTex sum_{i+j  LaTex leq n}^{} i + 2  LaTex cdot  LaTex sum_{i+j  LaTex leq n}^{} j</math>. Note that because <math>i+j = n</math> is symmetric with respect to <math>i,j</math>, the sum of <math>i</math> in all of the pairs will be equal to the sum of <math>j</math> in all of the pairs. Thus this is equal to calculating <math>3  LaTex cdot  LaTex sum_{i+j  LaTex leq n}^{} i</math>.

In the pairs, <math>i=1</math> appears for <math>j</math> ranging between <math>0</math> and <math>n-1</math> so the sum here is <math>1  LaTex cdot (n)</math>. Similarly <math>i=2</math> appears for <math>j</math> ranging from <math>0</math> to <math>n-2</math>, so the sum is <math>2  LaTex cdot (n-1)</math>. If we continue the pattern, the sum overall is <math>(n)+2  LaTex cdot (n-1) + 3  LaTex cdot (n-2) +  LaTex dots + (n)  LaTex cdot 1</math>. We can rearrange this as <math>((n)+(n-1)+  LaTex dots + 1) + ((n-1)+(n-2)+  LaTex dots + 1)+ ((n-2)+(n-3)+  LaTex dots + 1) +  LaTex dots + 1)</math>

<cmath> =  LaTex frac{(n)(n+1)}{2} +  LaTex frac{(n-1)(n)}{2}+  LaTex dots + 1</cmath>

We can write this in easier terms as <math> LaTex sum_{k=0}^{n}  LaTex frac{(k)(k+1)}{2} =  LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex cdot  LaTex sum_{k=0}^{n} k^2+k</math>
<cmath>= LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex cdot(  LaTex sum_{k=0}^{n} k^2 +  LaTex sum_{k=0}^{n} k)</cmath>
<cmath>=  LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex cdot (  LaTex frac{(n)(n+1)(2n+1)}{6} +  LaTex frac{(n)(n+1)}{2})</cmath>
<cmath>=  LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex cdot (  LaTex frac{(n)(n+1)(2n+1)}{6} +  LaTex frac{3n(n+1)}{6}) =  LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{n(n+1)(2n+4)}{6}</cmath>
<cmath> =  LaTex frac{n(n+1)(n+2)}{6}</cmath>

We multiply this by <math>3</math> to obtain that <cmath> LaTex sum_{i+j  LaTex leq n}^{} i+2j =  LaTex frac{n(n+1)(n+2)}{2}</cmath>

Thus our final answer for the number of distinct triplets <math>(h,i,j)</math> is:
<cmath> LaTex sum_{i+j LaTex leq n}^{} 2n+1-i-2j =  LaTex frac{(2n+1)(n+1)(n+2)}{2} -  LaTex frac{n(n+1)(n+2)}{2}</cmath>
<cmath> =  LaTex frac{(n+1)(n+2)}{2}  LaTex cdot (2n+1-n) =  LaTex frac{(n+1)(n+2)}{2}  LaTex cdot (n+1)</cmath>
<cmath> =  LaTex frac{(n+1)^2(n+2)}{2}</cmath>

Now most of the work is done. We set this equal to <math>936</math> and prime factorize. <math>936 = 12  LaTex cdot 78 = 2^3  LaTex cdot 3^2  LaTex cdot 13</math>, so <math>(n+1)^2(n+2) = 936  LaTex cdot 2 = 2^4  LaTex cdot 3^2  LaTex cdot 13</math>. Clearly <math>13</math> cannot be anything squared and <math>2^4  LaTex cdot 3^2</math> is a perfect square, so <math>n+2 = 13</math> and <math>n = 11 =  LaTex boxed{A}</math>



~KingRavi

prompt:
Suppose that <math>a</math>, <math>b</math>, <math>c</math> and <math>d</math> are positive integers satisfying all of the following relations.

<cmath>abcd=2^6 LaTex cdot 3^9 LaTex cdot 5^7</cmath>
<cmath> LaTex text{lcm}(a,b)=2^3 LaTex cdot 3^2 LaTex cdot 5^3</cmath>
<cmath> LaTex text{lcm}(a,c)=2^3 LaTex cdot 3^3 LaTex cdot 5^3</cmath>
<cmath> LaTex text{lcm}(a,d)=2^3 LaTex cdot 3^3 LaTex cdot 5^3</cmath>
<cmath> LaTex text{lcm}(b,c)=2^1 LaTex cdot 3^3 LaTex cdot 5^2</cmath>
<cmath> LaTex text{lcm}(b,d)=2^2 LaTex cdot 3^3 LaTex cdot 5^2</cmath>
<cmath> LaTex text{lcm}(c,d)=2^2 LaTex cdot 3^3 LaTex cdot 5^2</cmath>

What is <math> LaTex text{gcd}(a,b,c,d)</math>?
completion:
Denote by <math> LaTex nu_p (x)</math> the number of prime factor <math>p</math> in number <math>x</math>.

We index Equations given in this problem from (1) to (7).


First, we compute <math> LaTex nu_2 (x)</math> for <math>x  LaTex in  LaTex left LaTex { a, b, c, d  LaTex right LaTex }</math>.

Equation (5) implies <math> LaTex max  LaTex left LaTex {  LaTex nu_2 (b),  LaTex nu_2 (c)  LaTex right LaTex } = 1</math>.
Equation (2) implies <math> LaTex max  LaTex left LaTex {  LaTex nu_2 (a),  LaTex nu_2 (b)  LaTex right LaTex } = 3</math>.
Equation (6) implies <math> LaTex max  LaTex left LaTex {  LaTex nu_2 (b),  LaTex nu_2 (d)  LaTex right LaTex } = 2</math>.
Equation (1) implies <math> LaTex nu_2 (a) +  LaTex nu_2 (b) +  LaTex nu_2 (c) +  LaTex nu_2 (d) = 6</math>.

Therefore, all above jointly imply <math> LaTex nu_2 (a) = 3</math>, <math> LaTex nu_2 (d) = 2</math>, and <math> LaTex left(  LaTex nu_2 (b),  LaTex nu_2 (c)  LaTex right) =  LaTex left( 0 , 1  LaTex right)</math> or <math> LaTex left( 1, 0  LaTex right)</math>.


Second, we compute <math> LaTex nu_3 (x)</math> for <math>x  LaTex in  LaTex left LaTex { a, b, c, d  LaTex right LaTex }</math>.

Equation (2) implies <math> LaTex max  LaTex left LaTex {  LaTex nu_3 (a),  LaTex nu_3 (b)  LaTex right LaTex } = 2</math>.
Equation (3) implies <math> LaTex max  LaTex left LaTex {  LaTex nu_3 (a),  LaTex nu_3 (c)  LaTex right LaTex } = 3</math>.
Equation (4) implies <math> LaTex max  LaTex left LaTex {  LaTex nu_3 (a),  LaTex nu_3 (d)  LaTex right LaTex } = 3</math>.
Equation (1) implies <math> LaTex nu_3 (a) +  LaTex nu_3 (b) +  LaTex nu_3 (c) +  LaTex nu_3 (d) = 9</math>.

Therefore, all above jointly imply <math> LaTex nu_3 (c) = 3</math>, <math> LaTex nu_3 (d) = 3</math>, and <math> LaTex left(  LaTex nu_3 (a),  LaTex nu_3 (b)  LaTex right) =  LaTex left( 1 , 2  LaTex right)</math> or <math> LaTex left( 2, 1  LaTex right)</math>.

Third, we compute <math> LaTex nu_5 (x)</math> for <math>x  LaTex in  LaTex left LaTex { a, b, c, d  LaTex right LaTex }</math>.


Equation (5) implies <math> LaTex max  LaTex left LaTex {  LaTex nu_5 (b),  LaTex nu_5 (c)  LaTex right LaTex } = 2</math>.
Equation (2) implies <math> LaTex max  LaTex left LaTex {  LaTex nu_5 (a),  LaTex nu_5 (b)  LaTex right LaTex } = 3</math>.
Thus, <math> LaTex nu_5 (a) = 3</math>.

From Equations (5)-(7), we have either <math> LaTex nu_5 (b)  LaTex leq 1</math> and <math> LaTex nu_5 (c) =  LaTex nu_5 (d) = 2</math>, or <math> LaTex nu_5 (b) = 2</math> and <math> LaTex max  LaTex left LaTex {  LaTex nu_5 (c),  LaTex nu_5 (d)  LaTex right LaTex } = 2</math>.

Equation (1) implies <math> LaTex nu_5 (a) +  LaTex nu_5 (b) +  LaTex nu_5 (c) +  LaTex nu_5 (d) = 7</math>.
Thus, for <math> LaTex nu_5 (b)</math>, <math> LaTex nu_5 (c)</math>, <math> LaTex nu_5 (d)</math>, there must be two 2s and one 0.

Therefore,
<cmath>
 LaTex begin{align*}
{ LaTex rm gcd} (a,b,c,d)
& =  LaTex Pi_{p  LaTex in  LaTex { 2, 3, 5 LaTex }} p^{ LaTex min LaTex {  LaTex nu_p (a),  LaTex nu_p(b) ,  LaTex nu_p (c),  LaTex nu_p(d)  LaTex }}  LaTex  LaTex 
& = 2^0  LaTex cdot 3^1  LaTex cdot 5^0  LaTex  LaTex 
& =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(C) 3}}.
 LaTex end{align*}
</cmath>

~Steven Chen (Professor Chen Education Palace, www.professorchenedu.com)

prompt: A regular pentagon with area <math> LaTex sqrt{5}+1</math> is printed on paper and cut out. The five vertices of the pentagon are folded into the center of the pentagon, creating a smaller pentagon. What is the area of the new pentagon?
completion:
[[File:Pentagon_2023_12B_Q25_dissmo.png]]

Let the original pentagon be <math>ABCDE</math> centered at <math>O</math>. The dashed lines represent the fold lines. WLOG, let's focus on vertex <math>A</math>.

Since <math>A</math> is folded onto <math>O</math>, <math>AN = NO</math> where <math>N</math> is the intersection of <math>AO</math> and the creaseline between <math>A</math> and <math>O</math>. Note that the inner pentagon is regular, and therefore similar to the original pentagon, due to symmetry.

Because of their similarity, the ratio of the inner pentagon's area to that of the outer pentagon can be represented by 

<math>( LaTex frac{ON}{OM})^{2} = ( LaTex frac{ LaTex frac{OA}{2}}{OA LaTex sin ( LaTex angle OAE)})^{2} =  LaTex frac{1}{4 LaTex sin^{2}54}</math> 


===Option 1: Knowledge===

Remember that <math> LaTex sin54 =  LaTex frac{1+ LaTex sqrt5}{4}</math>.


===Option 2: Angle Identities===

<math> LaTex sin54 =  LaTex cos36</math>

<math>4 LaTex cos^{3}18-3 LaTex cos18 = 2 LaTex sin18 LaTex cos18</math>

<math>4(1- LaTex sin^{2}18)-3-2 LaTex sin18=0</math>

<math>4 LaTex sin^{2}18+2 LaTex sin18-1=0</math>

<math> LaTex sin18 =  LaTex frac{-1+ LaTex sqrt5}{4}</math>

<math> LaTex sin54 =  LaTex cos36 = 1-2 LaTex sin^{2}18 =  LaTex frac{1+ LaTex sqrt5}{4}</math>


<math> LaTex sin^{2}54 = LaTex frac{3+ LaTex sqrt5}{8}</math>

Let the inner pentagon be <math>Z</math>.

<math>[Z] =  LaTex frac{1}{4 LaTex sin^{2}54}[ABCDE]</math>

<math> =  LaTex frac{2(1+ LaTex sqrt5)}{3+ LaTex sqrt5}</math>

<math> =  LaTex sqrt5-1</math>
   
<math> LaTex boxed{B}</math>

-Dissmo

completion:
Let <math>p</math> and <math>q</math> be the roots of <math>x^{2}+kx+36.</math> By [[Vieta's Formulas]], we have <math>p+q=-k</math> and <math>pq=36.</math>

It follows that <math>p</math> and <math>q</math> must be distinct factors of <math>36.</math> The possibilities of <math> LaTex {p,q LaTex }</math> are <cmath> LaTex pm LaTex {1,36 LaTex }, LaTex pm LaTex {2,18 LaTex }, LaTex pm LaTex {3,12 LaTex }, LaTex pm LaTex {4,9 LaTex }.</cmath>

prompt: Let <math>P(x)</math> be a polynomial with rational coefficients such that when <math>P(x)</math> is divided by the polynomial <math>x^2 + x + 1</math>, the remainder is <math>x + 2</math>, and when <math>P(x)</math> is divided by the polynomial <math>x^2 + 1</math>, the remainder is <math>2x + 1</math>. Given that all the answer choices and coefficients are integers, we hope that <math>P(x)</math> has positive integer coefficients.

Throughout this solution, we will express all polynomials in base <math>x</math>. E.g. <math>x^2 + x + 1 = 111_{x}</math>.

We are given:
<cmath>111a + 12 = 101b + 21 = P(x).</cmath>
We add <math>111</math> and <math>101</math> to each side and balance respectively:
<cmath>111(a - 1) + 123 = 101(b - 1) + 122 = P(x).</cmath>
We make the unit's digits equal:
<cmath>111(a - 1) + 123 = 101(b - 2) + 223 = P(x).</cmath>
We now notice that:
<cmath>111(a - 11) + 1233 = 101(b - 12) + 1233 = P(x).</cmath>
Therefore <math>a = 11_{x} = x + 1</math>, <math>b = 12_{x} = x + 2</math>, and <math>P(x) = 1233_{x} = x^3 + 2x^2 + 3x + 3</math>. <math>3</math> is the minimal degree of <math>P(x)</math> since there is no way to influence the <math>x</math>‘s digit in <math>101b + 21</math> when <math>b</math> is an integer. <math>*</math> <math>P</math> and <math>Q</math> are externally tangent to <math>S</math>.

<math>*</math> <math>P</math> is externally and Circle <math>Q</math> is internally tangent to <math>S</math>.

Consider Cases <math>1</math> and <math>4</math> together. Since circles <math>O</math> and <math>P</math> have the same center, the line connecting the center of <math>S</math> and the center of <math>O</math> will pass through the tangency point of both <math>S</math> and <math>O</math> and the tangency point of <math>S</math> and <math>P</math>. This line will be the diameter of <math>S</math> and have length <math>r_P + r_O = 10</math>. Therefore the radius of <math>S</math> in these cases is <math>5</math>.

Consider Cases <math>2</math> and <math>3</math> together. Similarly to Cases <math>1</math> and <math>4</math>, the line connecting the center of <math>S</math> to the center of <math>O</math> will pass through the tangency points. This time, however, the diameter of <math>S</math> will have length <math>r_P-r_O=6</math>. Therefore, the radius of <math>S</math> in these cases is <math>3</math>.
    
The set of circles <math>S</math> consists of <math>8</math> circles - <math>4</math> of which have radius <math>5</math> and <math>4</math> of which have radius <math>3</math>. 
The total area of all circles in <math>S</math> is <math>4(5^2 LaTex pi + 3^2 LaTex pi) = 136 LaTex pi  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(E)}}</math>.

prompt: An organization has <math>30</math> employees, <math>20</math> of whom have a brand A computer while the other <math>10</math> have a brand B computer. For security, the computers can only be connected to each other and only by cables. The cables can only connect a brand A computer to a brand B computer. Employees can communicate with each other if their computers are directly connected by a cable or by relaying messages through a series of connected computers. Initially, no computer is connected to any other. A technician arbitrarily selects one computer of each brand and installs a cable between them, provided there is not already a cable between that pair. The technician stops once every employee can communicate with each other. What is the maximum possible number of cables used?
completion:
We claim that to maximize the number of cables used, we isolate one computer and connect all cables for the remaining 29 computers, then connect one more cable for the isolated computer. If a brand A computer is isolated, then the technician can use at most 19 LaTex cdot10+1=191 cables. If a brand B computer is isolated instead, then the technician can use at most 20 LaTex cdot9+1=181 cables. Therefore, the answer is LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B)} LaTex 191}. Remark Suppose that the computers are labeled A_1, A_2, LaTex ldots, A_{20} and B_1, B_2, LaTex ldots, B_{10}. We will prove the claim in the first paragraph of this solution:
  1. With exactly LaTex boldsymbol{190} cables, it is possible that some computers cannot communicate with each other.

    2. From this solution, it is clear that this claim is true: We isolate A_{20} and connect all cables for A_1, A_2, LaTex ldots, A_{19} and B_1, B_2, LaTex ldots, B_{10} to get 19 LaTex cdot10=190 cables. However, A_{20} cannot communicate with any of these 29 computers.

  2. With exactly LaTex boldsymbol{191} cables, all computers must be able to communicate with each other.

    3. By the Pigeonhole Principle, we conclude that at least one brand B computer connects to all 20 brand A computers. Without the loss of generality, we assume that B_1 connects to all 20 brand A computers. On the other hand, we conclude that at least 11 brand A computer connects to all 10 brand B computers. Without the loss of generality, we assume that A_1, A_2, LaTex ldots, A_{11} connect to all 10 brand B computers.

    Therefore, any two computers must be able to communicate with each other:

    • Between A_i and A_j, where i,j LaTex in LaTex {1,2, LaTex ldots,20 LaTex } and i LaTex neq j

      • The relay is A_i LaTex leftrightarrow B_1 LaTex leftrightarrow A_j.

    • Between B_i and B_j, where i,j LaTex in LaTex {1,2, LaTex ldots,10 LaTex } and i LaTex neq j

      • The relay is B_i LaTex leftrightarrow LaTex {A_1, A_2, LaTex ldots, A_{11} LaTex } LaTex leftrightarrow B_j.

    • Between A_i and B_j, where i LaTex in LaTex {1,2, LaTex ldots,20 LaTex } and j LaTex in LaTex {1,2, LaTex ldots,10 LaTex }

      • The relay is A_i LaTex leftrightarrow B_1 LaTex leftrightarrow LaTex {A_1, A_2, LaTex ldots, A_{11} LaTex } LaTex leftrightarrow B_j.

A quadratic equation does not have two distinct real solutions if and only if the discriminant is nonpositive. We conclude that:
  1. Since x^2+bx+c=0 does not have real solutions, we have b^2 LaTex leq 4c.

  2. Since x^2+cx+b=0 does not have real solutions, we have c^2 LaTex leq 4b.

Squaring the first inequality, we get b^4 LaTex leq 16c^2. Multiplying the second inequality by 16, we get 16c^2 LaTex leq 64b. Combining these results, we get b^4 LaTex leq 16c^2 LaTex leq 64b. We apply casework to the value of b: * If b=1, then 1 LaTex leq 16c^2 LaTex leq 64, from which c=1,2. * If b=2, then 16 LaTex leq 16c^2 LaTex leq 128, from which c=1,2. * If b=3, then 81 LaTex leq 16c^2 LaTex leq 192, from which c=3. * If b=4, then 256 LaTex leq 16c^2 LaTex leq 256, from which c=4. Together, there are LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B) } 6} ordered pairs (b,c), namely (1,1),(1,2),(2,1),(2,2),(3,3), and (4,4). ~MRENTHUSIASM

For this to happen <math>x</math> must have <math>6</math> divisors, which means its prime factorization is in the form <math>pq^2</math> or <math>p^5</math>, where <math>p</math> and <math>q</math> are prime numbers. Listing out values less than <math>50</math> which have these prime factorizations, we find <math>12,18,20,28,44,45,50</math> for <math>pq^2</math>, and just <math>32</math> for <math>p^5</math>. Here <math>12</math> especially catches our eyes, as this means if one of <math>f_i(n)=12</math>, each of <math>f_{i+1}(n), f_{i+2}(n), ...</math> will all be <math>12</math>. This is because <math>f_{i+1}(n)=f(f_i(n))</math> (as given in the problem statement), so were <math>f_i(n)=12</math>, plugging this in we get <math>f_{i+1}(n)=f(12)=12</math>, and thus the pattern repeats. Hence, as long as for a <math>i</math>, such that <math>i LaTex leq 50</math> and <math>f_{i}(n)=12</math>, <math>f_{50}(n)=12</math> must be true, which also immediately makes all our previously listed numbers, where <math>f(x)=12</math>, possible values of <math>n</math>.

We also know that if <math>f(x)</math> were to be any of these numbers, <math>x</math> would satisfy <math>f_{50}(n)</math> as well. Looking through each of the possibilities aside from <math>12</math>, we see that <math>f(x)</math> could only possibly be equal to <math>20</math> and <math>18</math>, and still have <math>x</math> less than or equal to <math>50</math>. From here there are no more possible values, so tallying our possibilities we count <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D) }10}</math> values (Namely <math>12,18,20,28,32,36,44,45,48,50</math>).

prompt: Azar and Carl play a game of tic-tac-toe. Azar places an in <math>X</math> one of the boxes in a <math>3</math>-by-<math>3</math> array of boxes, then Carl places an <math>O</math> in one of the remaining boxes. After that, Azar places an <math>X</math> in one of the remaining boxes, and so on until all boxes are filled or one of the players has of their symbols in a row—horizontal, vertical, or diagonal—whichever comes first, in which case that player wins the game. Suppose the players make their moves at random, rather than trying to follow a rational strategy, and that Carl wins the game when he places his third <math>O</math>. How many ways can the board look after the game is over?
completion:
We need to find out the number of configurations with 3 <math>O</math> and 3 <math>X</math> with 3 <math>O</math> in a row, and 3 <math>X</math> not in a row.

<math> LaTex textbf{Case 1}</math>: 3 <math>O</math> are in a horizontal row or a vertical row.

Step 1: We determine the row that 3 <math>O</math> occupy.

The number of ways is 6.

Step 2: We determine the configuration of 3 <math>X</math>.

The number of ways is <math> LaTex binom{6}{3} - 2 = 18</math>.

In this case, following from the rule of product, the number of ways is <math>6  LaTex cdot 18 = 108</math>.

<math> LaTex textbf{Case 2}</math>: 3 <math>O</math> are in a diagonal row.

Step 1: We determine the row that 3 <math>O</math> occupy.

The number of ways is 2.

Step 2: We determine the configuration of 3 <math>X</math>.

The number of ways is <math> LaTex binom{6}{3}  = 20</math>.

In this case, following from the rule of product, the number of ways is <math>2  LaTex cdot 20 = 40</math>.

Putting all cases together, the total number of ways is <math>108 + 40 = 148</math>.

Therefore, the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D) }148}</math>.

Note that one of these two quadratics has one solution (a double root) and the other has two as there are exactly three solutions. Solving for r_2 yields r_2 = LaTex frac{3}{4}. Therefore, LaTex tilde{p}(x)=x^2 - LaTex frac{1}{2} x - LaTex frac{3}{16}, so LaTex tilde{p}(1)= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A) } LaTex frac{5}{16}}. Remarks * For x^2-(r_1+r_2)x+(r_1r_2-r_2)=0 to have two solutions, the discriminant (r_1+r_2)^2-4r_1r_2+4r_2 must be positive. prompt:
Which of the following conditions is sufficient to guarantee that integers <math>x</math>, <math>y</math>, and <math>z</math> satisfy the equation
<cmath>x(x-y)+y(y-z)+z(z-x) = 1?</cmath>
completion:
It is obvious <math>x</math>, <math>y</math>, and <math>z</math> are symmetrical. We are going to solve the problem by Completing the Square.

<math>x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 + z ^ 2 - xy - yz - zx = 1</math>

<math>2x ^ 2 + 2y ^ 2 + 2z ^ 2 - 2xy - 2yz - 2zx = 2</math>

<math>(x-y)^2 + (y-z)^2 + (z-x)^2 = 2</math>

Because <math>x, y, z</math> are integers, <math>(x-y)^2</math>, <math>(y-z)^2</math>, and <math>(z-x)^2</math> can only equal <math>0, 1, 1</math>. So one variable must equal another, and the third variable is <math>1</math> different from those <math>2</math> equal variables. So the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{D}</math>.

We will use complementary counting to find the probability that the product is not divisible by <math>4</math>. Then, we can find the probability that we want by subtracting this from 1. We split this into <math>2</math> cases. 

Case 1: The product is not divisible by <math>2</math>.

We need every number to be odd, and since the chance we roll an odd number is <math> LaTex frac12,</math> our probability is <math> LaTex left( LaTex frac12 LaTex right)^6= LaTex frac1{64}.</math>

Case 2: The product is divisible by <math>2</math>, but not by <math>4</math>.

We need <math>5</math> numbers to be odd, and one to be divisible by <math>2</math>, but not by <math>4</math>. There is a <math> LaTex frac12</math> chance that an odd number is rolled, a <math> LaTex frac13</math> chance that we roll a number satisfying the second condition (only <math>2</math> and <math>6</math> work), and <math>6</math> ways to choose the order in which the even number appears.

Our probability is <math> LaTex left( LaTex frac12 LaTex right)^5 LaTex left( LaTex frac13 LaTex right) LaTex cdot6= LaTex frac1{16}.</math>

Therefore, the probability the product is not divisible by <math>4</math> is <math> LaTex frac1{64}+ LaTex frac1{16}= LaTex frac{5}{64}</math>.

Our answer is <math>1- LaTex frac{5}{64}= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(C)} LaTex   LaTex frac{59}{64}}</math>.

prompt: Suppose that <math>P(z), Q(z)</math>, and <math>R(z)</math> are polynomials with real coefficients, having degrees <math>2</math>, <math>3</math>, and <math>6</math>, respectively, and constant terms <math>1</math>, <math>2</math>, and <math>3</math>, respectively. Let <math>N</math> be the number of distinct complex numbers <math>z</math> that satisfy the equation <math>P(z)  LaTex cdot Q(z)=R(z)</math>. What is the minimum possible value of <math>N</math>?
completion:
The answer cannot be <math>0,</math> as every nonconstant polynomial has at least <math>1</math> distinct complex root (Fundamental Theorem of Algebra). Since <math>P(z)  LaTex cdot Q(z)</math> has degree <math>2 + 3 = 5,</math> we conclude that <math>R(z) - P(z) LaTex cdot Q(z)</math> has degree <math>6</math> and is thus nonconstant.

It now suffices to illustrate an example for which <math>N = 1</math>: Take
<cmath> LaTex begin{align*}
P(z)&=z^2+1,  LaTex  LaTex 
Q(z)&=z^3+2,  LaTex  LaTex 
R(z)&=(z+1)^6 + P(z)  LaTex cdot Q(z).
 LaTex end{align*}</cmath>
Note that <math>R(z)</math> has degree <math>6</math> and constant term <math>3,</math> so it satisfies the conditions.

We need to find the solutions to 
<cmath> LaTex begin{align*}
P(z)  LaTex cdot Q(z) &= (z+1)^6 + P(z)  LaTex cdot Q(z)  LaTex  LaTex 
0 &= (z+1)^6.
 LaTex end{align*}</cmath>
Clearly, the only distinct complex root is <math>-1,</math> so our answer is <math>N= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B)}  LaTex : 1}.</math>

prompt: Suppose <math>a</math>, <math>b</math>, <math>c</math> are positive integers such that <cmath>a+b+c=23</cmath> and <cmath> LaTex gcd(a,b)+ LaTex gcd(b,c)+ LaTex gcd(c,a)=9.</cmath> What is the sum of all possible distinct values of <math>a^2+b^2+c^2</math>?
completion:
Because <math>a + b + c</math> is odd, <math>a</math>, <math>b</math>, <math>c</math> are either one odd and two evens or three odds.

<math> LaTex textbf{Case 1}</math>: <math>a</math>, <math>b</math>, <math>c</math> have one odd and two evens.

Without loss of generality, we assume <math>a</math> is odd and <math>b</math> and <math>c</math> are even.

Hence, <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( a , b  LaTex right)</math> and <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( a , c  LaTex right)</math> are odd, and <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( b , c  LaTex right)</math> is even.
Hence, <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( a , b  LaTex right) + { LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( b , c  LaTex right) + { LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( c , a  LaTex right)</math> is even. This violates the condition given in the problem.

Therefore, there is no solution in this case.

<math> LaTex textbf{Case 2}</math>: <math>a</math>, <math>b</math>, <math>c</math> are all odd.

In this case, <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( a , b  LaTex right)</math>, <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( a , c  LaTex right)</math>, <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( b , c  LaTex right)</math> are all odd.

Without loss of generality, we assume
<cmath>
 LaTex [
{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( a , b  LaTex right)  LaTex leq { LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( b , c  LaTex right)  LaTex leq { LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( c , a  LaTex right) .
 LaTex ]
</cmath>
<math> LaTex textbf{Case 2.1}</math>: <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( a , b  LaTex right) = 1</math>, <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( b , c  LaTex right) = 1</math>, <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( c , a  LaTex right) = 7</math>.

The only solution is <math>(a, b, c) = (7, 9, 7)</math>.

Hence, <math>a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 179</math>.

<math> LaTex textbf{Case 2.2}</math>: <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( a , b  LaTex right) = 1</math>, <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( b , c  LaTex right) = 3</math>, <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( c , a  LaTex right) = 5</math>.

The only solution is <math>(a, b, c) = (5, 3, 15)</math>.

Hence, <math>a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 259</math>.

<math> LaTex textbf{Case 2.3}</math>: <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( a , b  LaTex right) = 3</math>, <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( b , c  LaTex right) = 3</math>, <math>{ LaTex rm gcd}  LaTex left( c , a  LaTex right) = 3</math>.

There is no solution in this case.

Therefore, putting all cases together, the answer is <math>179 + 259 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B)}  LaTex : 438}</math>.

prompt: A bug starts at a vertex of a grid made of equilateral triangles of side length <math>1</math>. At each step the bug moves in one of the <math>6</math> possible directions along the grid lines randomly and independently with equal probability. What is the probability that after <math>5</math> moves the bug never will have been more than <math>1</math> unit away from the starting position?
completion:
Let <math>S(n)</math> be the number of paths of <math>n</math> moves such that the bug never will have been more than <math>1</math> unit away from the starting position. Clearly, by symmetry, there are two possible states here, the bug being on the center and the bug being on one of the vertices of the unit hexagon around the center. Let <math>C(n)</math> be the number of paths with the aforementioned restriction that end on the center. Let <math>V(n)</math> be the number of paths with the aforementioned restriction that end on a vertex of the surrounding unit hexagon. We have <math>S(n) = 6C(n-1) + 3V(n-1),</math> since from the center, there are <math>6</math> possible points to land to and from a vertex there are <math>3</math> possible points to land to (the two adjacent vertices and the center). We also have <math>C(n) = V(n-1)</math>, since to get to the center the bug must have come from a vertex, and <math>V(n) = 2V(n-1) + 6C(n-1),</math> since from a vertex there are two vertices to move to, and from the center there are <math>6</math> vertices to move to. We can construct a recursion table using the base cases <math>V(1) = 6</math> and <math>C(1) = 0</math> and our recursive rules for <math>C(n)</math> and <math>V(n)</math> as follows: 
<cmath> LaTex begin{array}{c|c|c}
n & V(n) & C(n)  LaTex  LaTex   LaTex hline
& &  LaTex  LaTex  [-2ex]
1 & 6 & 0  LaTex  LaTex 
2 & 12 & 6  LaTex  LaTex 
3 & 60 & 12  LaTex  LaTex 
4 & 192 & 60  LaTex  LaTex 
 LaTex end{array}</cmath>
Then, <math>S(5) = 6C(4) + 3V(4) = 6  LaTex cdot 60 + 3  LaTex cdot 192 = 936,</math> and the desired probability is thus <math> LaTex frac{936}{6^5} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A)} LaTex   LaTex frac{13}{108}}.</math>

~fidgetboss_4000

prompt: Regular polygons with <math>5,6,7,</math> and <math>8</math> sides are inscribed in the same circle. No two of the polygons share a vertex, and no three of their sides intersect at a common point. At how many points inside the circle do two of their sides intersect?
completion:
Imagine we have <math>2</math> regular polygons with <math>m</math> and <math>n</math> sides and <math>m>n</math> inscribed in a circle without sharing a vertex. We see that each side of the polygon with <math>n</math> sides (the polygon with fewer sides) will be intersected twice.
(We can see this because to have a vertex of the <math>m</math>-gon on an arc subtended by a side of the <math>n</math>-gon, there will be one intersection to “enter” the arc and one to “exit” the arc. ~KingRavi)

This means that we will end up with <math>2</math> times the number of sides in the polygon with fewer sides.

If we have polygons with <math>5,</math> <math>6,</math> <math>7,</math> and <math>8</math> sides, we need to consider each possible pair of polygons and count their intersections. 

Throughout <math>6</math> of these pairs, the <math>5</math>-sided polygon has the least number of sides <math>3</math> times, the <math>6</math>-sided polygon has the least number of sides <math>2</math> times, and the <math>7</math>-sided polygon has the least number of sides <math>1</math> time.

Therefore the number of intersections is <math>2 LaTex cdot(3 LaTex cdot5+2 LaTex cdot6+1 LaTex cdot7)= LaTex boxed{( LaTex textbf{E})  LaTex :68}</math>.

~kingofpineapplz

prompt: A cube is constructed from <math>4</math> white unit cubes and <math>4</math> blue unit cubes. How many different ways are there to construct the <math>2  LaTex times 2  LaTex times 2</math> cube using these smaller cubes? (Two constructions are considered the same if one can be rotated to match the other.)
completion:
This problem is about the relationships between the white unit cubes and the blue unit cubes, which can be solved by [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_theory Graph Theory]. We use a [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planar_graph Planar Graph] to represent the larger cube. Each vertex of the planar graph represents a unit cube. Each edge of the planar graph represents a shared face between <math>2</math> neighboring unit cubes. Each face of the planar graph represents a face of the larger cube.

Now the problem becomes a [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_coloring Graph Coloring] problem of how many ways to assign <math>4</math> vertices blue and <math>4</math> vertices white with [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homeomorphism Topological Equivalence]. For example, in Figure <math>(1)</math>, as long as the <math>4</math> blue vertices belong to the same planar graph face, the different planar graphs are considered to be topological equivalent by rotating the larger cube.

[[File:Topology.jpg | 950px]]
 
Here is how the <math>4</math> blue unit cubes are arranged: 

In Figure <math>(1)</math>: <math>4</math> blue unit cubes are on the same layer (horizontal or vertical).

In Figure <math>(2)</math>: <math>4</math> blue unit cubes are in <math>T</math> shape.

In Figure <math>(3)</math> and <math>(4)</math>: <math>4</math> blue unit cubes are in <math>S</math> shape.

In Figure <math>(5)</math>: <math>3</math> blue unit cubes are in <math>L</math> shape, and the other is isolated without a shared face.

In Figure <math>(6)</math>: <math>2</math> pairs of neighboring blue unit cubes are isolated from each other without a shared face.

In Figure <math>(7)</math>: <math>4</math> blue unit cubes are isolated from each other without a shared face.

So the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A)} LaTex  7}</math>

~[https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/User:Isabelchen isabelchen]

For real numbers <math>x</math>, let

where <math>i =  LaTex sqrt{-1}</math>. For how many values of <math>x</math> with <math>0 LaTex leq x<2 LaTex pi</math> does 
<cmath>P(x)=0?</cmath>

So, <math>3x = 2x + 4</math> and <math>x=4</math> meaning there are <math>4</math> red cards in the deck at the start and <math>2(4) = 8</math> black cards.

prompt: The point <math>P(a,b)</math> in the <math>xy</math>-plane is first rotated counterclockwise by <math>90^ LaTex circ</math> around the point <math>(1,5)</math> and then reflected about the line <math>y=-x</math>. The final image of <math>P</math> is <math>(-6,3)</math>. We know the reflection rule for reflecting over <math>y=-x</math> is <math>(x,y)  LaTex rightarrow (-y, -x)</math>. So before the reflection and after rotation the point is <math>(-3,6)</math>.

By definition of rotation, the slope between <math>(-3,6)</math> and <math>(1,5)</math> must be perpendicular to the slope between <math>(a,b)</math> and <math>(1,5)</math>. The first slope is <math> LaTex frac{5-6}{1-(-3)} =  LaTex frac{-1}{4}</math>. This means the slope of <math>P</math> and <math>(1,5)</math> is <math>4</math>.

Rotations also preserve distance to the center of rotation, and since we only "travelled" up and down by the slope once to get from <math>(3,-6)</math> to <math>(1,5)</math> it follows we shall only use the slope once to travel from <math>(1,5)</math> to <math>P</math>.

Therefore point <math>P</math> is located at <math>(1+1, 5+4) = (2,9)</math>. The answer is <math>9-2 = 7 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D)} ~7}</math>.

prompt: Three equally spaced parallel lines intersect a circle, creating three chords of lengths <math>38,38,</math> and <math>34</math>. What is the distance between two adjacent parallel lines?
completion:
<asy>
size(8cm);
pair O = (0, 0), A = (0, 3), B = (0, 9), R = (19, 3), L = (17, 9);
draw(O--A--B);
draw(O--R);
draw(O--L);
label("$A$", A, NE);
label("$B$", B, N);
label("$R$", R, NE);
label("$L$", L, NE);
label("$O$", O, S);
label("$d$", O--A, W);
label("$2d$", A--B, W);
label("$r$", O--R, S);
label("$r$", O--L, NW);
dot(O);
dot(A);
dot(B);
dot(R);
dot(L);

draw(circle((0, 0), sqrt(370)));
draw(-R -- (R.x, -R.y));
draw((-R.x, R.y) -- R);
draw((-L.x, L.y) -- L);
</asy>



Since two parallel chords have the same length (<math>38</math>), they must be equidistant from the center of the circle. Let the perpendicular distance of each chord from the center of the circle be <math>d</math>. Thus, the distance from the center of the circle to the chord of length <math>34</math> is 

<cmath>2d + d = 3d</cmath>

and the distance between each of the chords is just <math>2d</math>. Let the radius of the circle be <math>r</math>. Drawing radii to the points where the lines intersect the circle, we create two different right triangles: 

- One with base <math> LaTex frac{38}{2}= 19</math>, height <math>d</math>, and hypotenuse <math>r</math>  (<math> LaTex triangle RAO</math> on the diagram)

- Another with base <math> LaTex frac{34}{2} = 17</math>, height <math>3d</math>, and hypotenuse <math>r</math>  (<math> LaTex triangle LBO</math> on the diagram)

By the Pythagorean theorem, we can create the following system of equations:

<cmath>19^2 + d^2 = r^2</cmath>

<cmath>17^2 + (2d + d)^2 = r^2</cmath>

Solving, we find <math>d = 3</math>, so <math>2d =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B)} LaTex  6}</math>.

-Solution by Joeya, diagram by Jamess2022(burntTacos), and minor edits by lpieleanu.

Note that
<cmath> LaTex begin{align*}
x^{2^{ LaTex sqrt{2}}} &= { LaTex sqrt{2}}^{2^x}  LaTex  LaTex 
2^{ LaTex sqrt{2}}  LaTex log_2 x &= 2^{x}  LaTex log_2  LaTex sqrt{2}.
 LaTex end{align*}</cmath>
(At this point we see by inspection that <math>x= LaTex sqrt{2}</math> is a solution.)

We simplify the RHS, then take the base-<math>2</math> logarithm for both sides:
<cmath> LaTex begin{align*}
2^{ LaTex sqrt{2}}  LaTex log_2 x &= 2^{x-1}  LaTex  LaTex

 LaTex sqrt{2} +  LaTex log_2  LaTex log_2 x &= x-1  LaTex  LaTex

 LaTex end{align*}</cmath>
The RHS is a line; the LHS is a concave curve that looks like a logarithm and has <math>x</math> intercept at <math>(2,0).</math>

There are at most two solutions, one of which is <math> LaTex sqrt{2}.</math> But note that at <math>x=2,</math> we have <math> LaTex log_2  LaTex log_2 {2} = 0 > 2 - 1 -  LaTex sqrt{2},</math> meaning that the log log curve is above the line, so it must intersect the line again at a point <math>x > 2.</math> Now we check <math>x=4</math> and see that <math> LaTex log_2  LaTex log_2 {4} = 1 < 4 - 1 -  LaTex sqrt{2},</math> which means at <math>x=4</math> the line is already above the log log curve. Thus, the second solution lies in the interval <math>(2,4).</math>

prompt:
Arjun and Beth play a game in which they take turns removing one brick or two adjacent bricks from one "wall" among a set of several walls of bricks, with gaps possibly creating new walls. The walls are one brick tall. For example, a set of walls of sizes <math>4</math> and <math>2</math> can be changed into any of the following by one move: <math>(3,2),(2,1,2),(4),(4,1),(2,2),</math> or <math>(1,1,2).</math>

<asy> unitsize(4mm); real[] boxes = {0,1,2,3,5,6,13,14,15,17,18,21,22,24,26,27,30,31,32,33}; for(real i:boxes){ 	draw(box((i,0),(i+1,3))); } draw((8,1.5)--(12,1.5),Arrow()); defaultpen(fontsize(20pt)); label(",",(20,0)); label(",",(29,0)); label(",...",(35.5,0)); </asy>

Arjun plays first, and the player who removes the last brick wins. For which starting configuration is there a strategy that guarantees a win for Beth?
completion:
We say that a game state is an N-position if it is winning for the next player (the player to move), and a P-position if it is winning for the other player. We are trying to find which of the given states is a P-position.

First we note that symmetrical positions are P-positions, as the second player can win by mirroring the first player's moves. It follows that <math>(6, 1, 1)</math> is an N-position, since we can win by moving to <math>(2, 2, 1, 1)</math>; this rules out <math> LaTex textbf{(A)}</math>. We next look at <math>(6, 2, 1)</math>. The possible next states are
<cmath>(6, 2),  LaTex enskip (6, 1, 1),  LaTex enskip (6, 1),  LaTex enskip (5, 2, 1),  LaTex enskip (4, 2, 1, 1),  LaTex enskip (4, 2, 1),  LaTex enskip (3, 2, 2, 1),  LaTex enskip (3, 2, 1, 1),  LaTex enskip (2, 2, 2, 1).</cmath>
None of these are symmetrical, so we might reasonably suspect that they are all N-positions. Indeed, it just so happens that for all of these states except <math>(6, 2)</math> and <math>(6, 1)</math>, we can win by moving to <math>(2, 2, 1, 1)</math>; it remains to check that <math>(6, 2)</math> and <math>(6, 1)</math> are N-positions.

To save ourselves work, it would be nice if we could find a single P-position directly reachable from both <math>(6, 2)</math> and <math>(6, 1)</math>. We notice that <math>(3, 2, 1)</math> is directly reachable from both states, so it would suffice to show that <math>(3, 2, 1)</math> is a P-position. Indeed, the possible next states are
<cmath>(3, 2),  LaTex enskip (3, 1, 1),  LaTex enskip (3, 1),  LaTex enskip (2, 2, 1),  LaTex enskip (2, 1, 1, 1),  LaTex enskip (2, 1, 1),</cmath>
which allow for the following refutations:

<cmath> LaTex begin{align*}
&(3, 2)  LaTex to (2, 2), && &&(3, 1, 1)  LaTex to (1, 1, 1, 1), && &&(3, 1)  LaTex to (1, 1),  LaTex  LaTex 
&(2, 2, 1)  LaTex to (2, 2), && &&(2, 1, 1, 1)  LaTex to (1, 1, 1, 1), && &&(2, 1, 1)  LaTex to (1, 1).
 LaTex end{align*}</cmath>

Hence, <math>(3, 2, 1)</math> is a P-position, so <math>(6, 2)</math> and <math>(6, 1)</math> are both N-positions, along with all other possible next states from <math>(6, 2, 1)</math> as noted before. Thus, <math>(6, 2, 1)</math> is a P-position, so our answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B)}}</math>. (For completeness, we could also rule out <math> LaTex textbf{(C)}</math>, <math> LaTex textbf{(D)}</math> and <math> LaTex textbf{(E)}</math> as in Solution 2.)

-Note: In general, this game is very complicated. For example <math>(8, 7, 5, 3, 2)</math> is winning for the first player but good luck showing that.

prompt: Three balls are randomly and independently tossed into bins numbered with the positive integers so that for each ball, the probability that it is tossed into bin <math>i</math> is <math>2^{-i}</math> for <math>i=1,2,3,....</math> More than one ball is allowed in each bin. The probability that the balls end up evenly spaced in distinct bins is <math> LaTex frac pq,</math> where <math>p</math> and <math>q</math> are relatively prime positive integers. (For example, the balls are evenly spaced if they are tossed into bins <math>3,17,</math> and <math>10.</math>) What is <math>p+q?</math>
completion:
"Evenly spaced" just means the bins form an arithmetic sequence.

Suppose the middle bin in the sequence is <math>x</math>. There are <math>x-1</math> different possibilities for the first bin, and these two bins uniquely determine the final bin. Now, the probability that these <math>3</math> bins are chosen is <math>6 LaTex cdot 2^{-3x} = 6 LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{1}{8^x}</math>, so the probability <math>x</math> is the middle bin is <math>6 LaTex cdot LaTex frac{x-1}{8^x}</math>. Then, we want the sum
<cmath> LaTex begin{align*}
6 LaTex sum_{x=2}^{ LaTex infty} LaTex frac{x-1}{8^x} &=  LaTex frac{6}{8} LaTex left[ LaTex frac{1}{8} +  LaTex frac{2}{8^2} +  LaTex frac{3}{8^3} LaTex cdots LaTex right] LaTex  LaTex 
&=  LaTex frac34 LaTex left[ LaTex left( LaTex frac{1}{8} +  LaTex frac{1}{8^2} +  LaTex frac{1}{8^3}+ LaTex cdots  LaTex right) +  LaTex left( LaTex frac{1}{8^2} +  LaTex frac{1}{8^3} +  LaTex frac{1}{8^4} +  LaTex cdots  LaTex right) +  LaTex cdots LaTex right] LaTex  LaTex 
&=  LaTex frac34 LaTex left[ LaTex frac17 LaTex cdot  LaTex left(1 +  LaTex frac{1}{8} +  LaTex frac{1}{8^2} +  LaTex frac{1}{8^3} +  LaTex cdots  LaTex right) LaTex right] LaTex  LaTex 
&=  LaTex frac34 LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{8}{49} LaTex  LaTex 
&=  LaTex frac{6}{49}
 LaTex end{align*}</cmath>
The answer is <math>6+49= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A) }55}.</math>

Let <math>X</math> denote the intersection point of the diagonals <math>AC</math> and <math>BD</math>. Remark that by symmetry <math>X</math> is the midpoint of both <math> LaTex overline{PQ}</math> and <math> LaTex overline{RS}</math>, so <math>XP = XQ = 3</math> and <math>XR = XS = 4</math>. Now note that since <math> LaTex angle APB =  LaTex angle ARB = 90^ LaTex circ</math>, quadrilateral <math>ARPB</math> is cyclic, and so
<cmath>XR LaTex cdot XA = XP LaTex cdot XB,</cmath>which implies <math> LaTex tfrac{XA}{XB} =  LaTex tfrac{XP}{XR} =  LaTex tfrac34</math>.

Thus let <math>x> 0</math> be such that <math>XA = 3x</math> and <math>XB = 4x</math>. Then Pythagorean Theorem on <math> LaTex triangle APX</math> yields <math>AP =  LaTex sqrt{AX^2 - XP^2} = 3 LaTex sqrt{x^2-1}</math>, and so<cmath>[ABCD] = 2[ABD] = AP LaTex cdot BD = 3 LaTex sqrt{x^2-1} LaTex cdot 8x = 24x LaTex sqrt{x^2-1}=15</cmath>Solving this for <math>x^2</math> yields <math>x^2 =  LaTex tfrac12 +  LaTex tfrac{ LaTex sqrt{41}}8</math>, and so<cmath>(8x)^2 = 64x^2 = 64 LaTex left( LaTex tfrac12 +  LaTex tfrac{ LaTex sqrt{41}}8 LaTex right) = 32 + 8 LaTex sqrt{41}.</cmath>The requested answer is <math>32 + 8 + 41 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A)} ~81}</math>.

prompt: Let <math>S</math> be the set of lattice points in the coordinate plane, both of whose coordinates are integers between <math>1</math> and <math>30,</math> inclusive. Exactly <math>300</math> points in <math>S</math> lie on or below a line with equation <math>y=mx.</math> The possible values of <math>m</math> lie in an interval of length <math> LaTex frac ab,</math> where <math>a</math> and <math>b</math> are relatively prime positive integers. What is <math>a+b?</math>
completion:
First, we find a numerical representation for the number of lattice points in <math>S</math> that are under the line <math>y=mx. </math> For any value of <math>x,</math> the highest lattice point under <math>y=mx</math> is <math> LaTex lfloor mx  LaTex rfloor. </math> Because every lattice point from <math>(x, 1)</math> to <math>(x,  LaTex lfloor mx  LaTex rfloor)</math> is under the line, the total number of lattice points under the line is <math> LaTex sum_{x=1}^{30}( LaTex lfloor mx  LaTex rfloor). </math>


Now, we proceed by finding lower and upper bounds for <math>m. </math> To find the lower bound, we start with an approximation. If <math>300</math> lattice points are below the line, then around <math> LaTex frac{1}{3}</math> of the area formed by <math>S</math> is under the line. By using the formula for a triangle's area, we find that when <math>x=30, y  LaTex approx 20. </math> Solving for <math>m</math> assuming that <math>(30, 20)</math> is a point on the line, we get <math>m =  LaTex frac{2}{3}. </math> Plugging in <math>m</math> to <math> LaTex sum_{x=1}^{30}( LaTex lfloor mx  LaTex rfloor), </math> we get:

<cmath> LaTex sum_{x=1}^{30}( LaTex lfloor  LaTex frac{2}{3}x  LaTex rfloor) = 0 + 1 + 2 + 2 + 3 +  LaTex cdots + 18 + 18 + 19 + 20</cmath>

We have a repeat every <math>3</math> values (every time <math>y= LaTex frac{2}{3}x</math> goes through a lattice point). Thus, we can use arithmetic sequences to calculate the value above:

<cmath> LaTex sum_{x=1}^{30}( LaTex lfloor  LaTex frac{2}{3}x  LaTex rfloor) = 0 + 1 + 2 + 2 + 3 +  LaTex cdots + 18 + 18 + 19 + 20</cmath><cmath>= LaTex frac{20(21)}{2} + 2 + 4 + 6 +  LaTex cdots + 18 </cmath><cmath>=210 +  LaTex frac{20}{2} LaTex cdot 9</cmath><cmath>=300</cmath>

This means that <math> LaTex frac{2}{3}</math> is a possible value of <math>m. </math> Furthermore, it is the lower bound for <math>m. </math> This is because <math>y= LaTex frac{2}{3}x</math> goes through many points (such as <math>(21, 14)</math>). If <math>m</math> was lower, <math>y=mx</math> would no longer go through some of these points, and there would be less than <math>300</math> lattice points under it.

Now, we find an upper bound for <math>m. </math> Imagine increasing <math>m</math> slowly and rotating the line <math>y=mx, </math> starting from the lower bound of <math>m= LaTex frac{2}{3}. </math>The upper bound for <math>m</math> occurs when <math>y=mx</math> intersects a lattice point again (look at this problem to get a better idea of what's happening: https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/2011_AMC_10B_Problems/Problem_24).

In other words, we are looking for the first <math>m >  LaTex frac{2}{3}</math> that is expressible as a ratio of positive integers <math> LaTex frac{p}{q}</math> with <math>q  LaTex le 30. </math> For each <math>q=1, LaTex dots,30</math>, the smallest multiple of <math> LaTex frac{1}{q}</math> which exceeds <math> LaTex frac{2}{3}</math> is <math>1,  LaTex frac{2}{2},  LaTex frac{3}{3},  LaTex frac{3}{4},  LaTex frac{4}{5},  LaTex cdots ,  LaTex frac{19}{27},  LaTex frac{19}{28},  LaTex frac{20}{29},  LaTex frac{21}{30}</math> respectively, and the smallest of these is <math> LaTex frac{19}{28}. </math>

Alternatively, see the method of finding upper bounds in solution 2.

The lower bound is <math> LaTex frac{2}{3}</math> and the upper bound is <math> LaTex frac{19}{28}. </math> Their difference is <math> LaTex frac{1}{84}, </math> so the answer is <math>1 + 84 =  LaTex boxed{85}. </math>

~JimY
~Minor edits by sl_hc

An alternative would be using Farey fractions and the mediant theorem to find the upper bound. <math> LaTex frac{2}{3}</math> and <math> LaTex frac{7}{10}</math> gives <math> LaTex frac{9}{13},</math> and so on using Farey addition.

An alternative approach with the same methodology can be done using Pick's Theorem. Wikipedia page: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pick%27s_theorem. It's a formula to find the number of lattice points strictly inside a polygon. Approximation of the lower bound is still necessary.

prompt: There are 10 people standing equally spaced around a circle. Each person knows exactly 3 of the other 9 people: the 2 people standing next to her or him, as well as the person directly across the circle. How many ways are there for the 10 people to split up into 5 pairs so that the members of each pair know each other?
completion:
Consider the <math>10</math> people to be standing in a circle, where two people opposite each other form a diameter of the circle.

Let us use casework on the number of pairs that form a diameter of the circle.

Case 1: <math>0</math> diameters

There are <math>2</math> ways: either <math>1</math> pairs with <math>2</math>, <math>3</math> pairs with <math>4</math>, and so on or <math>10</math> pairs with <math>1</math>, <math>2</math> pairs with <math>3</math>, etc.

Case 2: <math>1</math> diameter

There are <math>5</math> possible diameters to draw (everyone else pairs with the person next to them).

Note that there cannot be <math>2</math> diameters since there would be one person on either side that will not have a pair adjacent to them. The only scenario forced is when the two people on either side would be paired up across a diameter. Thus, a contradiction will arise.

Case 3: <math>3</math> diameters

There are <math>5</math> possible sets of <math>3</math> diameters to draw.
Notice we are technically choosing the number of ways to choose a pair of two diameters that are neighbors to each other. This means we can choose the first diameter in the pair, and have only two diameters to choose from for the second in the pair. This means we have <math>5*2=10</math> possibilities for choosing 5 neighboring diameters. However, notice that there are duplicates, so we divide the <math>10</math> possibilities by <math>2</math> to get <math>5</math>.

Note that there cannot be a case with <math>4</math> diameters because then there would have to be <math>5</math> diameters for the two remaining people as they have to be connected with a diameter. A contradiction arises.

Case 4: <math>5</math> diameters

There is only <math>1</math> way to do this.

Thus, in total there are <math>2+5+5+1= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(C) }13}</math> possible ways.
- Minor edits by Pearl2008

prompt: An urn contains one red ball and one blue ball. A box of extra red and blue balls lie nearby. George performs the following operation four times: he draws a ball from the urn at random and then takes a ball of the same color from the box and returns those two matching balls to the urn. After the four iterations the urn contains six balls. What is the probability that the urn contains three balls of each color?
completion:
Suppose that we have a deck, currently containing just one black card. We then insert <math>n</math> red cards one-by-one into the deck at random positions. It is easy to see using induction, that the black card is randomly situated in the deck. 

Now, suppose that we have this deck again, with only one black card. Each time we pick a red ball, we place a card above the black card, and each time we pick a blue ball, we place a card below the black card. It is easy to see that the probability that the card is inserted into the top part of the deck is simply equal to the number of red balls divided by the total number of balls, and the probability that the card is inserted into the bottom part of the deck is equal to the number of blue balls divided by the total number of balls. Therefore, this is equivalent to inserting the card randomly into the deck.

Finally, four more red cards will be inserted into the deck, and so the black card can be in five possible positions. Only one corresponds to having three balls of each type. Our probability is thus <math> LaTex frac{1}{5}</math>, and so the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{B}}</math>.

~mathboy100

prompt: How many polynomials of the form <math>x^5 + ax^4 + bx^3 + cx^2 + dx + 2020</math>, where <math>a</math>, <math>b</math>, <math>c</math>, and <math>d</math> are real numbers, have the property that whenever <math>r</math> is a root, so is <math> LaTex frac{-1+i LaTex sqrt{3}}{2}  LaTex cdot r</math>? (Note that <math>i= LaTex sqrt{-1}</math>)
completion:
Let <math>P(x) = x^5+ax^4+bx^3+cx^2+dx+2020</math>. We first notice that <math> LaTex frac{-1+i LaTex sqrt{3}}{2} = e^{2 LaTex pi i / 3}</math>.  That is because of Euler's Formula : <math>e^{ix} =  LaTex cos(x) + i  LaTex cdot  LaTex sin(x)</math>. <math> LaTex frac{-1+i LaTex sqrt{3}}{2}</math> = <math>- LaTex frac{1}{2} + i  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac { LaTex sqrt{3}}{2}</math> = <math> LaTex cos(120^ LaTex circ) + i  LaTex cdot  LaTex sin(120^ LaTex circ) = e^{ 2 LaTex pi i / 3}</math>.

In order <math>r</math> to be a root of <math>P</math>, <math>re^{2 LaTex pi i / 3}</math> must also be a root of P, meaning that 3 of the roots of <math>P</math> must be <math>r</math>, <math>re^{i LaTex frac{2 LaTex pi}{3}}</math>, <math>re^{i LaTex frac{4 LaTex pi}{3}}</math>. However, since <math>P</math> is degree 5, there must be two additional roots. Let one of these roots be <math>w</math>, if <math>w</math> is a root, then <math>we^{2 LaTex pi i / 3}</math> and <math>we^{4 LaTex pi i / 3}</math> must also be roots. However, <math>P</math> is a fifth degree polynomial, and can therefore only have <math>5</math> roots. This implies that <math>w</math> is either <math>r</math>, <math>re^{2 LaTex pi i / 3}</math>, or <math>re^{4 LaTex pi i / 3}</math>. Thus we know that the polynomial <math>P</math> can be written in the form <math>(x-r)^m(x-re^{2 LaTex pi i / 3})^n(x-re^{4 LaTex pi i / 3})^p</math>. Moreover, by Vieta's, we know that there is only one possible value for the magnitude of <math>r</math> as <math>||r||^5 = 2020</math>, meaning that the amount of possible polynomials <math>P</math> is equivalent to the possible sets <math>(m,n,p)</math>. In order for the coefficients of the polynomial to all be real, <math>n = p</math> due to <math>re^{2 LaTex pi i / 3}</math> and <math>re^{4  LaTex pi i / 3}</math> being conjugates and since <math>m+n+p = 5</math>, (as the polynomial is 5th degree) we have two possible solutions for <math>(m, n, p)</math> which are <math>(1,2,2)</math> and <math>(3,1,1)</math> yielding two possible polynomials. The answer is thus <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(C) } 2}</math>.

~Murtagh

prompt: Two different cubes of the same size are to be painted, with the color of each face being chosen independently and at random to be either black or white. What is the probability that after they are painted, the cubes can be rotated to be identical in appearance?
completion:
Define two ways of painting to be in the same <math>class</math> if one can be rotated to form the other.

We can count the number of ways of painting for each specific <math>class</math>.

Case 1: Black-white color distribution is 0-6 (out of 6 total faces)

Trivially <math>1^2 = 1</math> way to paint the cubes.

Case 2: Black-white color distribution is 1-5

Trivially all <math> LaTex dbinom{6}{5} = 6</math> ways belong to the same <math>class</math>, so <math>6^2</math> ways to paint the cubes.

Case 3: Black-white color distribution is 2-4

There are two <math>classes</math> for this case: the <math>class</math> where the two red faces are touching and the other <math>class</math> where the two red faces are on opposite faces. There are <math>3</math> members of the latter <math>class</math> since there are <math>3</math> unordered pairs of <math>2</math> opposite faces of a cube. Thus, there are <math> LaTex dbinom{6}{4} - 3 = 12</math> members of the former <math>class</math>. Thus, <math>12^2 + 3^2</math> ways to paint the cubes for this case.

Case 4: Black-white color distribution is 3-3

By simple intuition, there are also two <math>classes</math> for this case, the <math>class</math> where the three red faces meet at a single vertex, and the other class where the three red faces are in a "straight line" along the edges of the cube. Note that since there are <math>8</math> vertices in a cube, there are <math>8</math> members of the former class and <math> LaTex dbinom{6}{3} - 8 = 12</math> members of the latter class. Thus, <math>12^2 + 8^2</math> ways to paint the cubes for this case.

Note that by symmetry (since we are only switching the colors), the number of ways to paint the cubes for black-white color distributions 4-2, 5-1, and 6-0 is 2-4, 1-5, and 0-6 (respectively).

Thus, our total answer is<cmath> LaTex frac{2(6^2 + 1^2 + 12^2 + 3^2) + 12^2 + 8^2}{2^{12}} =  LaTex frac{588}{4096} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D) }  LaTex frac{147}{1024}}.</cmath>


-fidgetboss_4000

prompt: How many positive integers <math>n</math> satisfy<cmath> LaTex frac{n+1000}{70} =  LaTex lfloor  LaTex sqrt{n}  LaTex rfloor?</cmath>(Recall that <math> LaTex lfloor x LaTex rfloor</math> is the greatest integer not exceeding <math>x</math>.)
completion:
We can first consider the equation without a floor function:

<cmath> LaTex dfrac{n+1000}{70} =  LaTex sqrt{n} </cmath>

Multiplying both sides by 70 and then squaring:

<cmath>n^2 + 2000n + 1000000 = 4900n</cmath>

Moving all terms to the left:

<cmath>n^2 - 2900n + 1000000 = 0</cmath>

Now we can determine the factors:

<cmath>(n-400)(n-2500) = 0</cmath>

This means that for <math>n = 400</math> and <math>n = 2500</math>, the equation will hold without the floor function.

Now we can simply check the multiples of 70 around 400 and 2500 in the original equation:

For <math>n = 330</math>, left hand side  <math>=19</math> but <math>18^2 < 330 < 19^2</math> so right hand side  <math>=18</math>

For <math>n = 400</math>, left hand side  <math>=20</math> and right hand side  <math>=20</math>

For <math>n = 470</math>, left hand side  <math>=21</math> and right hand side  <math>=21</math>

For <math>n = 540</math>, left hand side  <math>=22</math> but <math>540 > 23^2</math> so right hand side  <math>=23</math>

Now we move to <math>n = 2500</math>

For <math>n = 2430</math>, left hand side  <math>=49</math> and <math>49^2 < 2430 < 50^2</math> so right hand side  <math>=49</math>

For <math>n = 2360</math>, left hand side  <math>=48</math> and <math>48^2 < 2360 < 49^2</math> so right hand side  <math>=48</math>

For <math>n = 2290</math>, left hand side  <math>=47</math> and <math>47^2 < 2360 < 48^2</math> so right hand side  <math>=47</math>

For <math>n = 2220</math>, left hand side  <math>=46</math> but <math>47^2 < 2220</math> so right hand side  <math>=47</math>

For <math>n = 2500</math>, left hand side  <math>=50</math> and right hand side  <math>=50</math>

For <math>n = 2570</math>, left hand side  <math>=51</math> but <math>2570 < 51^2</math> so right hand side  <math>=50</math>

Therefore we have 6 total solutions, <math>n = 400, 470, 2290, 2360, 2430, 2500 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(C) 6}}</math>

prompt:
How many integers <math>n  LaTex geq 2</math> are there such that whenever <math>z_1, z_2, ..., z_n</math> are complex numbers such that

<cmath>|z_1| = |z_2| = ... = |z_n| = 1  LaTex text{    and    } z_1 + z_2 + ... + z_n = 0,</cmath>
then the numbers <math>z_1, z_2, ..., z_n</math> are equally spaced on the unit circle in the complex plane?
completion:
For <math>n=2</math>, we see that if <math>z_{1}+z_{2}=0</math>, then <math>z_{1}=-z_{2}</math>, so they are evenly spaced along the unit circle.

For <math>n=3</math>, WLOG, we can set <math>z_{1}=1</math>. Notice that now <math> LaTex Re(z_{2}+z_{3})=-1</math> and <math> LaTex Im LaTex {z_{2} LaTex }=- LaTex Im LaTex {z_{3} LaTex }</math>. This forces <math>z_{2}</math> and <math>z_{3}</math> to be equal to <math>e^{i LaTex frac{2 LaTex pi}{3}}</math> and <math>e^{-i LaTex frac{2 LaTex pi}{3}}</math>, meaning that all three are equally spaced along the unit circle.

We can now show that we can construct complex numbers when <math>n LaTex geq 4</math> that do not satisfy the conditions in the problem.

Suppose that the condition in the problem holds for some <math>n=k</math>. We can now add two points <math>z_{k+1}</math> and <math>z_{k+2}</math> anywhere on the unit circle such that <math>z_{k+1}=-z_{k+2}</math>, which will break the condition. The Pythagorean triple <math>9</math> - <math>12</math> - <math>15</math> allows us easily to determine that the base is <math>24</math> and the height is <math>9</math>. The formula <math> LaTex frac { LaTex text{base}  LaTex cdot  LaTex text{height}} {2}</math> can also be used to find the area of the triangle as <math>108</math>, while the semiperimeter is simply <math> LaTex frac {15 + 15 + 24} {2} = 27</math>. After plugging into the equation, we thus get <math>108 =  LaTex text{inradius}  LaTex cdot 27</math>, so the inradius is <math>4</math>. Now, let the distance between <math>O</math> and the triangle be <math>x</math>. Choose a point on the incircle and denote it by <math>A</math>. The distance from point <math>A</math> to the center of the incircle is <math>4</math>, because it is the radius of the incircle. By using the Pythagorean Theorem, we thus find <math>x =  LaTex sqrt{6^2-4^2}= LaTex sqrt{20} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf {(D) } 2  LaTex sqrt {5}}</math>.

The main insight is that 

<cmath> LaTex frac{(n^2)!}{(n!)^{n+1}}</cmath> 

is always an integer. This is true because it is precisely the number of ways to split up <math>n^2</math> objects into <math>n</math> unordered groups of size <math>n</math>. Thus,

<cmath> LaTex frac{(n^2-1)!}{(n!)^n}= LaTex frac{(n^2)!}{(n!)^{n+1}} LaTex cdot LaTex frac{n!}{n^2}</cmath>

is an integer if <math>n^2  LaTex mid n!</math>, or in other words, if <math> LaTex frac{(n-1)!}{n}</math>, is an integer. This condition is false precisely when <math>n=4</math> or <math>n</math> is prime, by [[Wilson's Theorem]]. There are <math>15</math> primes between <math>1</math> and <math>50</math>, inclusive, so there are <math>15 + 1 = 16</math> terms for which

<cmath> LaTex frac{(n^2-1)!}{(n!)^{n}}</cmath>

is potentially not an integer. It can be easily verified that the above expression is not an integer for <math>n=4</math> as there are more factors of <math>2</math> in the denominator than the numerator. Similarly, it can be verified that the above expression is not an integer for any prime <math>n=p</math>, as there are more factors of p in the denominator than the numerator. Thus all <math>16</math> values of n make the expression not an integer and the answer is <math>50-16= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D)} LaTex  34}</math>.

SideNote: Another method to prove that <cmath> LaTex frac{(n^2)!}{(n!)^{n+1}}</cmath> is always an integer is instead as follows using Number Theory. Notice that <math>n</math> will divide the numerator <math>n+1</math> times, since <math>n^2 = n  LaTex times n</math> contains not one but two factors of <math>n.</math> Also, for <math>a < n,</math> notice that <math>a</math> divides <math>(n^2)!</math> at least <cmath> LaTex lfloor  LaTex frac{n^2}{a}  LaTex rfloor  LaTex ge  LaTex lfloor  LaTex frac{n^2}{n-1}  LaTex rfloor  LaTex ge  LaTex lfloor  LaTex frac{n^2 - 1}{n-1}  LaTex rfloor  LaTex ge n+1</cmath> times. Thus, each integer from <math>1</math> to <math>n</math> will divide <math>(n^2)!</math> at least <math>n+1</math> times, which proves such a lemma. <math> LaTex square{}</math>

Dividing these two equations gives <math>q+1=-1</math>, so <math>q=-2</math>. Substituting back, we get <math>p=-60</math> and <math>r=60</math>.

Our induction is complete, so for all positive integers <math>n</math>, <math>x_n=(-2)^n(x_0-60)+60</math>. Identical equalities hold for <math>y_n</math> and <math>z_n</math>.

prompt: A red ball and a green ball are randomly and independently tossed into bins numbered with the positive integers so that for each ball, the probability that it is tossed into bin k is 2^{-k} for k = 1,2,3.... What is the probability that the red ball is tossed into a higher-numbered bin than the green ball?

By symmetry, the probability of the red ball landing in a higher-numbered bin is the same as the probability of the green ball landing in a higher-numbered bin. Clearly, the probability of both landing in the same bin is <math> LaTex sum_{k=1}^{ LaTex infty}{2^{-k}  LaTex cdot 2^{-k}} =  LaTex sum_{k=1}^{ LaTex infty}2^{-2k} =  LaTex frac{1}{3}</math> (by the geometric series sum formula). Note: the formula is <math> LaTex frac{a_{1}}{1-r}</math> where <math>a_{1}</math> is the first term and <math>r</math> is the common ratio.
Derivation of the geometric series sum formula:
Let <math>S = S=a_{1}+a_{1}r+a_{1}r^{2}+a_{1}r^{3}+...</math> and so on to infinity.
Then <math>rS=a_{1}r+a_{1}r^{2}+a_{1}r^{3}+...</math> and so on to infinity. Notice that the terms in the second expression are the same as all the terms in the first EXCEPT for <math>a_{1}</math>.
Subtract <math>S-rS=a_{1}</math>, factor <math>S LaTex left(1-r LaTex right)=a_{1}</math>, and finally <math>S= LaTex frac{a_{1}}{1-r}</math>.

Post scriptum. The formula only works if r is less than 1; otherwise, the series will diverge to infinity or negative infinity.
~JH. L

prompt: There are lily pads in a row numbered <math>0</math> to <math>11</math>, in that order.
