Fiona the frog starts on pad <math>0</math>, and from any given lily pad, has a <math> LaTex frac{1}{2}</math> chance to hop to the next pad, and an equal chance to jump <math>2</math> pads. What is the probability that Fiona reaches pad <math>10</math> without landing on either pad <math>3</math> or pad <math>6</math>?
completion:
Firstly, notice that if Fiona jumps over the predator on pad <math>3</math>, she must land on pad <math>4</math>. Similarly, she must land on <math>7</math> if she makes it past <math>6</math>. Thus, we can split the problem into <math>3</math> smaller sub-problems, separately finding the probability. Fiona skips <math>3</math>, the probability she skips <math>6</math> (starting at <math>4</math>) and the probability she ''doesn't'' skip <math>10</math> (starting at <math>7</math>). Notice that by symmetry, the last of these three sub-problems is the complement of the first sub-problem, so the probability will be <math>1 -  LaTex text{the probability obtained in the first sub-problem}</math>.

In the analysis below, we call the larger jump a <math>2</math>-jump, and the smaller a <math>1</math>-jump. 

For the first sub-problem, consider Fiona's options. She can either go <math>1</math>-jump, <math>1</math>-jump, <math>2</math>-jump, with probability <math> LaTex frac{1}{8}</math>, or she can go <math>2</math>-jump, <math>2</math>-jump, with probability <math> LaTex frac{1}{4}</math>. These are the only two options, so they together make the answer <math> LaTex frac{1}{8}+ LaTex frac{1}{4}= LaTex frac{3}{8}</math>. We now also know the answer to the last sub-problem is <math>1- LaTex frac{3}{8}= LaTex frac{5}{8}</math>.

For the second sub-problem, Fiona ''must'' go <math>1</math>-jump, <math>2</math>-jump, with probability <math> LaTex frac{1}{4}</math>, since any other option would result in her death to a predator.

Thus, since the three sub-problems are independent, the final answer is <math> LaTex frac{3}{8}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{1}{4}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{5}{8} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A) } LaTex frac{15}{256}}</math>.

prompt: Raashan, Sylvia, and Ted play the following game. Each starts with <math>  LaTex $1</math>. A bell rings every <math>15</math> seconds, at which time each of the players who currently have money simultaneously chooses one of the other two players independently and at random and gives <math> LaTex $1</math> to that player. What is the probability that after the bell has rung <math>2019</math> times, each player will have <math> LaTex $1</math>? (For example, Raashan and Ted may each decide to give <math> LaTex $1</math> to Sylvia, and Sylvia may decide to give her dollar to Ted, at which point Raashan will have <math> LaTex $0</math>, Sylvia will have <math> LaTex $2</math>, and Ted will have <math> LaTex $1</math>, and that is the end of the first round of play. In the second round Rashaan has no money to give, but Sylvia and Ted might choose each other to give their <math>  LaTex $1</math> to, and the holdings will be the same at the end of the second round.)
completion:
On the first turn, each player starts off with <math> LaTex $1</math>. Each turn after that, there are only two possibilities: either everyone stays at <math> LaTex $1</math>, which we will write as <math>(1-1-1)</math>, or the distribution of money becomes <math> LaTex $2- LaTex $1- LaTex $0</math> in some order, which we write as <math>(2-1-0)</math>. (<math>(3-0-0)</math> cannot be achieved since either(1)the person cannot give money to himself or (2)there are a maximum of 2 dollars being distributed and the person has nothing to start with). We will consider these two states separately.

In the <math>(1-1-1)</math> state, each person has two choices for whom to give their dollar to, meaning there are <math>2^3=8</math> possible ways that the money can be rearranged. Note that there are only two ways that we can reach <math>(1-1-1)</math> again: 

1. Raashan gives his money to Sylvia, who gives her money to Ted, who gives his money to Raashan.

2. Raashan gives his money to Ted, who gives his money to Sylvia, who gives her money to Raashan.

Thus, the probability of staying in the <math>(1-1-1)</math> state is <math> LaTex frac{1}{4}</math>, while the probability of going to the <math>(2-1-0)</math> state is <math> LaTex frac{3}{4}</math> (we can check that the 6 other possibilities lead to <math>(2-1-0)</math>)


In the <math>(2-1-0)</math> state, we will label the person with <math> LaTex $2</math> as person A, the person with <math> LaTex $1</math> as person B, and the person with <math> LaTex $0</math> as person C. Person A has two options for whom to give money to, and person B has 2 options for whom to give money to, meaning there are total <math>2 LaTex cdot 2 = 4</math> ways the money can be redistributed. The only way that the distribution can return to <math>(1-1-1)</math> is if A gives <math> LaTex $1</math> to B, and B gives <math> LaTex $1</math> to C. We check the other possibilities to find that they all lead back to <math>(2-1-0)</math>. Thus, the probability of going to the <math>(1-1-1)</math> state is <math> LaTex frac{1}{4}</math>, while the probability of staying in the <math>(2-1-0)</math> state is <math> LaTex frac{3}{4}</math>.

No matter which state we are in, the probability of going to the <math>(1-1-1)</math> state is always <math> LaTex frac{1}{4}</math>. This means that, after the bell rings 2018 times, regardless of what state the money distribution is in, there is a <math> LaTex frac{1}{4}</math> probability of going to the <math>(1-1-1)</math> state after the 2019th bell ring. Thus, our answer is simply <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B) }  LaTex frac{1}{4}}</math>.

prompt: Points <math>A(6,13)</math> and <math>B(12,11)</math> lie on circle <math> LaTex omega</math> in the plane. completion:

Further, notice (due to the right angles formed by a radius and its tangent line) that the quadrilateral (a kite) <math>AOBX</math> is cyclic. 

Therefore, we can apply [[Ptolemy's Theorem]] to give:

<math>2 LaTex sqrt{170}r = d  LaTex sqrt{40}</math>, where <math>r</math> is the radius of the circle and <math>d</math> is the distance between the circle's center and <math>(5, 0)</math>. Therefore, <math>d =  LaTex sqrt{17}r</math>. 

Using the Pythagorean Theorem on the right triangle <math>OAX</math> (or <math>OBX</math>), we find that <math>170 + r^2 = 17r^2</math>, so <math>r^2 =  LaTex frac{85}{8}</math>, and thus the area of the circle is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(C) } LaTex frac{85}{8} LaTex pi}</math>.

Firstly, if <math>r=s</math>, then <math>a=b=c</math>, so the equation becomes <math>ax^2 + ax + a = 0  LaTex Rightarrow x^2 + x + 1=0</math>, which has no real roots.

Hence there are three cases we need to consider:

'''Case 1''': <math>a=b=r</math> and <math>c=s  LaTex neq r</math>:
The equation becomes <math>ax^2+ax+c=0</math>, and by Vieta's Formulas, we have <math>a+c=-1</math> and <math>ac =  LaTex frac{c}{a}</math>. This second equation becomes <math>(a^2-1)c=0</math>. Hence one possibility is <math>c=0</math>, in which case <math>a=-1</math>, giving the equation <math>-x^2 - x = 0</math>, which has roots <math>0</math> and <math>{-}1</math>. This gives one valid solution. On the other hand, if <math>c LaTex neq 0</math>, then <math>a^2-1=0</math>, so <math>a =  LaTex pm 1</math>. If <math>a=1</math>, we have <math>c=-2</math>, and the equation is <math>x^2 + x - 2 = 0</math>, which clearly works, giving a second valid solution. If <math>a=-1</math>, then we have <math>c=0</math>, which has already been considered, so this possibility gives no further valid solutions.

'''Case 2''': <math>a=c=r</math>, <math>b=s  LaTex neq r</math>:
The equation becomes <math>ax^2 + bx + a = 0</math>, so by Vieta's Formulas, we have <math>a+b = - LaTex frac{b}{a}</math> and <math>ab = 1</math>. These equations reduce to <math>a^3 + a + 1 = 0</math>. By sketching a graph of this function, we see that there is exactly one real root. (Alternatively, note that as it is of odd degree, there is at least one real root, and by differentiation, it has no stationary points, so there is at most one real root. Combining these gives exactly one real root.) This gives a third valid solution.

'''Case 3''': <math>a=r</math>, <math>b=c=s  LaTex neq r</math>: 
The equation becomes <math>ax^2 + bx+b=0</math>, so by Vieta's Formulas, we have <math>a+b = - LaTex frac{b}{a}</math> and <math>ab =  LaTex frac{b}{a}</math>.
Observe that <math>b  LaTex neq 0</math>, as if it were <math>0</math>, the equation would just have one real root, <math>0</math>, so this would not give a valid solution. Thus, taking the second equation and dividing both sides by <math>b</math>, we deduce have <math>a= LaTex frac{1}{a}</math>, so <math>a= LaTex pm 1</math>. If <math>a=1</math>, we have <math>1+b=-b</math>, giving <math>b=- LaTex frac{1}{2}</math>, so the equation is <math>x^2 -  LaTex frac{1}{2}x -  LaTex frac{1}{2} = 0</math>, which is a fourth valid solution. If <math>a=-1</math>, we have <math>1+b=b</math>, which is a contradiction, so this case gives no further valid solutions.

Hence the total number of valid solutions is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B) } 4}</math>.

prompt:

<cmath>x_{n+1}= LaTex frac{x_n^2+5x_n+4}{x_n+6}</cmath>for all nonnegative integers <math>n.</math> Let <math>m</math> be the least positive integer such that

completion:
We first prove that <math>x_n > 4</math> for all <math>n  LaTex ge 0</math>, by induction. Observe that
<cmath>
x_{n+1} - 4 =  LaTex frac{x_n^2 + 5x_n + 4 - 4(x_n+6)}{x_n+6} =  LaTex frac{(x_n - 4)(x_n+5)}{x_n+6}.
</cmath>
so (since <math>x_n</math> is clearly positive for all <math>n</math>, from the initial definition), <math>x_{n+1} > 4</math> if and only if <math>x_{n} > 4</math>.

We similarly prove that <math>x_n</math> is decreasing:
<cmath>
x_{n+1} - x_n =  LaTex frac{x_n^2 + 5x_n + 4 - x_n(x_n+6)}{x_n+6} =  LaTex frac{4-x_n}{x_n+6} < 0.
</cmath>

Now we need to estimate the value of <math>x_{n+1}-4</math>, which we can do using the rearranged equation:
<cmath>
x_{n+1} - 4 = (x_n-4) LaTex cdot LaTex frac{x_n + 5}{x_n+6}. 
</cmath>
Since <math>x_n</math> is decreasing, <math> LaTex frac{x_n + 5}{x_n+6}</math> is also decreasing, so we have
<cmath>
 LaTex frac{9}{10} <  LaTex frac{x_n + 5}{x_n+6}  LaTex le  LaTex frac{10}{11}
</cmath>
and
<cmath>
 LaTex frac{9}{10}(x_n-4) < x_{n+1} - 4  LaTex le  LaTex frac{10}{11}(x_n-4).
</cmath>

This becomes
<cmath>
 LaTex left( LaTex frac{9}{10} LaTex right)^n =  LaTex left( LaTex frac{9}{10} LaTex right)^n  LaTex left(x_0-4 LaTex right) < x_{n} - 4  LaTex le  LaTex left( LaTex frac{10}{11} LaTex right)^n  LaTex left(x_0-4 LaTex right) =  LaTex left( LaTex frac{10}{11} LaTex right)^n.
</cmath>
The problem thus reduces to finding the least value of <math>n</math> such that
<cmath>
 LaTex left( LaTex frac{9}{10} LaTex right)^n < x_{n} - 4  LaTex le  LaTex frac{1}{2^{20}}  LaTex text{  and  } 
 LaTex left( LaTex frac{10}{11} LaTex right)^{n-1} > x_{n-1} - 4 >  LaTex frac{1}{2^{20}}.
</cmath>

Taking logarithms, we get
<math>n  LaTex ln  LaTex frac{9}{10} < -20  LaTex ln 2</math> and <math>(n-1) LaTex ln  LaTex frac{10}{11} > -20  LaTex ln 2</math>, i.e.

<cmath>
n >  LaTex frac{20 LaTex ln 2}{ LaTex ln LaTex frac{10}{9}}  LaTex text{  and  }  n-1 <  LaTex frac{20 LaTex ln 2}{ LaTex ln LaTex frac{11}{10}}
.</cmath>

As approximations, we can use <math> LaTex ln LaTex frac{10}{9}  LaTex approx  LaTex frac{1}{9}</math>, <math> LaTex ln LaTex frac{11}{10}  LaTex approx  LaTex frac{1}{10}</math>, and <math> LaTex ln 2 LaTex approx 0.7</math>. These approximations allow us to estimate
<cmath>
            126 < n < 141,

prompt: How many sequences of <math>0</math>s and <math>1</math>s of length <math>19</math> are there that begin with a <math>0</math>, end with a <math>0</math>, contain no two consecutive <math>0</math>s, and contain no three consecutive <math>1</math>s?
completion:
Let <math>f(n)</math> be the number of valid sequences of length <math>n</math> (satisfying the conditions given in the problem). 

We know our valid sequence must end in a <math>0</math>. Then, since we cannot have two consecutive <math>0</math>s, it must end in a <math>10</math>. Now, we only have two cases: it ends with <math>010</math>, or it ends with <math>110</math> which is equivalent to <math>0110</math>. Thus, our sequence must be of the forms <math>0 LaTex ldots010</math> or <math>0 LaTex ldots0110</math>. In the first case, the first <math>n-2</math> digits are equivalent to a valid sequence of length <math>n-2</math>. In the second, the first <math>n-3</math> digits are equivalent to a valid sequence of length <math>n-3</math>. Therefore, it must be the case that <math>f(n) = f(n-3) + f(n-2)</math>, with <math>n  LaTex ge 3</math> (because otherwise, the sequence would contain only 0s and this is not allowed due to the given conditions). 

It is easy to find <math>f(3) = 1</math> since the only possible valid sequence is <math>010</math>. <math>f(4)=1</math> since the only possible valid sequence is <math>0110</math>. <math>f(5)=1</math> since the only possible valid sequence is <math>01010</math>. 

The recursive sequence is then as follows:

<cmath>f(3)=1</cmath>
<cmath>f(4)=1</cmath>
<cmath>f(5) = 1</cmath>
<cmath>f(6) = 1 + 1 = 2</cmath> 
<cmath>f(7) = 1 + 1 = 2</cmath>
<cmath>f(8) = 1 + 2 = 3</cmath> 
<cmath>f(9) = 2 + 2 = 4</cmath>
<cmath>f(10) = 2 + 3 = 5</cmath>
<cmath>f(11) = 3 + 4 = 7</cmath> 
<cmath>f(12) = 4 + 5 = 9</cmath> 
<cmath>f(13) = 5 + 7 = 12</cmath>
<cmath>f(14) = 7 + 9 = 16</cmath> 
<cmath>f(15) = 9 + 12 = 21</cmath>
<cmath>f(16) = 12 + 16 = 28</cmath>
<cmath>f(17) = 16 + 21 = 37</cmath> 
<cmath>f(18) = 21 + 28 = 49</cmath>
<cmath>f(19) = 28 + 37 = 65</cmath>

So, our answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex text{ LaTex bf{(C)}  } 65}</math>.

completion:
Place an origin at <math>A</math>, and assign position vectors of <math>B =  LaTex vec{p}</math> and <math>D =  LaTex vec{q}</math>. Since <math>AB</math> is not parallel to <math>AD</math>, vectors <math> LaTex vec{p}</math> and <math> LaTex vec{q}</math> are linearly independent, so we can write <math>C = m LaTex vec{p} + n LaTex vec{q}</math> for some constants <math>m</math> and <math>n</math>. Now, recall that the centroid of a triangle <math> LaTex triangle XYZ</math> has position vector <math> LaTex frac{1}{3} LaTex left( LaTex vec{x}+ LaTex vec{y}+ LaTex vec{z} LaTex right)</math>. 

Thus the centroid of <math> LaTex triangle ABC</math> is <math>g_1 =  LaTex frac{1}{3}(m+1) LaTex vec{p} +  LaTex frac{1}{3}n LaTex vec{q}</math>; the centroid of <math> LaTex triangle BCD</math> is <math>g_2 =  LaTex frac{1}{3}(m+1) LaTex vec{p} +  LaTex frac{1}{3}(n+1) LaTex vec{q}</math>; and the centroid of <math> LaTex triangle ACD</math> is <math>g_3 =  LaTex frac{1}{3}m LaTex vec{p} +  LaTex frac{1}{3}(n+1) LaTex vec{q}</math>. 

Hence <math> LaTex overrightarrow{G_{1}G_{2}} =  LaTex frac{1}{3} LaTex vec{q}</math>, <math> LaTex overrightarrow{G_{2}G_{3}} = - LaTex frac{1}{3} LaTex vec{p}</math>, and <math> LaTex overrightarrow{G_{3}G_{1}} =  LaTex frac{1}{3} LaTex vec{p} -  LaTex frac{1}{3} LaTex vec{q}</math>. For <math> LaTex triangle G_{1}G_{2}G_{3}</math> to be equilateral, we need <math> LaTex left| LaTex overrightarrow{G_{1}G_{2}} LaTex right| =  LaTex left| LaTex overrightarrow{G_{2}G_{3}} LaTex right|  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex left| LaTex vec{p} LaTex right| =  LaTex left| LaTex vec{q} LaTex right|  LaTex Rightarrow AB = AD</math>. Further, <math> LaTex left| LaTex overrightarrow{G_{1}G_{2}} LaTex right| =  LaTex left| LaTex overrightarrow{G_{1}G_{3}} LaTex right|  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex left| LaTex vec{p} LaTex right| =  LaTex left| LaTex vec{p} -  LaTex vec{q} LaTex right| = BD</math>. Hence we have <math>AB = AD = BD</math>, so <math> LaTex triangle ABD</math> is equilateral.

Now let the side length of <math> LaTex triangle ABD</math> be <math>k</math>, and let <math> LaTex angle BCD =  LaTex theta</math>. By the Law of Cosines in <math> LaTex triangle BCD</math>, we have <math>k^2 = 2^2 + 6^2 - 2  LaTex cdot 2  LaTex cdot 6  LaTex cdot  LaTex cos{ LaTex theta} = 40 - 24 LaTex cos{ LaTex theta}</math>. Thus the total area of <math>ABCD</math> is <math>10 LaTex sqrt{3} + 6 LaTex left( LaTex sin{ LaTex theta} -  LaTex sqrt{3} LaTex cos{ LaTex theta} LaTex right) = 10 LaTex sqrt{3} + 12 LaTex left( LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex sin{ LaTex theta} -  LaTex frac{ LaTex sqrt{3}}{2} LaTex cos{ LaTex theta} LaTex right) = 10 LaTex sqrt{3}+12 LaTex sin{ LaTex left( LaTex theta-60^{ LaTex circ} LaTex right)}</math>, where in the last step we used the subtraction formula for <math> LaTex sin</math>. Alternatively, we can use calculus to find the local maximum. prompt: A set of <math>n</math> people participate in an online video basketball tournament. Let there be <math>T</math> teams. For each team, there are <math>{n-5 LaTex choose 4}</math> different subsets of <math>9</math> players that includes a given full team, so the total number of team-(group of 9) pairs is 

<cmath>T{n-5 LaTex choose 4}.</cmath>

Thus, the expected value of the number of full teams in a random set of <math>9</math> players is

<cmath> LaTex frac{T{n-5 LaTex choose 4}}{{n LaTex choose 9}}.</cmath>

Similarly, the expected value of the number of full teams in a random set of <math>8</math> players is

<cmath> LaTex frac{T{n-5 LaTex choose 3}}{{n LaTex choose 8}}.</cmath>

The condition is thus equivalent to the existence of a positive integer <math>T</math> such that

<cmath> LaTex frac{T{n-5 LaTex choose 4}}{{n LaTex choose 9}} LaTex frac{T{n-5 LaTex choose 3}}{{n LaTex choose 8}} = 1.</cmath>

<cmath>T^2 LaTex frac{(n-5)!(n-5)!8!9!(n-8)!(n-9)!}{n!n!(n-8)!(n-9)!3!4!} = 1</cmath>

<cmath>T^2 =  LaTex big((n)(n-1)(n-2)(n-3)(n-4) LaTex big)^2  LaTex frac{3!4!}{8!9!}</cmath>

<cmath>T^2 =  LaTex big((n)(n-1)(n-2)(n-3)(n-4) LaTex big)^2  LaTex frac{144}{7!7!8 LaTex cdot8 LaTex cdot9}</cmath>

<cmath>T^2 =  LaTex big((n)(n-1)(n-2)(n-3)(n-4) LaTex big)^2  LaTex frac{1}{4 LaTex cdot7!7!}</cmath>

<cmath>T =  LaTex frac{(n)(n-1)(n-2)(n-3)(n-4)}{2^5 LaTex cdot3^2 LaTex cdot5 LaTex cdot7}</cmath>

Note that this is always less than <math>{n LaTex choose 5}</math>, so as long as <math>T</math> is integral, <math>n</math> is a possibility. Thus, we have that this is equivalent to 

<cmath>2^5 LaTex cdot3^2 LaTex cdot5 LaTex cdot7 LaTex big|(n)(n-1)(n-2)(n-3)(n-4).</cmath>

It is obvious that <math>5</math> divides the RHS, and that <math>7</math> does iff <math>n LaTex equiv 0,1,2,3,4 LaTex mod 7</math>. Also, <math>3^2</math> divides it iff <math>n LaTex not LaTex equiv 5,8 LaTex mod 9</math>. One can also bash out that <math>2^5</math> divides it in <math>16</math> out of the <math>32</math> possible residues <math> LaTex mod 32</math>. 

Note that <math>2016 = 7*9*32</math> so by using all numbers from <math>2</math> to <math>2017</math>, inclusive, it is clear that each possible residue <math> LaTex mod 7,9,32</math> is reached an equal number of times, so the total number of working <math>n</math> in that range is <math>5 LaTex cdot 7 LaTex cdot 16 = 560</math>. However, we must subtract the number of "working" <math>2 LaTex leq n LaTex leq 8</math>, which is <math>3</math>. Thus, the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D) } 557}</math>.

Alternatively, it is enough to approximate by finding the floor of <math>2017  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac57  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac79  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac12 - 3</math> to get <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D) } 557}</math>.

prompt: Let <math>N</math> be a positive multiple of <math>5</math>. One red ball and <math>N</math> green balls are arranged in a line in random order. Let <math>P(N)</math> be the probability that at least <math> LaTex tfrac{3}{5}</math> of the green balls are on the same side of the red ball. Observe that <math>P(5)=1</math> and that <math>P(N)</math> approaches <math> LaTex tfrac{4}{5}</math> as <math>N</math> grows large. What is the sum of the digits of the least value of <math>N</math> such that <math>P(N) <  LaTex tfrac{321}{400}</math>?
completion:
Let <math>n =  LaTex frac{N}{5}</math>. Then, consider <math>5</math> blocks of <math>n</math> green balls in a line, along with the red ball. Shuffling the line is equivalent to choosing one of the <math>N + 1</math> positions between the green balls to insert the red ball. Less than <math> LaTex frac{3}{5}</math> of the green balls will be on the same side of the red ball if the red ball is inserted inside the middle block of <math>n</math> balls, and there are <math>n - 1</math> positions where this happens. Thus, <math>P(N) = 1 -  LaTex frac{n - 1}{N + 1} =  LaTex frac{4n + 2}{5n + 1}</math>, so

<cmath>P(N) =  LaTex frac{4n + 2}{5n + 1} <  LaTex frac{321}{400}.</cmath>

Multiplying both sides of the inequality by <math>400(5n+1)</math>, we have

<cmath>400(4n+2)<321(5n+1),</cmath>

and by the distributive property,

<cmath>1600n+800<1605n+321.</cmath>

Subtracting <math>1600n+321</math> on both sides of the inequality gives us

<cmath>479<5n.</cmath>

Therefore, <math>N=5n>479</math>, so the least possible value of <math>N</math> is <math>480</math>. The sum of the digits of <math>480</math> is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A) } 12}</math>.

prompt: Each vertex of a cube is to be labeled with an integer from <math>1</math> through <math>8</math>, with each integer being used once, in such a way that the sum of the four numbers on the vertices of a face is the same for each face.  Arrangements that can be obtained from each other through rotations of the cube are considered to be the same.  How many different arrangements are possible?
completion:
Note that the sum of the numbers on each face must be 18, because <math> LaTex frac{1+2+ LaTex cdots+8}{2}=18</math>. 

So now consider the opposite edges (two edges which are parallel but not on same face of the cube);
they must have the same sum value too.
Now think about the points <math>1</math> and <math>8</math>. If they are not on the same edge, they must be endpoints of opposite edges, and we should have <math>1+X=8+Y</math>. However, this scenario would yield no solution for <math>[7,2]</math>, which is a contradiction. (Try drawing out the cube if it doesn't make sense to you.)

The points <math>1</math> and <math>8</math> are therefore on the same side and all edges parallel must also sum to <math>9</math>.

Now we have <math>4</math> parallel sides <math>1-8, 2-7, 3-6, 4-5</math>.
Thinking about <math>4</math> endpoints, we realize they need to sum to <math>18</math>.
It is easy to notice only <math>1-7-6-4</math> and <math>8-2-3-5</math> would work.

So if we fix one direction <math>1-8 (</math>or <math>8-1)</math> all other <math>3</math> parallel sides must lay in one particular direction. <math>(1-8,7-2,6-3,4-5)</math> or <math>(8-1,2-7,3-6,5-4)</math>

Now, the problem is the same as arranging <math>4</math> points in a two-dimensional square, which is <math> LaTex frac{4!}{4}= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(C) }6.}</math>

Notice that we can find <math>[P'PQRR']</math> in two different ways: <math>[P'PQQ']+[Q'QRR']</math> and <math>[PQR]+[P'PRR'].</math> Since we want <math>[PQR],</math> we use the latter method, so we have <math>[P'PQQ']+[Q'QRR']=[PQR]+[P'PRR'].</math>

<math>P'Q'= LaTex sqrt{PQ^2-(QQ'-PP')^2}= LaTex sqrt{3^2-1^2}= LaTex sqrt{8}=2 LaTex sqrt{2}</math>. Additionally, <math>Q'R'= LaTex sqrt{QR^2-(RR'-QQ')^2}= LaTex sqrt{5^2-1^2}= LaTex sqrt{24}=2 LaTex sqrt{6}</math>. Therefore, <math>[P'PQQ']= LaTex frac{P'P+Q'Q}{2}*2 LaTex sqrt{2}= LaTex frac{1+2}{2}*2 LaTex sqrt{2}=3 LaTex sqrt{2}</math>. Similarly, <math>[Q'QRR']=5 LaTex sqrt6</math>. We can calculate <math>[P'PRR']</math> easily because <math>P'R'=P'Q'+Q'R'=2 LaTex sqrt{2}+2 LaTex sqrt{6}</math>. <math>[P'PRR']=4 LaTex sqrt{2}+4 LaTex sqrt{6}</math>. <math> LaTex newline</math>

Plugging into first equation, the two sums of areas, <math>3 LaTex sqrt{2}+5 LaTex sqrt{6}=4 LaTex sqrt{2}+4 LaTex sqrt{6}+[PQR],</math> so therefore <math>[PQR]= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D) } LaTex sqrt{6}- LaTex sqrt{2}.}</math>

prompt: Let <math>ABCD</math> be a square. Since <math>EG</math> is the diagonal of square <math>EFGH</math>, <math> LaTex frac{[EFGH]}{ABCD} =  LaTex frac{ LaTex frac{EG^2}{2}}{1^2} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B) } LaTex frac{2 +  LaTex sqrt{3}}{3}}</math>

To achieve the desired <math>110</math> factors, we need the number of factors to also be divisible by <math>5</math>, so we can set <math>n=2^3  LaTex cdot 5</math>, so <math>2^{10}  LaTex cdot 5^4  LaTex cdot 11</math> has <math>110</math> factors.  Therefore, <math>n=2^3  LaTex cdot 5</math>.  In order to find the number of factors of <math>81n^4</math>, we raise this to the fourth power and multiply it by <math>81</math>, and find the factors of that number.  We have <math>3^4  LaTex cdot 2^{12}  LaTex cdot 5^4</math>, and this has <math>5  LaTex cdot 13  LaTex cdot 5= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D) }325}</math> factors.

For <math>6</math> to <math>8</math> heads, we are guaranteed to hit <math>4</math> heads, so the sum here is <math> LaTex binom{8}{2}+ LaTex binom{8}{1}+ LaTex binom{8}{0}=28+8+1=37</math>.

For <math>4</math> heads, you have to hit the <math>4</math> heads at the start so there's only one way, <math>1</math>.

For <math>5</math> heads, we either start off with <math>4</math> heads, which gives us <math>_4 LaTex text{C}_1=4</math> ways to arrange the other flips, or we start off with five heads and one tail, which has <math>6</math> ways minus the <math>2</math> overlapping cases, <math> LaTex text{HHHHHTTT}</math> and <math> LaTex text{HHHHTHTT}</math>. Total ways: <math>8</math>.

Then we sum to get <math>46</math>. There are a total of <math>2^8=256</math> possible sequences of <math>8</math> coin flips, so the probability is <math> LaTex frac{46}{256}= LaTex frac{23}{128}</math>. Summing, we get <math>23+128= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B) }151}</math>.

completion:
<asy>

</asy>

Let <math>AD</math> intersect <math>OB</math> at <math>E</math> and <math>OC</math> at <math>F.</math>


<math> LaTex overarc{AB}=  LaTex overarc{BC}=  LaTex overarc{CD}= LaTex theta</math>

<math> LaTex angle{BAD}= LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex cdot  LaTex overarc{BCD}= LaTex theta= LaTex angle{AOB}</math>


From there, <math> LaTex triangle{OAB}  LaTex sim  LaTex triangle{ABE}</math>, thus:

<math>OA = OB</math> because they are both radii of <math> LaTex odot{O}</math>. Since <math> LaTex frac{OA}{AB} =  LaTex frac{OB}{AE}</math>, we have that <math>AB = AE</math>. Similarly, <math>CD = DF</math>.

<math>OE = 100 LaTex sqrt{2} =  LaTex frac{OB}{2}</math> and <math>EF= LaTex frac{BC}{2}=100</math> , so <math>AD=AE + EF + FD = 200 + 100 + 200 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(E) } 500}</math>

completion: We prime factorize <math>72,600,</math> and <math>900</math>. The prime factorizations are <math>2^3 LaTex times 3^2</math>, <math>2^3 LaTex times 3 LaTex times 5^2</math> and <math>2^2 LaTex times 3^2 LaTex times 5^2</math>, respectively. Let <math>x=2^a LaTex times 3^b LaTex times 5^c</math>, <math>y=2^d LaTex times 3^e LaTex times 5^f</math> and <math>z=2^g LaTex times 3^h LaTex times 5^i</math>. We know that <cmath> LaTex max(a,d)=3</cmath> <cmath> LaTex max(b,e)=2</cmath> <cmath> LaTex max(a,g)=3</cmath> <cmath> LaTex max(b,h)=1</cmath> <cmath> LaTex max(c,i)=2</cmath> <cmath> LaTex max(d,g)=2</cmath> <cmath> LaTex max(e,h)=2</cmath> and <math>c=f=0</math> since <math> LaTex text{lcm}(x,y)</math> isn't a multiple of 5. Since <math> LaTex max(d,g)=2</math> we know that <math>a=3</math>. We also know that since <math> LaTex max(b,h)=1</math> that <math>e=2</math>. So now some equations have become useless to us...let's take them out. <cmath> LaTex max(b,h)=1</cmath> <cmath> LaTex max(d,g)=2</cmath> are the only two important ones left. We do casework on each now. If <math> LaTex max(b,h)=1</math> then <math>(b,h)=(1,0),(0,1)</math> or <math>(1,1)</math>. Similarly if <math> LaTex max(d,g)=2</math> then <math>(d,g)=(2,0),(2,1),(2,2),(1,2),(0,2)</math>. Thus our answer is <math>5 LaTex times 3= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A) }15}.</math>

prompt: There is a smallest positive real number <math>a</math> such that there exists a positive real number <math>b</math> such that all the roots of the polynomial <math>x^3-ax^2+bx-a</math> are real. In fact, for this value of <math>a</math> the value of <math>b</math> is unique. What is the value of <math>b?</math>
completion:
The acceleration must be zero at the <math>x</math>-intercept; this intercept must be an inflection point for the minimum <math>a</math> value.
Derive <math>f(x)</math> so that the acceleration <math>f''(x)=0</math>. Using the power rule,
<cmath> LaTex begin{align*}
f(x) &= x^3-ax^2+bx-a  LaTex  LaTex 
f’(x) &= 3x^2-2ax+b  LaTex  LaTex  
f’’(x) &= 6x-2a
 LaTex end{align*}</cmath>
So <math>x= LaTex frac{a}{3}</math> for the inflection point/root. Furthermore, the slope of the function must be zero - maximum - at the intercept, thus having a triple root at <math>x=a/3</math> (if the slope is greater than zero, there will be two complex roots and we do not want that).

The function with the minimum <math>a</math>:

<cmath>f(x)= LaTex left(x- LaTex frac{a}{3} LaTex right)^3</cmath>
<cmath>x^3-ax^2+ LaTex left( LaTex frac{a^2}{3} LaTex right)x- LaTex frac{a^3}{27}</cmath>
Since this is equal to the original equation <math>x^3-ax^2+bx-a</math>, equating the coefficients, we get that

<cmath> LaTex frac{a^3}{27}=a LaTex rightarrow a^2=27 LaTex rightarrow a=3 LaTex sqrt{3}</cmath>
<cmath>b= LaTex frac{a^2}{3}= LaTex frac{27}{3}= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B) }9}</cmath>

The actual function:
<math>f(x)=x^3- LaTex left(3 LaTex sqrt{3} LaTex right)x^2+9x-3 LaTex sqrt{3}</math>

<math>f(x)=0 LaTex rightarrow x= LaTex sqrt{3}</math> triple root. "Complete the cube."

prompt: Let <math>k</math> be a positive integer. Bernardo and Silvia take turns writing and erasing numbers on a blackboard as follows: Bernardo starts by writing the smallest perfect square with <math>k+1</math> digits. Every time Bernardo writes a number, Silvia erases the last <math>k</math> digits of it. Bernardo then writes the next perfect square, Silvia erases the last <math>k</math> digits of it, and this process continues until the last two numbers that remain on the board differ by at least 2. Let <math>f(k)</math> be the smallest positive integer not written on the board. For example, if <math>k = 1</math>, then the numbers that Bernardo writes are <math>16, 25, 36, 49, 64</math>, and the numbers showing on the board after Silvia erases are <math>1, 2, 3, 4,</math> and <math>6</math>, and thus <math>f(1) = 5</math>. What is the sum of the digits of <math>f(2) + f(4)+ f(6) + ... + f(2016)</math>?
completion:
Consider <math>f(2)</math>. The numbers left on the blackboard will show the hundreds place at the end. In order for the hundreds place to differ by 2, the difference between two perfect squares needs to be at least <math>100</math>. Since <math>100 LaTex le (x+1)^2-x^2=2x+1</math>, this first happens at <math>x LaTex ge  LaTex lfloor 99/2 LaTex rfloor = 50</math>. The perfect squares from here go: <math>2500,  2601, 2704, 2809 LaTex dots</math>. Note that the ones and tens also make the perfect squares, <math>1^2,2^2,3^2 LaTex dots</math>. After the ones and tens make <math>100</math>, the hundreds place will go up by <math>2</math>, thus reaching our goal. Since <math>10^2=100</math>, the last perfect square to be written will be <math> LaTex left(50+10 LaTex right)^2=60^2=3600</math>. The missing number is one less than the number of hundreds <math>(k=2)</math> of <math>3600</math>, or <math>35</math>.

Now consider <math>f(4)</math>. Instead of the difference between two squares needing to be <math>100</math>, the difference must now be <math>10000</math>. This first happens at <math>x LaTex ge 5000</math>. After this point, similarly, <math> LaTex sqrt{10000}=100</math> more numbers are needed to make the <math>10^4</math> th's place go up by <math>2</math>. This will take place at <math> LaTex left(5000+100 LaTex right)^2=5100^2= 26010000</math>. Removing the last four digits (the zeros) and subtracting one yields <math>2600</math> for the skipped value.

In general, each new value of <math>f(k+2)</math> will add two digits to the "<math>5</math>" and one digit to the "<math>1</math>". This means that the last number Bernardo writes for <math>k=6</math> is <math> LaTex left(500000+1000 LaTex right)^2</math>, the last for <math>k = 8</math> will be <math> LaTex left(50000000+10000 LaTex right)^2</math>, and so on until <math>k=2016</math>. Removing the last <math>k</math> digits as Silvia does will be the same as removing <math>k/2</math> trailing zeroes on the number to be squared. This means that the last number on the board for <math>k=6</math> is <math>5001^2</math>, <math>k=8</math> is <math>50001^2</math>, and so on. So the first missing number is <math>5001^2-1,50001^2-1 LaTex text{ etc.}</math> The squaring will make a "<math>25</math>" with two more digits than the last number, a "<math>10</math>" with one more digit, and a "<math>1</math>". The missing number is one less than that, so the "1" will be subtracted from <math>f(k)</math>. In other words, <math>f(k) = 25 LaTex cdot 10^{k-2}+1 LaTex cdot 10^{k/2}</math>.

Therefore:

The second term in a geometric series is <math>a_2 = a  LaTex cdot r</math>, where <math>r</math> is the common ratio for the series and <math>a</math> is the first term of the series. So we know that <math>a LaTex cdot r = 1</math> and we wish to find the minimum value of the infinite sum of  the series. We know that: <math>S_ LaTex infty =  LaTex frac{a}{1-r}</math> and substituting in <math>a= LaTex frac{1}{r}</math>, we get that <math>S_ LaTex infty =  LaTex frac{ LaTex frac{1}{r}}{1-r} =  LaTex frac{1}{r(1-r)} =  LaTex frac{1}{r}+ LaTex frac{1}{1-r}</math>. From here, you can either use calculus or AM-GM.

<math> LaTex textbf{Calculus}</math>

Let <math>f(x) =  LaTex frac{1}{x-x^2} = (x-x^2)^{-1}</math>, then <math>f'(x) = -(x-x^2)^{-2} LaTex cdot (1-2x)</math>. Since <math>f(0)</math> and <math>f(1)</math> are undefined <math>x  LaTex neq 0,1</math>. This means that we only need to find where the derivative equals <math>0</math>, meaning <math>1-2x = 0  LaTex Rightarrow x = LaTex frac{1}{2}</math>. So <math> r =  LaTex frac{1}{2}</math>, meaning that <math>S_ LaTex infty =  LaTex frac{1}{ LaTex frac{1}{2} - ( LaTex frac{1}{2})^2} =  LaTex frac{1}{ LaTex frac{1}{2}- LaTex frac{1}{4}} =  LaTex frac{1}{ LaTex frac{1}{4}} = 4</math>

<math> LaTex textbf{AM-GM}</math>

For 2 positive real numbers <math>a</math> and <math>b</math>, <math> LaTex frac{a+b}{2}  LaTex geq  LaTex sqrt{ab}</math>. Let <math>a =  LaTex frac{1}{r}</math> and <math>b =  LaTex frac{1}{1-r}</math>. Then: <math> LaTex frac{ LaTex frac{1}{r}+ LaTex frac{1}{1-r}}{2}  LaTex geq  LaTex sqrt{ LaTex frac{1}{r} LaTex cdot LaTex frac{1}{1-r}}= LaTex sqrt{ LaTex frac{1}{r}+ LaTex frac{1}{1-r}}</math>. This implies that <math> LaTex frac{S_ LaTex infty}{2}  LaTex geq  LaTex sqrt{S_ LaTex infty}</math>. or <math>S_ LaTex infty^2  LaTex geq 4  LaTex cdot S_ LaTex infty</math>. Rearranging : <math>(S_ LaTex infty-2)^2  LaTex geq 4  LaTex Rightarrow S_ LaTex infty - 2  LaTex geq 2  LaTex Rightarrow S_ LaTex infty  LaTex geq 4</math>. Thus, the smallest value is <math>S_ LaTex infty = 4</math>.

We use complementary counting. First, because each team played <math>20</math> other teams, there are <math>21</math> teams total. All sets that do not have <math>A</math> beat <math>B</math>, <math>B</math> beat <math>C</math>, and <math>C</math> beat <math>A</math> have one team that beats both the other teams. Thus we must count the number of sets of three teams such that one team beats the two other teams and subtract that number from the total number of ways to choose three teams.

There are <math>21</math> ways to choose the team that beat the two other teams, and <math> LaTex binom{10}{2} = 45</math> to choose two teams that the first team both beat. This is <math>21 * 45 = 945</math> sets. There are <math> LaTex binom{21}{3} = 1330</math> sets of three teams total. Subtracting, we obtain <math>1330 - 945 =  LaTex boxed{385}</math>, thus <math>( LaTex text{A})</math>  is our answer.

prompt: Eight people are sitting around a circular table, each holding a fair coin. All eight people flip their coins and those who flip heads stand while those who flip tails remain seated. What is the probability that no two adjacent people will stand?

We will count how many valid standing arrangements there are (counting rotations as distinct), and divide by <math>2^8 = 256</math> at the end. We casework on how many people are standing.

Case <math>1:</math> <math>0</math> people are standing. This yields <math>1</math> arrangement.

Case <math>2:</math> <math>1</math> person is standing. This yields <math>8</math> arrangements.

Case <math>3:</math> <math>2</math> people are standing. This yields <math> LaTex dbinom{8}{2} - 8 = 20</math> arrangements, because the two people cannot be next to each other.

Case <math>5:</math> <math>4</math> people are standing. Then the people must be arranged in stand-sit-stand-sit-stand-sit-stand-sit fashion, yielding <math>2</math> possible arrangements.

More difficult is:

Case <math>4:</math> <math>3</math> people are standing. First, choose the location of the first person standing (<math>8</math> choices). Next, choose <math>2</math> of the remaining people in the remaining <math>5</math> legal seats to stand, amounting to <math>6</math> arrangements considering that these two people cannot stand next to each other. However, we have to divide by <math>3,</math> because there are <math>3</math> ways to choose the first person given any three. This yields <math> LaTex dfrac{8  LaTex cdot 6}{3} = 16</math> arrangements for Case <math>5.</math>

Alternate Case <math>4:</math> Use complementary counting. Total number of ways to choose 3 people from 8 which is <math> LaTex dbinom{8}{3}</math>. Sub-case <math>1:</math> three people are next to each other which is <math> LaTex dbinom{8}{1}</math>. Sub-case <math>2:</math> two people are next to each other and the third person is not <math> LaTex dbinom{8}{1}</math> <math> LaTex dbinom{4}{1}</math>. This yields <math> LaTex dbinom{8}{3} -  LaTex dbinom{8}{1} -  LaTex dbinom{8}{1}  LaTex dbinom{4}{1} = 16</math> 

Summing gives <math>1 + 8 + 20 + 2 + 16 = 47,</math> and so our probability is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A) }  LaTex dfrac{47}{256}}</math>.

Alternate: (Quicksolve) - We know that for case 5, there are 8 ways to choose the first person, and 3 ways to choose the first person given any 3 - which means that for the case, there is 8 * something divided by 3. The sum of the other cases is 31/256. Thus, add a multiple of 8 to 31 to get an answer. The options are 31 + 8 = 39, 31 + 16 = 47, 31 + 24 = 55, etc. The only possible answer is 47/256.

prompt: Larry and Julius are playing a game, taking turns throwing a ball at a bottle sitting on a ledge. Larry throws first. The winner is the first person to knock the bottle off the ledge. prompt: How many noncongruent integer-sided triangles with positive area and perimeter less than 15 are neither equilateral, isosceles, nor right triangles?

Since we want non-congruent triangles that are neither isosceles nor equilateral, we can just list side lengths <math>(a,b,c)</math> with <math>a<b<c</math>. Furthermore, "positive area" tells us that <math>c < a + b</math> and the perimeter constraints means <math>a+b+c < 15</math>.

When <math>a=2</math>, similar to above, <math>c</math> must be less than <math>b+2</math>, so this leaves the only possibility <math>c = b+1</math>. This gives 3 triangles <math>(2,3,4), (2,4,5), (2,5,6)</math> within our perimeter constraint.

When <math>a=3</math>, <math>c</math> can be <math>b+1</math> or <math>b+2</math>, which gives triangles <math>(3,4,5), (3,4,6), (3,5,6)</math>. Note that <math>(3,4,5)</math> is a right triangle, so we get rid of it and we get only 2 triangles.

All in all, this gives us <math>3+2 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(C)} LaTex ; 5}</math> triangles.

Then <math> LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex times 13  LaTex times h=30</math>, and so <math>h =  LaTex frac{60}{13}</math>. Therefore the sum of all the heights is <math>5+12+ LaTex frac{60}{13}= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(E)} LaTex ;  LaTex frac{281}{13}}</math>.

Therefore the answer is <math>9 +  LaTex tfrac{7+8}{2} = 9 + 7.5 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D)} LaTex ; 16.5}.</math>

prompt: At Rachelle's school an A counts 4 points, a B 3 points, a C 2 points, and a D 1 point. Her GPA on the four classes she is taking is computed as the total sum of points divided by 4. She is certain that she will get As in both Mathematics and Science, and at least a C in each of English and History. She thinks she has a <math> LaTex tfrac{1}{6}</math> chance of getting an A in English, and a <math> LaTex tfrac{1}{4}</math> chance of getting a B. In History, she has a <math> LaTex tfrac{1}{4}</math> chance of getting an A, and a <math> LaTex tfrac{1}{3}</math> chance of getting a B, independently of what she gets in English. What is the probability that Rachelle will get a GPA of at least 3.5?
completion:
The probability that Rachelle gets a C in English is <math>1- LaTex frac{1}{6}- LaTex frac{1}{4} =  LaTex frac{7}{12}</math>.

The probability that she gets a C in History is <math>1- LaTex frac{1}{4}- LaTex frac{1}{3} =  LaTex frac{5}{12}</math>.

We see that the sum of Rachelle's "point" scores must be at least 14 since <math>4*3.5 = 14</math>. We know that in Mathematics and Science we have a total point score of 8 (since she will get As in both), so we only need a sum of 6 in English and History. This can be achieved by getting two As, one A and one B, one A and one C, or two Bs. We evaluate these cases.

The probability that she gets two As is <math> LaTex frac{1}{6} LaTex cdot LaTex frac{1}{4} =  LaTex frac{1}{24}</math>.

The probability that she gets one A and one B is <math> LaTex frac{1}{6} LaTex cdot LaTex frac{1}{3} +  LaTex frac{1}{4} LaTex cdot LaTex frac{1}{4} =  LaTex frac{1}{18}+ LaTex frac{1}{16} =   LaTex frac{8}{144}+ LaTex frac{9}{144} =  LaTex frac{17}{144}</math>.

The probability that she gets one A and one C is <math> LaTex frac{1}{6} LaTex cdot LaTex frac{5}{12} +  LaTex frac{1}{4} LaTex cdot LaTex frac{7}{12} =  LaTex frac{5}{72}+ LaTex frac{7}{48} =   LaTex frac{31}{144}</math>.

The probability that she gets two Bs is <math> LaTex frac{1}{4} LaTex cdot LaTex frac{1}{3} =  LaTex frac{1}{12}</math>.

Adding these, we get <math> LaTex frac{1}{24} +  LaTex frac{17}{144} +   LaTex frac{31}{144} +  LaTex frac{1}{12} =  LaTex frac{66}{144} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathbf{(D)} LaTex ;   LaTex frac{11}{24}}</math>.

prompt: A regular hexagon with sides of length 6 has an isosceles triangle attached to each side. Each of these triangles has two sides of length 8. The isosceles triangles are folded to make a pyramid with the hexagon as the base of the pyramid. What is the volume of the pyramid?
completion:
The distance from a corner to the center is 6, and from the corner to the top of the pyramid is 8, so the height is <math> LaTex sqrt{8^2 - 6^2} =  LaTex sqrt{64 - 36} =  LaTex sqrt{28} = 2 LaTex sqrt{7}</math>.

Thus, the volume of the pyramid is 

<cmath> LaTex frac{1}{3}  LaTex times  LaTex text{base}  LaTex times  LaTex text{height} =  LaTex frac{ 54 LaTex sqrt{3}  LaTex cdot 2 LaTex sqrt{7}}{3} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(C)} LaTex ; 36 LaTex sqrt{21}}</cmath>.

prompt: An unfair coin lands on heads with a probability of <math> LaTex tfrac{1}{4}</math>. When tossed <math>n</math> times, the probability of exactly two heads is the same as the probability of exactly three heads. What is the value of <math>n</math> ?

When tossed <math>n</math> times, the probability of getting exactly 2 heads and the rest tails is

<cmath> LaTex dbinom{n}{2} { LaTex left(  LaTex frac{1}{4}  LaTex right)}^2 { LaTex left(  LaTex frac{3}{4}  LaTex right) }^{n-2}.</cmath>

<cmath> LaTex dbinom{n}{3}{ LaTex left(  LaTex frac{1}{4}  LaTex right)}^3 { LaTex left(  LaTex frac{3}{4}  LaTex right) }^{n-3}.</cmath>

Now set the two probabilities equal to each other and solve for <math>n</math>:

<cmath> LaTex dbinom{n}{2}{ LaTex left(  LaTex frac{1}{4}  LaTex right)}^2 { LaTex left(  LaTex frac{3}{4}  LaTex right) }^{n-2}= LaTex dbinom{n}{3}{ LaTex left(  LaTex frac{1}{4}  LaTex right)}^3 { LaTex left(  LaTex frac{3}{4}  LaTex right) }^{n-3}</cmath>

<cmath> LaTex frac{n(n-1)}{2!}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{3}{4} =  LaTex frac{n(n-1)(n-2)}{3!}   LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{1}{4}</cmath>

<cmath>3 =  LaTex frac{n-2}{3}</cmath>

<cmath>n-2 = 9</cmath>

<cmath>n =  LaTex fbox{ LaTex textbf{(D)} LaTex ; 11}</cmath>


Note: the original problem did not specify <math>n>1</math>, so <math>n=1</math> was a solution, but this was fixed in the Wiki problem text so that the answer would make sense. [[User:Adihaya|— @adihaya]] ([[User talk:Adihaya|talk]]) 15:23, 19 February 2016 (EST)

completion:
<asy>

First, we should find the center and radius of this circle. We can find the center by drawing the perpendicular bisectors of <math>WZ</math> and <math>XY</math> and finding their intersection point. This point happens to be the midpoint of <math>AB</math>, the hypotenuse. Let this point be <math>M</math>. To find the radius, determine <math>MY</math>, where <math>MY^{2} = MA^2 + AY^2</math>, <math>MA =  LaTex frac{12}{2} = 6</math>, and <math>AY = AB = 12</math>. Thus, the radius <math>=r =MY = 6 LaTex sqrt5</math>.

Next we let <math>AC = b</math> and <math>BC = a</math>. Consider the right triangle <math>ACB</math> first. Using the Pythagorean theorem, we find that <math>a^2 + b^2 = 12^2 = 144</math>. 
<asy>
pair A,B,C,M,E,W,Z,X,Y;
A=(2,0);
B=(0,2);
C=(0,0);
M=(A+B)/2;
W=(-2,2);

Now, we let <math>E</math> be the midpoint of <math>WZ</math>, and we consider right triangle <math>ZEM</math>. By the Pythagorean theorem, we have that <math> LaTex left( LaTex frac{a}{2} LaTex right)^2 +  LaTex left(a +  LaTex frac{b}{2} LaTex right)^2 = r^2 = 180</math>. Expanding this equation, we get that

<cmath> LaTex frac{1}{4}(a^2+b^2) + a^2 + ab = 180</cmath>
<cmath> LaTex frac{144}{4} + a^2 + ab = 180</cmath>
<cmath>a^2 + ab = 144 = a^2 + b^2</cmath>
<cmath>ab = b^2</cmath>
<cmath>b = a</cmath>

This means that <math>ABC</math> is a 45-45-90 triangle, so <math>a = b =  LaTex frac{12}{ LaTex sqrt2} = 6 LaTex sqrt2</math>. Thus the perimeter is <math>a + b + AB = 12 LaTex sqrt2 + 12</math> which is answer <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(C)} LaTex ; 12 + 12 LaTex sqrt2}</math>.

prompt:

Define a function <math>f:  LaTex {0,1,2,3, LaTex dots LaTex }  LaTex times  LaTex {0,1,2,3,4 LaTex }  LaTex to  LaTex {0,1,2,3,4 LaTex }</math> recursively as follows:

 LaTex end{cases}</cmath>  

What is <math>f(2015,2)</math>?
completion:
Simply take some time to draw a table of values of <math>f(i,j)</math> for the first few values of <math>i</math>:

<cmath> LaTex begin{array}{|c || c | c | c | c | c |}
 LaTex hline
i  LaTex text{ LaTex   LaTex textbackslash LaTex  } j & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 LaTex  LaTex   LaTex hline LaTex hline
0 & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 0 LaTex  LaTex   LaTex hline

4 & 3 & 1 & 3 & 1 & 3 LaTex  LaTex   LaTex hline

 LaTex end{array}</cmath>

Now we claim that for <math>i  LaTex ge 5</math>, <math>f(i,j) = 1</math> for all values <math>0  LaTex le j  LaTex le 4</math>.  We will prove this by induction on <math>i</math> and <math>j</math>.  The base cases for <math>i = 5</math>, have already been proven.

For our inductive step, we must show that for all valid values of <math>j</math>, <math>f(i, j) = 1</math> if for all valid values of <math>j</math>, <math>f(i - 1, j) = 1</math>.

We prove this itself by induction on <math>j</math>.  For the base case, <math>j=0</math>, <math>f(i, 0) = f(i-1, 1) = 1</math>.  For the inductive step, we need <math>f(i, j) = 1</math> if <math>f(i, j-1) = 1</math>.  Then, <math>f(i, j) = f(i-1, f(i, j-1)).</math>  <math>f(i, j-1) = 1</math> by our inductive hypothesis from our inner induction and <math>f(i-1, 1) = 1</math> from our outer inductive hypothesis.  Thus, <math>f(i, j) = 1</math>, completing the proof.

It is now clear that for <math>i  LaTex ge 5</math>, <math>f(i,j) = 1</math> for all values <math>0  LaTex le j  LaTex le 4</math>.

Thus, <math>f(2015,2) =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B)}  LaTex ; 1}</math>.

prompt: Cozy the Cat and Dash the Dog are going up a staircase with a certain number of steps. However, instead of walking up the steps one at a time, both Cozy and Dash jump. We can translate this wordy problem into this simple equation: LaTex left LaTex lceil LaTex frac{s}{2} LaTex right LaTex rceil - 19 = LaTex left LaTex lceil LaTex frac{s}{5} LaTex right LaTex rceil We will proceed to solve this equation via casework. Case 1: LaTex left LaTex lceil LaTex frac{s}{2} LaTex right LaTex rceil = LaTex frac{s}{2} Our equation becomes LaTex frac{s}{2} - 19 = LaTex frac{s}{5} + LaTex frac{j}{5}, where j LaTex in LaTex {0,1,2,3,4 LaTex } Using the fact that s is an integer, we quickly find that j=1 and j=4 yield s=64 and s=66, respectively.
Case 2: LaTex left LaTex lceil LaTex frac{s}{2} LaTex right LaTex rceil = LaTex frac{s}{2}+ LaTex frac{1}{2} Our equation becomes LaTex frac{s}{2} + LaTex frac{1}{2} - 19 = LaTex frac{s}{5} + LaTex frac{j}{5}, where j LaTex in LaTex {0,1,2,3,4 LaTex } Using the fact that s is an integer, we quickly find that j=2 yields s=63. Summing up we get 63+64+66=193. The sum of the digits is LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D)} LaTex ; 13}.

prompt: Six chairs are evenly spaced around a circular table. One person is seated in each chair. Each person gets up and sits down in a chair that is not the same chair and is not adjacent to the chair he or she originally occupied, so that again one person is seated in each chair. In how many ways can this be done?
completion:
Consider shifting every person over three seats left after each person has gotten up and sat back down again. Now, instead of each person being seated not in the same chair and not in an adjacent chair, each person will be seated either in the same chair or an adjacent chair. The problem now becomes the number of ways in which six people can sit down in a chair that is either the same chair or an adjacent chair in a circle.

Consider the similar problem of <math>n</math> people sitting in a chair that is either the same chair or an adjacent chair in a row. Call the number of possibilities for this <math>F_n</math>. Then if the leftmost person stays put, the problem is reduced to a row of <math>n-1</math> chairs, and if the leftmost person shifts one seat to the right, the new person sitting in the leftmost seat must be the person originally second from the left, reducing the problem to a row of <math>n-2</math> chairs. Thus, <math>F_n = F_{n-1} + F_{n-2}</math> for <math>n  LaTex geq 3</math>. Clearly <math>F_1 = 1</math> and <math>F_2 = 2</math>, so <math>F_3 = 3</math>, <math>F_4 = 5</math>, and <math>F_5 = 8</math>.

Now consider the six people in a circle and focus on one person. If that person stays put, the problem is reduced to a row of five chairs, for which there are <math>F_5 = 8</math> possibilities. If that person moves one seat to the left, then the person who replaces him in his original seat will either be the person originally to the right of him, which will force everyone to simply shift over one seat to the left, or the person originally to the left of him, which reduces the problem to a row of four chairs, for which there are <math>F_4 = 5</math> possibilities, giving <math>1 + 5 = 6</math> possibilities in all. By symmetry, if that person moves one seat to the right, there are another <math>6</math> possibilities, so we have a total of <math>8+6+6 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D)} LaTex ; 20}</math> possibilities.

prompt: A rectangular box measures <math>a  LaTex times b  LaTex times c</math>, where <math>a</math>, <math>b</math>, and <math>c</math> are integers and <math>1 LaTex leq a  LaTex leq b  LaTex leq c</math>. prompt: Paula the painter and her two helpers each paint at constant, but different, rates.  They always start at <math> LaTex text{8:00 AM}</math>, and all three always take the same amount of time to eat lunch.  On Monday the three of them painted <math>50 LaTex %</math> of a house, quitting at <math> LaTex text{4:00 PM}</math>.  On Tuesday, when Paula wasn't there, the two helpers painted only <math>24 LaTex %</math> of the house and quit at <math> LaTex text{2:12 PM}</math>.  On Wednesday Paula worked by herself and finished the house by working until <math> LaTex text{7:12 PM}</math>.  How long, in minutes, was each day's lunch break?
completion:
Let Paula work at a rate of <math>p</math>, the two helpers work at a combined rate of <math>h</math>, and the time it takes to eat lunch be <math>L</math>, where <math>p</math> and <math>h</math> are in house/hours and L is in hours. Then the labor on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday can be represented by the three following equations:

<cmath>(8-L)(p+h)=50</cmath>

<cmath>(6.2-L)h=24</cmath>

<cmath>(11.2-L)p=26</cmath>

With three equations and three variables, we need to find the value of <math>L</math>.
Adding the second and third equations together gives us <math>6.2h+11.2p-L(p+h)=50</math>. Subtracting the first equation from this new one gives us <math>-1.8h+3.2p=0</math>, so we get <math>h= LaTex frac{16}{9}p</math>. 
Plugging into the second equation:

<cmath>(6.2-L) LaTex frac{16}{9}p=24</cmath>
<cmath>(6.2-L)p= LaTex frac{27}{2}</cmath>

We can then subtract this from the third equation:

<cmath>5p=26- LaTex frac{27}{2}</cmath>
<cmath>p= LaTex frac{5}{2}</cmath>
Plugging <math>p</math> into our third equation gives: <cmath>L= LaTex frac{4}{5}</cmath>

Converting <math>L</math> from hours to minutes gives us <math>L=48</math> minutes, which is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D)} LaTex  48}</math>.

Then add the areas of the three sectors outside the hexagon (<math>2 LaTex pi</math>) and subtract the areas of the three sectors inside the hexagon but outside the figure(<math> LaTex pi</math>) to get the area enclosed in the curved figure <math>( LaTex pi+6 LaTex sqrt{3})</math>, which is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(E)} LaTex   LaTex pi+6 LaTex sqrt{3}}</math>.

prompt: A <math>3 LaTex times3</math> square is partitioned into <math>9</math> unit squares.  Each unit square is painted either white or black with each color being equally likely, chosen independently and at random.  The square is then rotated <math>90^ LaTex circ</math> clockwise about its center, and every white square in a position formerly occupied by a black square is painted black.  The colors of all other squares are left unchanged.  What is the probability that the grid is now entirely black?
completion:
First, look for invariants. The center, unaffected by rotation, must be black. So automatically, the chance is less than <math> LaTex frac{1}{2}.</math> Note that a <math>90^{ LaTex circ}</math> rotation requires that black squares be across from each other across a vertical or horizontal axis. 


As such, <math>2</math> squares directly across from each other must be black in the <math>4</math> edge squares. Since there are <math>2</math> configurations for this to be possible (top and bottom, right and left), this is a chance of
<cmath>  LaTex left ( LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex right )+  LaTex left ( LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex right )= LaTex frac{1}{2}</cmath> 


However, by [[PIE]], subtract the chance all 4 are black and both configurations are met: <math> LaTex frac{1}{2}-  LaTex left ( LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex right )  LaTex cdot  LaTex left ( LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex right )= LaTex frac{7}{16}</math>. Through symmetrical reasoning, the corners also have a <math> LaTex frac{7}{16}</math> chance of having a configuration that yields all black corners. 

Then, the chance that all squares black is the intersection of all these probabilities: <math> LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex left ( LaTex frac{7}{16}  LaTex right )  LaTex left ( LaTex frac{7}{16}  LaTex right ) =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A)} LaTex   LaTex frac{49}{512}}</math> 



~BJHHar

Also, if you have little to no time and are guessing, notice there are a total of <math>2^9 = 512</math> ways to permutate the colors on the square (Each square can be white or black, so there are 2 possibilities for each of the 9 squares). Thus, the answer must be in some form of <math> LaTex frac{ LaTex text{the number of good cases}}{ LaTex text{the total number of cases}}</math>, so E is not possible. From there, your chances of guessing the right answer are slightly higher. ~Extremelysupercooldude

prompt: Circle <math>C_1</math> has its center <math>O</math> lying on circle <math>C_2</math>.  The two circles meet at <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math>.  Point <math>Z</math> in the exterior of <math>C_1</math> lies on circle <math>C_2</math> and <math>XZ=13</math>, <math>OZ=11</math>, and <math>YZ=7</math>.  What is the radius of circle <math>C_1</math>?
completion: Let <math>r</math> denote the radius of circle <math>C_1</math>. Note that quadrilateral <math>ZYOX</math> is cyclic. By Ptolemy's Theorem, we have <math>11XY=13r+7r</math> and <math>XY=20r/11</math>. Let <math>t</math> be the measure of angle <math>YOX</math>. Since <math>YO=OX=r</math>, the law of cosines on triangle <math>YOX</math> gives us <math> LaTex cos t =-79/121</math>. Again since <math>ZYOX</math> is cyclic, the measure of angle <math>YZX=180-t</math>. We apply the law of cosines to triangle <math>ZYX</math> so that <math>XY^2=7^2+13^2-2(7)(13) LaTex cos(180-t)</math>. Since <math> LaTex cos(180-t)=- LaTex cos t=79/121</math> we obtain <math>XY^2=12000/121</math>. But<math> XY^2=400r^2/121</math> so that <math>r= LaTex boxed{(E) LaTex sqrt{30}}</math>.

prompt: Let <math>S</math> be a subset of <math> LaTex {1,2,3, LaTex dots,30 LaTex }</math> with the property that no pair of distinct elements in <math>S</math> has a sum divisible by <math>5</math>.  What is the largest possible size of <math>S</math>?
completion:
Of the integers from <math>1</math> to <math>30</math>, there are six each of <math>0,1,2,3,4 LaTex  ( LaTex text{mod} LaTex  5)</math>. We can create several rules to follow for the elements in subset <math>S</math>. No element can be <math>1 LaTex  ( LaTex text{mod} LaTex  5)</math> if there is an element that is <math>4 LaTex  ( LaTex text{mod} LaTex  5)</math>. No element can be <math>2 LaTex  ( LaTex text{mod} LaTex  5)</math> if there is an element that is <math>3 LaTex  ( LaTex text{mod} LaTex  5)</math>. Thus we can pick 6 elements from either <math>1 LaTex  ( LaTex text{mod} LaTex  5)</math> or <math>4 LaTex  ( LaTex text{mod} LaTex  5)</math> and 6 elements from either <math>2 LaTex  ( LaTex text{mod} LaTex  5)</math> or <math>3 LaTex  ( LaTex text{mod} LaTex  5)</math> for a total of <math>6+6=12</math> elements. Considering <math>0 LaTex  ( LaTex text{mod} LaTex  5)</math>, there can be one element that is so because it will only be divisible by <math>5</math> if paired with another element that is <math>0 LaTex  ( LaTex text{mod} LaTex  5)</math>. The final answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B)} LaTex  13}</math>.





== Solution 2 == ( Similar to solution 1 but more detailed) 
Since we are taking the sum of distinct numbers mod(5), the only values that can be the remainder is <math>0</math>,<math>1</math>,<math>2</math>,<math>3</math>,<math>4</math>. We dismiss the case of remainder <math>0</math> because this would make the sum a multiple of 5, which is not allowed. In addition, since we can't have 0 or 5 mod(5), we make some restraints. There are four different cases for the "allowed" mods in the sequence, or the remainders that the sum of distinct elements are allowed to be in the sequence. They are:

1)      1mod(5), and 3mod(5)


2)      1mod(5), and 2mod(5)


3)      2mod(5), and 4mod(5), 


4)      2mod(5), and 1mod(5) 

Now, we can calculate the number of elements in each of these cases. For the first case, we rewrite 1mod(5) in the form 5k+1. Because 5k+1 < 30, which is the largest element in the sequence possible, we obtain k=5. In addition, for 3mod(5), we have 3x+5<30, x=5. This gives us 5+5=10 solutions. The reason why we can add these elements is because all of these elements, no matter which two you add, can never be a multiple of 5. The only possible remainders for the sum are 1+1, 1+3, or 3+3. 

In a similar manner, we calculate the element using the same logic. We find that 2mod(5) has 5 elements, and 1mod(5) has 8 elements, meaning that there are a total of 13 elements, which is the answer. 
~CharmaineMa07292010

prompt: Triangle <math>ABC</math> has <math>AB=27</math>, <math>BC=25</math>, and <math>CA=26</math>.  Let <math>I</math> denote the intersection of the internal angle bisectors of <math> LaTex triangle ABC</math>.  What is <math>BI</math>?
completion:
Inscribe circle <math>C</math> of radius <math>r</math> inside triangle <math>ABC</math> so that it meets <math>AB</math> at <math>Q</math>, <math>BC</math> at <math>R</math>, and <math>AC</math> at <math>S</math>. Note that angle bisectors of triangle <math>ABC</math> are concurrent at the center <math>O</math>(also <math>I</math>) of circle <math>C</math>. Let <math>x=QB</math>, <math>y=RC</math> and <math>z=AS</math>. Note that <math>BR=x</math>, <math>SC=y</math> and <math>AQ=z</math>. Hence <math>x+z=27</math>, <math>x+y=25</math>, and <math>z+y=26</math>. Subtracting the last 2 equations we have <math>x-z=-1</math> and adding this to the first equation we have <math>x=13</math>. 

By Heron's formula for the area of a triangle we have that the area of triangle <math>ABC</math> is <math> LaTex sqrt{39(14)(13)(12)}</math>. On the other hand the area is given by <math>(1/2)25r+(1/2)26r+(1/2)27r</math>.  Then <math>39r= LaTex sqrt{39(14)(13)(12)}</math> so that <math>r^2=56</math>.

Since the radius of circle <math>O</math> is perpendicular to <math>BC</math> at <math>R</math>, we have by the pythagorean theorem <math>BO^2=BI^2=r^2+x^2=56+169=225</math> so that <math>BI= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A) } 15}</math>.

prompt: Adam, Benin, Chiang, Deshawn, Esther, and Fiona have internet accounts.  Some, but not all, of them are internet friends with each other, and none of them has an internet friend outside this group.  Each of them has the same number of internet friends.  In how many different ways can this happen?
completion:
Note that if <math>n</math> is the number of friends each person has, then <math>n</math> can be any integer from <math>1</math> to <math>4</math>, inclusive.

One person can have at most 4 friends since they cannot be all friends (stated in the problem).

Also note that the cases of <math>n=1</math> and <math>n=4</math> are the same, since a map showing a solution for <math>n=1</math> can correspond one-to-one with a map of a solution for <math>n=4</math> by simply making every pair of friends non-friends and vice versa.  The same can be said of configurations with <math>n=2</math> when compared to configurations of <math>n=3</math>.  Thus, we have two cases to examine, <math>n=1</math> and <math>n=2</math>, and we count each of these combinations twice.

(Note: If you aren’t familiar with one-to-one correspondences, think of it like this: the number of ways to choose 4 friends is equal to number of ways to exclude one friend from your friend group. Hence, since the number of ways to choose 1 friend is the same thing as choosing 1 to not be friends with, <math>n=1</math> and <math>n=4</math> have the same number of ways. Similarly, <math>n=2</math> and <math>n=3</math> have the same number of ways as well. ~peelybonehead)

For <math>n=1</math>, if everyone has exactly one friend, that means there must be <math>3</math> pairs of friends, with no other interconnections.  The first person has <math>5</math> choices for a friend.  There are <math>4</math> people left.  The next person has <math>3</math> choices for a friend.  There are two people left, and these remaining two must be friends.  Thus, there are <math>15</math> configurations with <math>n=1</math>.

For <math>n=2</math>, there are two possibilities.  The group of <math>6</math> can be split into two groups of <math>3</math>, with each group creating a friendship triangle.  The first person has <math> LaTex binom{5}{2} = 10</math> ways to pick two friends from the other five, while the other three are forced together.  Thus, there are <math>10</math> triangular configurations.  

However, the group can also form a friendship hexagon, with each person sitting on a vertex, and each side representing the two friends that person has.  The first person may be seated anywhere on the hexagon [[without loss of generality]].  This person has <math> LaTex binom{5}{2} = 10</math> choices for the two friends on the adjoining vertices.  Each of the three remaining people can be seated "across" from one of the original three people, forming a different configuration.  Thus, there are <math>10  LaTex cdot 3! = 60</math> hexagonal configurations, and in total <math>70</math> configurations for <math>n=2</math>.

As stated before, <math>n=3</math> has <math>70</math> configurations, and <math>n=4</math> has <math>15</math> configurations.  This gives a total of <math>(70 + 15) LaTex cdot 2 = 170</math> configurations, which is option <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B)} LaTex  170}</math>.

=== Note ===

We can also calculate the triangular configurations by applying <math> LaTex frac{ LaTex binom{6}{3}}{2} =  LaTex frac{20}{2}=10</math> (Because choosing <math>A</math>,<math>B</math> and <math>C</math> is the same as choosing <math>D</math>,<math>E</math> and <math>F</math>.


For the hexagonal configurations, we know that the total amount of combinations is <math>6!=720</math>. However, we must correct for our  overcounting because of rotation and reflection. We have that there are <math>{720  LaTex over 6  LaTex cdot 2} = 60</math> because there <math>6</math> rotations of the hexagon and 2 reflections (clockwise and counterclockwise) for each valid way.

=== Note 2 ===
We can also calculate the hexagonal configurations by placing each person at a random vertex (6!) and dividing for rotations (by 6) and reflections (by 2): 
                                                 <math> LaTex frac{6!}{12}=60</math>

=== Note 3 ===

For the hexagonal configuration, it is essentially congruent to counting the number of paths that start and end with A. From <math>A</math>, we have <math>5</math> options, then the next one has <math>4</math>, and so on, so we have: <math>5 LaTex cdot 4  LaTex hdots 1  LaTex cdot 1</math>, where the final <math>1</math> is because the final point needs to reconnect to <math>A</math>. Thus, there are <math>5! = 120</math> ways. Dividng by <math>2</math> since we overcounted by accounting for both directions, we have <math>120/2 =  LaTex fbox{60}</math>

-bigbrain123

Consider the polynomial

<cmath>P(x)= LaTex prod_{k=0}^{10}(x^{2^k}+2^k)=(x+1)(x^2+2)(x^4+4) LaTex cdots (x^{1024}+1024)</cmath>

The coefficient of <math>x^{2012}</math> is equal to <math>2^a</math>.  What is <math>a</math>?
completion:
Every term in the expansion of the product is formed by taking one term from each factor and multiplying them all together. Therefore, we pick a power of <math>x</math> or a power of <math>2</math> from each factor.

Every number, including <math>2012</math>, has a unique representation by the sum of powers of two, and that representation can be found by converting a number to its binary form. <math>2012 = 11111011100_2</math>, meaning <math>2012 = 1024 + 512 + 256 + 128 + 64 + 16 + 8 + 4</math>. 

Thus, the <math>x^{2012}</math> term was made by multiplying <math>x^{1024}</math> from the <math>(x^{1024} + 1024)</math> factor, <math>x^{512}</math> from the <math>(x^{512} + 512)</math> factor, and so on. The only numbers not used are <math>32</math>, <math>2</math>, and <math>1</math>.

Thus, from the <math>(x^{32} + 32), (x^2+2), (x+1)</math> factors, <math>32</math>, <math>2</math>, and <math>1</math> were chosen as opposed to <math>x^{32}, x^2</math>, and <math>x</math>. 

Thus, the coefficient of the <math>x^{2012}</math> term is <math>32  LaTex times 2  LaTex times 1 = 64 = 2^6</math>. So the answer is <math>6  LaTex rightarrow  LaTex boxed{B}</math>.

prompt:
Let <math>a</math>, <math>b</math>, and <math>c</math> be positive integers with <math>a LaTex ge</math> <math>b LaTex ge</math> <math>c</math> such that
<cmath>
 LaTex begin{align*}a^{2}-b^{2}-c^{2}+ab&=2011 LaTex text{ and} LaTex  LaTex 
a^{2}+3b^{2}+3c^{2}-3ab-2ac-2bc&=-1997
 LaTex end{align*}
</cmath>

completion:
Add the two equations.

<math>2a^2 + 2b^2 + 2c^2 - 2ab - 2ac - 2bc = 14</math>.

Now, this can be rearranged and factored.

<math>(a^2 - 2ab + b^2) + (a^2 - 2ac + c^2) + (b^2 - 2bc + c^2) = 14</math>

Likewise on Monday: three possibilities, the three things that were not eaten on Tuesday.

On Sunday, it is tempting to think there are four possibilities, but remember that cake must be served on Friday. This serves to limit the number of foods we can eat on Sunday, with the result being that there are three possibilities: The three things that were not eaten on Monday.

So the number of menus is <math>3  LaTex cdot 3  LaTex cdot 3  LaTex cdot 3  LaTex cdot 3  LaTex cdot 1  LaTex cdot 3 = 729.</math>
The answer is <math> LaTex boxed{A}</math>.

prompt: Two parabolas have equations <math>y= x^2 + ax +b</math> and <math>y= x^2 + cx +d</math>, where <math>a</math>, <math>b</math>, <math>c</math>, and <math>d</math> are integers, each chosen independently by rolling a fair six-sided die. completion: Set the two equations equal to each other: <math>x^2 + ax + b = x^2 + cx + d</math>. Now remove the x squared and get <math>x</math>'s on one side: <math>ax-cx=d-b</math>. Now factor <math>x</math>: <math>x(a-c)=d-b</math>. If <math>a</math> cannot equal <math>c</math>, then there is always a solution, but if <math>a=c</math>, a <math>1</math> in <math>6</math> chance, leaving a <math>1080</math> out <math>1296</math>, always having at least one point in common. And if <math>a=c</math>, then the only way for that to work, is if <math>d=b</math>, a <math>1</math> in <math>36</math> chance, however, this can occur <math>6</math> ways, so a <math>1</math> in <math>6</math> chance of this happening. So adding one  thirty sixth to <math> LaTex frac{1080}{1296}</math>, we get the simplified fraction of <math> LaTex frac{31}{36}</math>; answer <math> LaTex boxed{(D)}</math>.

prompt: Bernardo and Silvia play the following game. An integer between <math>0</math> and <math>999</math> inclusive is selected and given to Bernardo. Whenever Bernardo receives a number, he doubles it and passes the result to Silvia. Whenever Silvia receives a number, she adds <math>50</math> to it and passes the result to Bernardo. The winner is the last person who produces a number less than <math>1000</math>. Let <math>N</math> be the smallest initial number that results in a win for Bernardo. What is the sum of the digits of <math>N</math>?
completion:
=== Solution 1 ===

The last number that Bernardo says has to be between 950 and 999. Note that <math>1 LaTex rightarrow 2 LaTex rightarrow 52 LaTex rightarrow 104 LaTex rightarrow 154 LaTex rightarrow 308 LaTex rightarrow 358 LaTex rightarrow 716 LaTex rightarrow 766</math> contains 4 doubling actions. Thus, we have <math>x  LaTex rightarrow 2x  LaTex rightarrow 2x+50  LaTex rightarrow 4x+100  LaTex rightarrow 4x+150  LaTex rightarrow 8x+300  LaTex rightarrow 8x+350  LaTex rightarrow 16x+700</math>. 

Thus, <math>950<16x+700<1000</math>. Then, <math>16x>250  LaTex implies x  LaTex geq 16</math>. 

Because we are looking for the smallest integer <math>x</math>, <math>x=16</math>. Our answer is <math>1+6= LaTex boxed{7}</math>, which is A.

~minor edits by KevinChen_Yay
~removed unnecessary last step (EvanDu168)

=== Solution 2 ===

Work backwards. The last number Bernardo produces must be in the range <math>[950,999]</math>. That means that before this, Silvia must produce a number in the range <math>[475,499]</math>. Before this, Bernardo must produce a number in the range <math>[425,449]</math>. Before this, Silvia must produce a number in the range <math>[213,224]</math>. Before this, Bernardo must produce a number in the range <math>[163,174]</math>. Before this, Silvia must produce a number in the range <math>[82,87]</math>. Before this, Bernardo must produce a number in the range <math>[32,37]</math>. Before this, Silvia must produce a number in the range <math>[16,18]</math>. Silvia could not have added 50 to any number before this to obtain a number in the range <math>[16,18]</math>, hence the minimum <math>N</math> is 16 with the sum of digits being <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A)} LaTex  7}</math>.

=== Solution 3 ===

If our first number is <math>N,</math> then the sequence of numbers will be <cmath>2N,~2N+50,~4N+100,~4N+150,~8N+300,~8N+350,~16N+700,~16N+750</cmath> Note that we cannot go any further because doubling gives an extra <math>1500</math> at the end, which is already greater than <math>1000.</math> The smallest <math>N</math> will be given if <math>16N+750>1000>16N+700  LaTex implies 15<N<19.</math> Since the problem asks for the smallest possible value of <math>N,</math> we get <math>16,</math> and the sum of its digits is <math>1+6= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A)}~7}</math>

~ 1001

Using the Pythagorean theorem, the height of the larger cone is <math>4 LaTex cdot LaTex sqrt{5}</math> and the smaller cone is <math>8 LaTex cdot LaTex sqrt{2}</math>, and now for volume just square the radii and multiply by <math> LaTex tfrac{1}{3}</math> of the height to get the volume of each cone: <math>128 LaTex cdot LaTex sqrt{2}</math> and <math>256 LaTex cdot LaTex sqrt{5}</math> [both multiplied by three as ratio come out the same. now divide the volumes by each other to get the final ratio of <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(C) }  LaTex frac{ LaTex sqrt{10}}{10}}</math>

prompt: Amy, Beth, and Jo listen to four different songs and discuss which ones they like. No song is liked by all three. Furthermore, for each of the three pairs of the girls, there is at least one song liked by those girls but disliked by the third. In how many different ways is this possible?
completion:
Let the ordered triple <math>(a,b,c)</math> denote that <math>a</math> songs are liked by Amy and Beth, <math>b</math> songs by Beth and Jo, and <math>c</math> songs by Jo and Amy. The only possible triples are <math>(1,1,1), (2,1,1), (1,2,1)(1,1,2)</math>. 

To show this, observe these are all valid conditions. Second, note that none of <math>a,b,c</math> can be bigger than 3. Suppose otherwise, that <math>a = 3</math>. Without loss of generality, say that Amy and Beth like songs 1, 2, and 3. Then because there is at least one song liked by each pair of girls, we require either <math>b</math> or <math>c</math> to be at least 1. In fact, we require either <math>b</math> or <math>c</math> to equal 1, otherwise there will be a song liked by all three. Suppose <math>b = 1</math>. Then we must have <math>c=0</math> since no song is liked by all three girls, a contradiction.

'''Case 1''': How many ways are there for <math>(a,b,c)</math> to equal <math>(1,1,1)</math>? There are 4 choices for which song is liked by Amy and Beth, 3 choices for which song is liked by Beth and Jo, and 2 choices for which song is liked by Jo and Amy. The fourth song can be liked by only one of the girls, or none of the girls, for a total of 4 choices. So <math>(a,b,c)=(1,1,1)</math> in <math>4 LaTex cdot3 LaTex cdot2 LaTex cdot4 = 96</math> ways.

'''Case 2''': To find the number of ways for <math>(a,b,c) = (2,1,1)</math>, observe there are <math> LaTex binom{4}{2} = 6</math> choices of songs for the first pair of girls. There remain 2 choices of songs for the next pair (who only like one song). The last song is given to the last pair of girls. But observe that we let any three pairs of the girls like two songs, so we multiply by 3. In this case there are <math>6 LaTex cdot2 LaTex cdot3=36</math> ways for the girls to like the songs.

That gives a total of <math>96 + 36 = 132</math> ways for the girls to like the songs, so the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{( LaTex textrm{ LaTex textbf{B}})}</math>.
