prompt: The sum of the [[root|zeros]], the product of the zeros, and the sum of the [[coefficient]]s of the [[function]] <math>f(x)=ax^{2}+bx+c</math> are equal. Their common value must also be which of the following?
completion:
By [[Vieta's formulas]], the sum of the roots of a [[quadratic equation]] is <math> LaTex frac {-b}a</math>,  the product of the zeros is <math> LaTex frac ca</math>, and the sum of the coefficients is <math>a + b + c</math>. Setting equal the first two tells us that <math> LaTex frac {-b}{a} =  LaTex frac ca  LaTex Rightarrow b = -c</math>. Thus, <math>a + b + c = a + b - b = a</math>, so the common value is also equal to the coefficient of <math>x^2  LaTex Longrightarrow  LaTex fbox{ LaTex textrm{A}}</math>. 

To disprove the others, note that:
*<math> LaTex mathrm{B}</math>: then <math>b =  LaTex frac {-b}a</math>, which is not necessarily true.
*<math> LaTex mathrm{C}</math>: the y-intercept is <math>c</math>, so <math>c =  LaTex frac ca</math>, not necessarily true.
*<math> LaTex mathrm{D}</math>: an x-intercept of the graph is a root of the polynomial, but this excludes the other root.
*<math> LaTex mathrm{E}</math>: the mean of the x-intercepts will be the sum of the roots of the quadratic divided by 2.

prompt: For each positive integer <math>n</math>, let <math>S(n)</math> denote the sum of the digits of <math>n.</math> For how many values of <math>n</math> is <math>n + S(n) + S(S(n)) = 2007?</math>
completion:
For the sake of notation, let <math>T(n) = n + S(n) + S(S(n))</math>. Obviously <math>n<2007</math>. Then the maximum value of <math>S(n) + S(S(n))</math> is when <math>n = 1999</math>, and the sum becomes <math>28 + 10 = 38</math>. So the minimum bound is <math>1969</math>. We do [[casework]] upon the tens digit:

Case 1: <math>196u  LaTex Longrightarrow u = 9</math>. Easy to directly disprove.

Case 2: <math>197u</math>. <math>S(n) = 1 + 9 + 7 + u = 17 + u</math>, and <math>S(S(n)) = 8+u</math> if <math>u  LaTex le 2</math> and <math>S(S(n)) = 2 + (u-3) = u-1</math> otherwise. 

:Subcase a: <math>T(n) = 1970 + u + 17 + u + 8 + u = 1995 + 3u = 2007  LaTex Longrightarrow u = 4</math>. This exceeds our bounds, so no solution here.
:Subcase b: <math>T(n) = 1970 + u + 17 + u + u - 1 = 1986 + 3u = 2007  LaTex Longrightarrow u = 7</math>. First solution.

Case 3: <math>198u</math>. <math>S(n) = 18 + u</math>, and <math>S(S(n)) = 9 + u</math> if <math>u  LaTex le 1</math> and <math>2 + (u-2) = u</math> otherwise.

:Subcase a: <math>T(n) = 1980 + u + 18 + u + 9 + u = 2007 + 3u = 2007  LaTex Longrightarrow u = 0</math>. Second solution.
:Subcase b: <math>T(n) = 1980 + u + 18 + u + u = 1998 + 3u = 2007  LaTex Longrightarrow u = 3</math>. Third solution. 

Case 4: <math>199u</math>. But <math>S(n) > 19</math>, and <math>n + S(n)</math> clearly sum to <math>> 2007</math>.

Case 5: <math>200u</math>. So <math>S(n) = 2 + u</math> and <math>S(S(n)) = 2 + u</math> (recall that <math>n < 2007 </math>), and <math>2000 + u + 2 + u + 2 + u = 2004 + 3u = 2007  LaTex Longrightarrow u = 1</math>. Fourth solution.

In total we have <math>4  LaTex mathrm{(D)}</math> solutions, which are <math>1977, 1980, 1983, </math> and <math>2001</math>.

prompt: [[Square]] <math>ABCD</math> has area <math>36,</math> and <math> LaTex overline{AB}</math> is [[parallel]] to the [[x-axis]]. Vertices <math>A,</math> <math>B</math>, and <math>C</math> are on the graphs of <math>y =  LaTex log_{a}x,</math> <math>y = 2 LaTex log_{a}x,</math> and <math>y = 3 LaTex log_{a}x,</math> respectively. What is <math>a?</math>
completion:
Let <math>x</math> be the x-coordinate of <math>B</math> and <math>C</math>, and <math>x_2</math> be the x-coordinate of <math>A</math> and <math>y</math> be the y-coordinate of <math>A</math> and <math>B</math>. Then <math>2 LaTex log_ax= y  LaTex Longrightarrow a^{y/2} = x</math> and <math> LaTex log_ax_2 = y  LaTex Longrightarrow x_2 = a^y =  LaTex left(a^{y/2} LaTex right)^2 = x^2</math>. Since the distance between <math>A</math> and <math>B</math> is <math>6</math>, we have <math>x^2 - x - 6 = 0</math>, yielding <math>x = -2, 3</math>.

However, we can discard the negative root (all three [[logarithm]]ic equations are underneath the line <math>y = 3</math> and above <math>y = 0</math> when <math>x</math> is negative, hence we can't squeeze in a square of side 6). Thus <math>x = 3</math>.

Substituting back, <math>3 LaTex log_{a}x - 2 LaTex log_{a}x = 6  LaTex Longrightarrow a^6 = x</math>, so <math>a =  LaTex sqrt[6]{3} LaTex   LaTex   LaTex mathrm{(A)}</math>.

prompt: For each integer <math>n>1</math>, let <math>F(n)</math> be the number of solutions to the equation <math> LaTex sin{x}= LaTex sin{(nx)}</math> on the interval <math>[0, LaTex pi]</math>. What is <math> LaTex sum_{n=2}^{2007} F(n)</math>?

<math>F(2)=3</math>

By looking at various graphs, we obtain that, for most of the graphs

<math>F(n) = n + 1</math>

<math>3+4+5+5+7+8+9+9+ LaTex cdots+2008</math>
<math>= (1+2+3+4+5+ LaTex cdots+2008) - 3 - 501</math>
<math>=  LaTex frac{(2008)(2009)}{2} - 504 = 2016532</math>  <math> LaTex mathrm{(D)}</math>

prompt: Call a set of integers ''spacy'' if it contains no more than one out of any three consecutive integers. How many [[subset]]s of <math> LaTex {1,2,3, LaTex ldots,12 LaTex },</math> including the [[empty set]], are spacy?
completion:
Let S_{n} denote the number of spacy subsets of LaTex { 1, 2, ... n LaTex }. We have S_{0} = 1, S_{1} = 2, S_{2} = 3. The spacy subsets of S_{n + 1} can be divided into two groups: *A = those not containing n + 1. Clearly |A|=S_{n}. *B = those containing n + 1. We have |B|=S_{n - 2}, since removing n + 1 from any set in B produces a spacy set with all elements at most equal to n - 2, and each such spacy set can be constructed from exactly one spacy set in B. Hence,
S_{n + 1} = S_{n} + S_{n - 2}
From this [[recursion]], we find that {| class="wikitable" border="1px solid" |- | S(0) || S(1) || S(2) || S(3) || S(4) || S(5) || S(6) || S(7) || S(8) || S(9) || S(10) || S(11) || S(12) || |- | 1 || 2 || 3 || 4 || 6 || 9 || 13 || 19 || 28 || 41 || 60 || 88 || 129 |} And so the answer is (E) 129.

 LaTex end{align*}</cmath>
<cmath> LaTex angle A = 360  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{12}{25} = 172.8  LaTex approx  LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(D)  LaTex  } 173}</cmath>

prompt: A traffic light runs repeatedly through the following cycle: green for <math>30</math> seconds, then yellow for <math>3</math> seconds, and then red for <math>30</math> seconds. completion:
The traffic light runs through a <math>63</math> second cycle.

Letting <math>t=0</math> reference the moment it turns green, the light changes at three different times: <math>t=30</math>, <math>t=33</math>, and <math>t=63</math>

This means that the light will change if the beginning of Leah's interval lies in
<math>[27,30]</math>, <math>[30,33]</math> or <math>[60,63]</math>

This gives a total of <math>9</math> seconds out of <math>63</math>

<math> LaTex frac{9}{63} =  LaTex frac{1}{7}  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(D)}</math>

prompt: Point <math>P</math> is inside equilateral <math> LaTex triangle ABC</math>. completion:
Drawing <math> LaTex overline{PA}</math>, <math> LaTex overline{PB}</math>, and <math> LaTex overline{PC}</math>, <math> LaTex triangle ABC</math> is split into three smaller triangles. The altitudes of these triangles are given in the problem as <math>PQ</math>, <math>PR</math>, and <math>PS</math>.

Summing the areas of each of these triangles and equating it to the area of the entire triangle, we get:

<cmath> LaTex frac{s}{2} +  LaTex frac{2s}{2} +  LaTex frac{3s}{2} =  LaTex frac{s^2 LaTex sqrt{3}}{4}</cmath>
where <math>s</math> is the length of a side of the equilateral triangle

<cmath>s =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(D)  LaTex  } 4 LaTex sqrt{3}}</cmath>

*Note - This is called [[Viviani's Theorem]].

prompt: The geometric series <math>a+ar+ar^2 LaTex cdots</math> has a sum of <math>7</math>, and the terms involving odd powers of <math>r</math> have a sum of <math>3</math>. What is <math>a+r</math>?
completion:
The sum of an infinite geometric series is given by <math> LaTex frac{a}{1-r}</math> where <math>a</math> is the first term and <math>r</math> is the common ratio.

In this series, <math> LaTex frac{a}{1-r} = 7</math>

The series with odd powers of <math>r</math> is given as <cmath>ar + ar^3 + ar^5 ...</cmath>

Its sum can be given by <math> LaTex frac{ar}{1-r^2} = 3</math>

Doing a little algebra

<math>ar = 3(1-r)(1+r)</math>

<math>ar = 3 LaTex left( LaTex frac{a}{7} LaTex right)(1+r)</math>

<math> LaTex frac{7}{3}r = 1 + r</math>

<math>r =  LaTex frac{3}{4}</math>

<math>a = 7(1-r) =  LaTex frac{7}{4}</math>

<math>a + r = LaTex boxed{  LaTex frac{5}{2}}  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(E)}</math>

prompt: Each face of a regular tetrahedron is painted either red, white, or blue. Two colorings are considered indistinguishable if two congruent tetrahedra with those colorings can be rotated so that their appearances are identical. How many distinguishable colorings are possible?
completion:
A tetrahedron has 4 sides.
The ratio of the number of faces with each color must be one of the following:

<math>4:0:0</math>, <math>3:1:0</math>, <math>2:2:0</math>, or <math>2:1:1</math>



The first ratio yields <math>3</math> appearances, one of each color.

The second ratio yields <math>3 LaTex cdot 2 = 6</math> appearances, three choices for the first color, and two choices for the second.

The third ratio yields <math> LaTex binom{3}{2} = 3</math> appearances since the two colors are interchangeable.

The fourth ratio yields <math>3</math> appearances. There are three choices for the first color, and since the second two colors are interchangeable, there is only one distinguishable pair that fits them.

The total is <math>3 + 6 + 3 + 3 = 15</math> appearances <math> LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(A)}</math>

prompt: If <math>a</math> is a nonzero integer and <math>b</math> is a positive number such that <math>ab^2= LaTex log_{10}b</math>, what is the median of the set <math> LaTex {0,1,a,b,1/b LaTex }</math>?
completion:
Note that if <math>a</math> is positive, then, the equation will have no solutions for <math>b</math>. This becomes more obvious by noting that at <math>b=1</math>, <math>ab^2 >  LaTex log_{10} b</math>. The LHS quadratic function will increase faster than the RHS logarithmic function, so they will never intersect.

This puts <math>a</math> as the smallest in the set since it must be negative.

Checking the new equation: <math>-b^2 =  LaTex log_{10}b</math>

Near <math>b=0</math>, <math>-b^2 >  LaTex log_{10} b</math> but at <math>b=1</math>, <math>-b^2 <  LaTex log_{10} b</math>

This implies that the solution occurs somewhere in between: <math>0 < b < 1</math>

This also implies that <math> LaTex frac{1}{b} > 1</math>

This makes our set (ordered)
<math> LaTex {a,0,b,1,1/b LaTex }</math>

The median is <math>b  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex mathrm {(D)}</math>

prompt: Let <math>a</math>, <math>b</math>, and <math>c</math> be digits with <math>a LaTex ne 0</math>. The three-digit integer <math>abc</math> lies one third of the way from the square of a positive integer to the square of the next larger integer. The integer <math>acb</math> lies two thirds of the way between the same two squares. What is <math>a+b+c</math>?
completion:
The difference between <math>acb</math> and <math>abc</math> is given by

<math>(100a + 10c + b) - (100a + 10b + c) = 9(c-b)</math>

The difference between the two squares is three times this amount or

<math>27(c-b)</math>

The difference between two consecutive squares is always an odd number, therefore <math>c-b</math> is odd. We will show that <math>c-b</math> must be 1. Otherwise we would be looking for two consecutive squares that are at least 81 apart. But already the equation <math>(x+1)^2-x^2 = 27 LaTex cdot 3</math> solves to <math>x=40</math>, and <math>40^2</math> has more than three digits.

The consecutive squares with common difference <math>27</math> are <math>13^2=169</math> and <math>14^2=196</math>. One third of the way between them is <math>178</math> and two thirds of the way is <math>187</math>.

This gives <math>a=1</math>, <math>b=7</math>, <math>c=8</math>.

<math>a+b+c = 16  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(C)}</math>

prompt: The first <math>2007</math> positive integers are each written in base <math>3</math>. How many of these base-<math>3</math> representations are palindromes? (A palindrome is a number that reads the same forward and backward.)

All numbers of six or less digits in base 3 have been written.

The form of each palindrome is as follows

4 digits - <math>abba</math>

All of these numbers are also small enough, giving <math>2 LaTex cdot 3^2</math> more palindromes

Summing our cases there are
<math>52 + 3^3 + 2 LaTex cdot 3^2 + 3 = 100  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(A)}</math>

prompt: Two particles move along the edges of equilateral <math> LaTex triangle ABC</math> in the direction <cmath>A LaTex Rightarrow B LaTex Rightarrow C LaTex Rightarrow A,</cmath> starting simultaneously and moving at the same speed. One starts at <math>A</math>, and the other starts at the midpoint of <math> LaTex overline{BC}</math>. The midpoint of the line segment joining the two particles traces out a path that encloses a region <math>R</math>. What is the ratio of the area of <math>R</math> to the area of <math> LaTex triangle ABC</math>?
completion:
First, notice that each of the midpoints of <math>AB</math>,<math>BC</math>, and <math>CA</math> are on the locus.
Suppose after some time the particles have each been displaced by a short distance <math>x</math>, to new positions <math>A'</math> and <math>M'</math> respectively. Consider <math> LaTex triangle ABM</math> and drop a perpendicular from <math>M'</math> to hit <math>AB</math> at <math>Y</math>. Then, <math>BA'=1-x</math> and <math>BM'=1/2+x</math>. From here, we can use properties of a <math>30-60-90</math> triangle to determine the lengths <math>YA'</math> and <math>YM'</math> as monomials in <math>x</math>. Thus, the locus of the midpoint will be linear between each of the three special points mentioned above. It follows that the locus consists of the only triangle with those three points as vertices. (A cheaper way to find the shape of the region is to look at the answer choices: if it were any sort of conic section then the ratio would not generally be rational.)
Comparing inradii between this "midpoint" triangle and the original triangle, the area contained by <math>R</math> must be <math> LaTex textbf{(A)}  LaTex frac{1}{16}</math> of the total area.

prompt: How many non-congruent right triangles with positive integer leg lengths have areas that are numerically equal to <math>3</math> times their perimeters?
completion:
Let <math>a</math> and <math>b</math> be the two legs of the triangle.

We have <math> LaTex frac{1}{2}ab = 3(a+b+c)</math>.

Then <math>ab=6  LaTex left(a+b+ LaTex sqrt {a^2 + b^2} LaTex right)</math>.

We can complete the square under the root, and we get, <math>ab=6  LaTex left(a+b+ LaTex sqrt {(a+b)^2 - 2ab} LaTex right)</math>.

Let <math>ab=p</math> and <math>a+b=s</math>, we have <math>p=6  LaTex left(s+  LaTex sqrt {s^2 - 2p} LaTex right)</math>.

After rearranging, squaring both sides, and simplifying, we have <math>p=12s-72</math>.


Putting back <math>a</math> and <math>b</math>, and after factoring using Simon's Favorite Factoring Trick, we've got <math>(a-12)(b-12)=72</math>.


Factoring 72, we get 6 pairs of <math>a</math> and <math>b</math>


<math>(13, 84), (14, 48), (15, 36), (16, 30), (18, 24), (20, 21).</math>


And this gives us <math>6</math> solutions <math> LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(A)}</math>.


Alternatively, note that <math>72 = 2^3  LaTex cdot 3^2</math>. Then 72 has <math>(3+1)(2+1) = (4)(3) = 12</math> factors. However, half of these are repeats, so we have <math> LaTex frac{12}{2} = 6</math> solutions.

prompt: How many pairs of positive integers <math>(a,b)</math> are there such that <math> LaTex gcd{(a,b)}=1</math> and <cmath> LaTex frac{a}{b}+ LaTex frac{14b}{9a}</cmath> is an integer?
completion:
Combining the fraction, <math> LaTex frac{9a^2 + 14b^2}{9ab}</math> must be an integer.

Since the denominator contains a factor of <math>9</math>, <math>9 | 9a^2 + 14b^2  LaTex quad LaTex Longrightarrow LaTex quad 9 | b^2  LaTex quad LaTex Longrightarrow LaTex quad 3 | b</math>

Since <math>b = 3n</math> for some positive integer <math>n</math>, we can rewrite the fraction(divide by <math>9</math> on both top and bottom) as <math> LaTex frac{a^2 + 14n^2}{3an}</math>

Since the denominator now contains a factor of <math>n</math>, we get <math>n | a^2 + 14n^2  LaTex quad LaTex Longrightarrow LaTex quad n | a^2</math>.

But since <math>1= LaTex gcd(a,b)= LaTex gcd(a,3n)= LaTex gcd(a,n)</math>, we must have <math>n=1</math>, and thus <math>b=3</math>.

For <math>b=3</math> the original fraction simplifies to <math> LaTex frac{a^2 + 14}{3a}</math>.

For that to be an integer, <math>a</math> must be a factor of <math>14</math>, and therefore we must have <math>a LaTex in LaTex {1,2,7,14 LaTex }</math>. Each of these values does indeed yield an integer.

Thus there are four solutions: <math>(1,3)</math>, <math>(2,3)</math>, <math>(7,3)</math>, <math>(14,3)</math> and the answer is <math> LaTex mathrm{(A)}</math>

prompt: How many sets of two or more consecutive positive integers have a sum of <math>15</math>?
completion:
Notice that if the consecutive positive integers have a sum of <math>15</math>, then their average (which could be a fraction) must be a divisor of <math>15</math>. If the number of integers in the list is odd, then the average must be either <math>1, 3, </math> or <math>5</math>, and <math>1</math> is clearly not possible. The other two possibilities both work:

*<math>1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 = 15</math>
*<math>4 + 5 + 6 = 15</math>

If the number of integers in the list is even, then the average will have a <math> LaTex frac{1}{2}</math>. The only possibility is <math> LaTex frac{15}{2}</math>, from which we get:

*<math>15 = 7 + 8</math>

Thus, the correct answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(C) }3}.</math>


Question: (RealityWrites) Is it possible that the answer is <math>4</math>, because <math>0+1+2+3+4+5</math> should technically count, right?

prompt: Oscar buys <math>13</math> pencils and <math>3</math> erasers for <math> LaTex textdollar 1.00</math>. A pencil costs more than an eraser, and both items cost a whole number of cents. What is the total cost, in cents, of one pencil and one eraser?
completion:
Let the price of a pencil be <math>p</math> and an eraser <math>e</math>.  Then <math>13p + 3e = 100</math> with <math>p > e > 0</math>.  Since <math>p</math> and <math>e</math> are [[positive integer]]s, we must have <math>e  LaTex geq 1</math> and <math>p  LaTex geq 2</math>.

Considering the [[equation]] <math>13p + 3e = 100</math> [[modulo]] 3 (that is, comparing the [[remainder]]s when both sides are divided by 3) we have <math>p + 0e  LaTex equiv 1  LaTex pmod 3</math> so <math>p</math> leaves a remainder of 1 on division by 3.

Since <math>p  LaTex geq 2</math>, possible values for <math>p</math> are 4, 7, 10 ....

Since 13 pencils cost less than 100 cents, <math>13p < 100</math>.  <math>13  LaTex times 10 = 130</math> is too high, so <math>p</math> must be 4 or 7.

If <math>p = 4</math> then <math>13p = 52</math> and so <math>3e = 48</math> giving <math>e = 16</math>.  This contradicts the pencil being more expensive.  The only remaining value for <math>p</math> is 7; then the 13 pencils cost <math>7  LaTex times 13= 91</math> cents and so the 3 erasers together cost 9 cents and each eraser costs <math> LaTex frac{9}{3} = 3</math> cents.

Thus one pencil plus one eraser cost <math>7 + 3 = 10</math> cents, which is answer choice <math> LaTex mathrm{(A)  LaTex  }</math>.

[[Bezout%27s Lemma]] tells us that the smallest <math>c</math> for the Diophantine equation <math>am + bn = c</math> to have solutions is when <math>c</math> is the GCD ([[greatest common divisor]]) of <math>a</math> and <math>b</math>. Let the starting point be <math>(0,0)</math>. After <math>10</math> steps we can only be in locations <math>(x,y)</math> where <math>|x|+|y| LaTex leq 10</math>. Once we pick <math>x LaTex in LaTex {-10, LaTex dots,10 LaTex }</math>, we have <math>11-|x|</math> valid choices for <math>y</math>, giving a total of <math> LaTex boxed{121}</math> possible positions.

prompt: Mr. Jones has eight children of different ages. On a family trip his oldest child, who is 9, spots a license plate with a 4-digit number in which each of two digits appears two times. completion:

<math>aabb</math>, <math>abba</math> or <math>abab</math>. 

We can conclude straight away that <math>a+b= 9</math> using the <math>9</math> divisibility rule. 

If <math>b=1</math>, the number is not divisible by <math>2</math> (unless it's <math>1818</math>, which is not divisible by <math>4</math>), which means there are no <math>2</math>, <math>4</math>, <math>6</math>, or <math>8</math> year olds on the car, but that can't be true, as that would mean there are less than <math>8</math> kids on the car. 

If <math>b=2</math>, then the only possible number is <math>7272</math>. <math>7272</math> is divisible by <math>4</math>, <math>6</math>, and <math>8</math>, but not by <math>5</math> and <math>7</math>, so that doesn't work. 

If <math>b=3</math>, then the only number is <math>6336</math>, also not divisible by <math>5</math> or <math>7</math>. 

If <math>b=4</math>, the only number is <math>5544</math>. It is divisible by <math>4</math>, <math>6</math>, <math>7</math>, and <math>8</math>. 

Therefore, we conclude that the answer is <math>  LaTex mathrm{(B)} LaTex  5 </math>

'''NOTE''': Automatically, since there are 8 children and all of their ages are less than or equal to 9 and are different, the answer choices can be narrowed down to <math>5</math> or <math>8</math>.

Let <math>k</math> be an arbitrary integer. For which <math>x</math> do we have <math> LaTex lfloor LaTex log_{10}4x LaTex rfloor =  LaTex lfloor LaTex log_{10}x LaTex rfloor = k</math>?

The equation <math> LaTex lfloor LaTex log_{10}x LaTex rfloor = k</math> can be rewritten as <math>10^k  LaTex leq x < 10^{k+1}</math>. The second one gives us <math>10^k  LaTex leq 4x < 10^{k+1}</math>. Combining these, we get that both hold at the same time if and only if <math>10^k  LaTex leq x <  LaTex frac{10^{k+1}}4</math>.

Hence for each integer <math>k</math> we get an interval of values for which <math> LaTex lfloor LaTex log_{10}4x LaTex rfloor -  LaTex lfloor LaTex log_{10}x LaTex rfloor = 0</math>. These intervals are obviously pairwise disjoint.

For any <math>k LaTex geq 0</math> the corresponding interval is disjoint with <math>(0,1)</math>, so it does not contribute to our answer. On the other hand, for any <math>k<0</math> the entire interval is inside <math>(0,1)</math>. Hence our answer is the sum of the lengths of the intervals for <math>k<0</math>.

For a fixed <math>k</math> the length of the interval <math> LaTex left[ 10^k,  LaTex frac{10^{k+1}}4  LaTex right)</math> is <math> LaTex frac 32 LaTex cdot 10^k</math>. 

This means that our result is <math> LaTex frac 32  LaTex left( 10^{-1} + 10^{-2} +  LaTex cdots  LaTex right) =  LaTex frac 32  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac 19 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex frac 16}</math>.

A sequence <math>a_1,a_2, LaTex dots</math> of non-negative integers is defined by the rule <math>a_{n+2}=|a_{n+1}-a_n|</math> for <math>n LaTex geq 1</math>. If <math>a_1=999</math>, <math>a_2<999</math> and <math>a_{2006}=1</math>, how many different values of <math>a_2</math> are possible?
completion:
We say the sequence <math>(a_n)</math> completes at <math>i</math> if <math>i</math> is the minimal positive integer such that <math>a_i = a_{i + 1} = 1</math>. Otherwise, we say <math>(a_n)</math> does not complete.


Note that if <math>d =  LaTex gcd(999, a_2)  LaTex neq 1</math>, then <math>d|a_n</math> for all <math>n  LaTex geq 1</math>, and <math>d</math> does not divide <math>1</math>, so if <math> LaTex gcd(999, a_2)  LaTex neq 1</math>, then <math>(a_n)</math> does not complete. (Also, <math>a_{2006}</math> cannot be 1 in this case since <math>d</math> does not divide <math>1</math>, so we do not care about these <math>a_2</math> at all.)

From now on, suppose <math> LaTex gcd(999, a_2) = 1</math>.


We will now show that <math>(a_n)</math> completes at <math>i</math> for some <math>i  LaTex leq 2006</math>. We will do this with 3 lemmas.


'''Lemma:''' If <math>a_j  LaTex neq a_{j + 1}</math>, and neither value is <math>0</math>, then <math> LaTex max(a_j, a_{j + 1}) >  LaTex max(a_{j + 2}, a_{j + 3})</math>.

'''Proof:''' There are 2 cases to consider.

If <math>a_j > a_{j + 1}</math>, then <math>a_{j + 2} = a_j - a_{j + 1}</math>, and <math>a_{j + 3} = |a_j - 2a_{j + 1}|</math>. So <math>a_j > a_{j + 2}</math> and <math>a_j > a_{j + 3}</math>.

If <math>a_j < a_{j + 1}</math>, then <math>a_{j + 2} = a_{j + 1} - a_j</math>, and <math>a_{j + 3} = a_j</math>. So <math>a_{j + 1} > a_{j + 2}</math> and <math>a_{j + 1} > a_{j + 3}</math>.

In both cases, <math> LaTex max(a_j, a_{j + 1}) >  LaTex max(a_{j + 2}, a_{j + 3})</math>, as desired.
----------------------

'''Lemma:''' If <math>a_i = a_{i + 1}</math>, then <math>a_i = 1</math>. Moreover, if instead we have <math>a_i = 0</math> for some <math>i > 2</math>, then <math>a_{i - 1} = a_{i - 2} = 1</math>.

'''Proof:''' By the way <math>(a_n)</math> is constructed in the problem statement, having two equal consecutive terms <math>a_i = a_{i + 1}</math> implies that <math>a_i</math> divides every term in the sequence. So <math>a_i | 999</math> and <math>a_i | a_2</math>, so <math>a_i |  LaTex gcd(999, a_2) = 1</math>, so <math>a_i = 1</math>. For the proof of the second result, note that if <math>a_i = 0</math>, then <math>a_{i - 1} = a_{i - 2}</math>, so by the first result we just proved, <math>a_{i - 2} = a_{i - 1} = 1</math>.
----------------------

'''Lemma:''' <math>(a_n)</math> completes at <math>i</math> for some <math>i  LaTex leq 2000</math>.

'''Proof:''' Suppose <math>(a_n)</math> completed at some <math>i > 2000</math> or not at all. Then by the second lemma and the fact that neither <math>999</math> nor <math>a_2</math> are <math>0</math>, none of the pairs <math>(a_1, a_2), ..., (a_{1999}, a_{2000})</math> can have a <math>0</math> or be equal to <math>(1, 1)</math>. So the first lemma implies
<cmath> LaTex max(a_1, a_2) >  LaTex max(a_3, a_4) >  LaTex cdots >  LaTex max(a_{1999}, a_{2000})  > 0,</cmath>
so <math>999 =  LaTex max(a_1, a_2)  LaTex geq 1000</math>, a contradiction. Hence <math>(a_n)</math> completes at <math>i</math> for some <math>i  LaTex leq 2000</math>.
----------------------


Now we're ready to find exactly which values of <math>a_2</math> we want to count.

Let's keep in mind that <math>2006  LaTex equiv 2  LaTex pmod 3</math> and that <math>a_1 = 999</math> is odd. We have two cases to consider.


'''Case 1:''' If <math>a_2</math> is odd, then <math>a_3</math> is even, so <math>a_4</math> is odd, so <math>a_5</math> is odd, so <math>a_6</math> is even, and this pattern must repeat every three terms because of the recursive definition of <math>(a_n)</math>, so the terms of <math>(a_n)</math> reduced modulo 2 are
<cmath>1, 1, 0, 1, 1, 0, ...,</cmath> 
so <math>a_{2006}</math> is odd and hence <math>1</math> (since if <math>(a_n)</math> completes at <math>i</math>, then <math>a_k</math> must be <math>0</math> or <math>1</math> for all <math>k  LaTex geq i</math>).
---------------------

'''Case 2:''' If <math>a_2</math> is even, then <math>a_3</math> is odd, so <math>a_4</math> is odd, so <math>a_5</math> is even, so <math>a_6</math> is odd, and this pattern must repeat every three terms, so the terms of <math>(a_n)</math> reduced modulo 2 are 
<cmath>1, 0, 1, 1, 0, 1, ...,</cmath>
so <math>a_{2006}</math> is even, and hence <math>0</math>.
---------------------


We have found that <math>a_{2006} = 1</math> is true precisely when <math> LaTex gcd(999, a_2) = 1</math> and <math>a_2</math> is odd. This tells us what we need to count.


There are <math> LaTex phi(999) = 648</math> numbers less than <math>999</math> and relatively prime to it (<math> LaTex phi</math> is the Euler totient function). We want to count how many of these are odd. Note that
<cmath>t  LaTex mapsto 999 - t</cmath>
is a 1-1 correspondence between the odd and even numbers less than and relatively prime to <math>999</math>. So our final answer is <math>648/2 = 324</math>, or <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex text{B}}</math>.

prompt: Six ants simultaneously stand on the six [[vertex|vertices]] of a regular [[octahedron]], with each ant at a different vertex. Simultaneously and independently, each ant moves from its vertex to one of the four adjacent vertices, each with equal [[probability]]. What is the probability that no two ants arrive at the same vertex?
completion:
=== Solution 1 ===
We approach this problem by counting the number of ways ants can do their desired migration, and then multiple this number by the probability that each case occurs.

Let the octahedron be <math>ABCDEF</math>, with points <math>B,C,D,E</math> [[coplanar]]. Then the ant from <math>A</math> and the ant from <math>F</math> must move to plane <math>BCDE</math>. Suppose, without loss of generality, that the ant from <math>A</math> moved to point <math>B</math>. Then, we must consider three cases.

*Case 1: Ant from point <math>F</math> moved to point <math>C</math>
On the plane, points <math>B</math> and <math>C</math> are taken. The ant that moves to <math>D</math> can come from either <math>E</math> or <math>C</math>. The ant that moves to <math>E</math> can come from either <math>B</math> or <math>D</math>. Once these two ants are fixed, the other two ants must migrate to the "poles" of the octahedron, points <math>A</math> and <math>F</math>. Thus, there are two degrees of freedom in deciding which ant moves to <math>D</math>, two degrees of freedom in deciding which ant moves to <math>E</math>, and two degrees of freedom in deciding which ant moves to <math>A</math>. Hence, there are <math>2  LaTex times 2  LaTex times 2=8</math> ways the ants can move to different points.

*Case 2: Ant from point <math>F</math> moved to point <math>D</math>
On the plane, points <math>B</math> and <math>D</math> are taken. The ant that moves to <math>C</math> must be from <math>B</math> or <math>D</math>, but the ant that moves to <math>E</math> must also be from <math>B</math> or <math>D</math>. The other two ants, originating from points <math>C</math> and <math>E</math>, must move to the poles. Therefore, there are two degrees of freedom in deciding which ant moves to <math>C</math> and two degrees of freedom in choosing which ant moves to <math>A</math>. Hence, there are <math>2  LaTex times 2=4</math> ways the ants can move to different points.

*Case 3: Ant from point <math>F</math> moved to point <math>E</math>
By symmetry to Case 1, there are <math>8</math> ways the ants can move to different points.

Given a point <math>B</math>, there is a total of <math>8+4+8=20</math> ways the ants can move to different points. We oriented the square so that point <math>B</math> was defined as the point to which the ant from point <math>A</math> moved. Since the ant from point <math>A</math> can actually move to four different points, there is a total of <math>4  LaTex times 20=80</math> ways the ants can move to different points.

Each ant acts independently, having four different points to choose from. Hence, each ant has probability <math>1/4</math> of moving to the desired location. Since there are six ants, the probability of each case occuring is <math> LaTex frac{1}{4^6} =  LaTex frac{1}{4096}</math>. Thus, the desired answer is <math> LaTex frac{80}{4096}=  LaTex boxed{ LaTex frac{5}{256}}  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(A)}</math>.

=== Solution 2 ===
Let <math>f(n)</math> be the number of [[cycle]]s of length <math>n</math> the can be walked among the vertices of an octahedron. For example, <math>f(3)</math> would represent the number of ways in which an ant could navigate <math>2</math> vertices and then return back to the original spot. Since an ant cannot stay still, <math>f(1) = 0</math>. We also easily see that <math>f(2) = 1, f(3) = 2</math>. 

Now consider any four vertices of the octahedron. All four vertices will be connected by edges except for one pair. Let’s think of this as a [[square]] with one diagonal (from top left to bottom right). EDIT: This part is wrong as if you choose the 4 vertices that have a cross section as a square, there exists no connecting diagonal.  
<center><asy>
size(30);
defaultpen(0.6);
pair A = (0,0), B=(5,0), C=(5,5), D=(0,5);
draw(A--B--C--D--cycle); 
draw(B--D);
</asy></center>
Suppose an ant moved across this diagonal; then the ant at the other end can only move across the diagonal (which creates 2-cycle, bad) or it can move to another vertex, but then the ant at that vertex must move to the spot of the original ant (which creates 3-cycle, bad). Thus none of the ants can navigate the diagonal and can either shift clockwise or counterclockwise, and so <math>f(4) = 2</math>.

For <math>f(6)</math>, consider an ant at the top of the octahedron. It has four choices. Afterwards, it can either travel directly to the bottom, and then it has <math>2</math> ways back up, or it can travel along the sides and then go to the bottom, of which simple counting gives us <math>6</math> ways back up. Hence, this totals <math>4  LaTex times (2+6) = 32</math>.

prompt: Let <math>S</math> be the set of points <math>(a,b)</math> in the coordinate plane, where each of <math>a</math> and <math>b</math> may be <math>- 1</math>, <math>0</math>, or <math>1</math>. How many distinct lines pass through at least two members of <math>S</math>?
completion:
[[Image:2004_AMC12A-13.png|center]]
=== Solution 1 ===
Let's count them by cases:

[[Image:2004_AMC12A-13b.png|center]]

*'''Case 1''': The line is horizontal or vertical, clearly <math>3  LaTex cdot 2 = 6</math>.
*'''Case 2''': The line has slope <math> LaTex pm 1</math>, with <math>2</math> through <math>(0,0)</math> and <math>4</math> additional ones one unit above or below those. These total <math>6</math>.  
*'''Case 3''': The only remaining lines pass through two points, a vertex and a non-vertex point on the opposite side. Thus we have each vertex pairing up with two points on the two opposites sides, giving <math>4  LaTex cdot 2 = 8</math> lines.
These add up to <math>6+6+8=20 LaTex   LaTex mathrm{(B)}</math>. 

=== Solution 2 ===
There are <math>{9  LaTex choose 2} = 36</math> ways to pick two points, but we've clearly overcounted all of the lines which pass through three points. In fact, each line which passes through three points will have been counted <math>{3  LaTex choose 2} = 3</math> times, so we have to subtract <math>2</math> for each of these lines. Quick counting yields <math>3</math> horizontal, <math>3</math> vertical, and <math>2</math> diagonal lines, so the answer is <math>36 - 2(3+3+2) = 20</math> distinct lines.

=== Solution 3 ===
First consider how many lines go through <math>(-1, -1)</math> and hit two points in <math>S</math>. You can see that there are <math>5</math> such lines. Now, we cross out <math>(-1, -1)</math> and make sure to never consider consider lines that go through it anymore (As doing so would be double counting). Repeat for <math>(-1, 0)</math>, making sure not to count the vertical line as it goes through the crossed out <math>(-1, -1)</math>. Then cross out <math>(-1, 0)</math>. Repeat for the rest, and count <math>20</math> lines in total.

prompt: Select numbers <math>a</math> and <math>b</math> between <math>0</math> and <math>1</math> independently and at random, and let <math>c</math> be their sum. Let <math>A, B</math> and <math>C</math> be the results when <math>a, b</math> and <math>c</math>, respectively, are rounded to the nearest integer. What is the probability that <math>A + B = C</math>?
completion:
=== Solution 1 === 
[[Casework]]:

#<math>0 + 0 = 0</math>. The probability that <math>a <  LaTex frac{1}{2}</math> and <math>b <  LaTex frac{1}{2}</math> is <math> LaTex left( LaTex frac 12 LaTex right)^2 =  LaTex frac{1}{4}</math>. Notice that the sum <math>a+b</math> ranges from <math>0</math> to <math>1</math> with a symmetric distribution across <math>a+b=c= LaTex frac 12</math>, and we want <math>c <  LaTex frac 12</math>. Thus the chance is <math> LaTex frac{ LaTex frac{1}{4}}2 =  LaTex frac 18</math>.
#<math>0 + 1 = 1</math>. The probability that <math>a <  LaTex frac 12</math> and <math>b >  LaTex frac 12</math> is <math> LaTex frac 14</math>, but now <math> LaTex frac{1}{2} < a+b = c <  LaTex frac 32</math>, which makes <math>C = 1</math> automatically. Hence the chance is <math> LaTex frac 14</math>. 
#<math>1 + 0 = 1</math>. This is the same as the previous case.
#<math>1 + 1 = 2</math>. We recognize that this is equivalent to the first case. 

Our answer is <math>2 LaTex left( LaTex frac 18 +  LaTex frac 14  LaTex right) =  LaTex frac 34  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(E)}</math>.

=== Solution 2 ===
Use areas to deal with this continuous probability problem. Set up a unit square with values of <math>a</math> on x-axis and <math>b</math> on y-axis.

If <math>a + b < 1/2</math> then this will work because <math>A = B = C = 0</math>. Similarly if <math>a + b > 3/2</math> then this will work because in order for this to happen, <math>a</math> and <math>b</math> are each greater than <math>1/2</math> making <math>A = B = 1</math>, and <math>C = 2</math>. Each of these triangles in the unit square has area of 1/8.

The only case left is when <math>C = 1</math>. Then each of <math>A</math> and <math>B</math> must be 1 and 0, in any order. These cut off squares of area 1/2 from the upper left and lower right corners of the unit square.

Then the area producing the desired result is 3/4. Since the area of the unit square is 1, the probability is <math> LaTex frac 34</math>.

If <math>3</math> of the faces are colored the same, the property obviously cannot be satisfied. prompt: The graph of <math>2x^2 + xy + 3y^2 - 11x - 20y + 40 = 0</math> is an ellipse in the first quadrant of the <math>xy</math>-plane. Let <math>a</math> and <math>b</math> be the maximum and minimum values of <math> LaTex frac yx</math> over all points <math>(x,y)</math> on the ellipse. What is the value of <math>a+b</math>?
completion:
[[Image:2004_12B_AMC-21.png]]

<math> LaTex frac yx</math> represents the slope of a line passing through the origin. It follows that since a line <math>y = mx</math> intersects the ellipse at either <math>0, 1,</math> or <math>2</math> points, the minimum and maximum are given when the line <math>y = mx</math> is a tangent, with only one point of intersection. Substituting,
<cmath>2x^2 + x(mx) + 3(mx)^2 - 11x - 20(mx) + 40 = 0</cmath>
Rearranging by the degree of <math>x</math>,
<cmath>(3m^2 + m + 2)x^2 - (20m + 11)x + 40 = 0</cmath>
Since the line <math>y=mx</math> is tangent to the ellipse, we want the discriminant, 
<cmath>(20m+11)^2 - 4 LaTex cdot 40  LaTex cdot (3m^2 + m + 2) = -80m^2 + 280m - 199 </cmath>
to be equal to <math>0</math>. We want <math>a+b</math>, which is the sum of the roots of the above quadratic. By [[Vieta’s formulas]], that is <math> LaTex frac{280}{80} =  LaTex frac{7}{2}  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(C)}</math>.

prompt:
The square
<center><math>
 LaTex begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}  LaTex hline 50 &  LaTex textit{b} &  LaTex textit{c}  LaTex  LaTex 
 LaTex hline  LaTex textit{d} &  LaTex textit{e} &  LaTex textit{f}  LaTex  LaTex 
 LaTex hline  LaTex textit{g} &  LaTex textit{h} & 2  LaTex  LaTex 
 LaTex hline  LaTex end{tabular}
</math></center>
is a multiplicative magic square. That is, the product of the numbers in each row, column, and diagonal is the same. If all the entries are positive integers, what is the sum of the possible values of <math>g</math>?
completion:
All the unknown entries can be expressed in terms of <math>b</math>.
Since <math>100e = beh = ceg = def</math>, it follows that <math>h =  LaTex frac{100}{b}, g =  LaTex frac{100}{c}</math>,
and <math>f =  LaTex frac{100}{d}</math>. Comparing rows <math>1</math> and <math>3</math> then gives
<math>50bc = 2  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{100}{b}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{100}{c}</math>,
from which <math>c =  LaTex frac{20}{b}</math>.
Comparing columns <math>1</math> and <math>3</math> gives
<math>50d  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{100}{c}= 2c  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{100}{d}</math>,
from which <math>d =  LaTex frac{c}{5} =  LaTex frac{4}{b}</math>.
Finally, <math>f = 25b, g = 5b</math>, and <math>e = 10</math>. All the entries are positive integers
if and only if <math>b = 1, 2,</math> or <math>4</math>. The corresponding values for <math>g</math> are <math>5, 10,</math> and
<math>20</math>, and their sum is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathbf{(C)}35} </math>.

prompt: The [[polynomial]] <math>x^3 - 2004 x^2 + mx + n</math> has [[integer]] coefficients and three distinct positive zeros. Exactly one of these is an integer, and it is the sum of the other two.  How many values of <math>n</math> are possible?
completion:
Let the roots be <math>r,s,r + s</math>, and let <math>t = rs</math>. Then

<center><math>(x - r)(x - s)(x - (r + s))</math> <math>= x^3 - (r + s + r + s) x^2 + (rs + r(r + s) + s(r + s))x - rs(r + s) = 0</math></center>

and by matching coefficients, <math>2(r + s) = 2004  LaTex Longrightarrow r + s = 1002</math>. Then our polynomial looks like 
<cmath>x^3 - 2004x^2 + (t + 1002^2)x - 1002t = 0</cmath>
and we need the number of possible products <math>t = rs = r(1002 - r)</math>. Because <math>m=t+1002^2</math> is an integer, we also note that <math>t</math> must be an integer. 

Since <math>r > 0</math> and <math>t > 0</math>, it follows that <math>0 < t = r(1002-r) < 501^2 = 251001</math>, with the endpoints not achievable because the roots must be distinct and positive. Because neither <math>r</math> nor <math>1002-r</math> can be an integer, there are <math>251,000 - 500 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(C) } 250,500}</math> possible values of <math>n = -1002t</math>.

Let <math> LaTex alpha = DBC</math>. Then the first condition tells us that
<cmath>
 LaTex tan^2 DBE =  LaTex tan(DBE -  LaTex alpha) LaTex tan(DBE +  LaTex alpha) =  LaTex frac { LaTex tan^2 DBE -  LaTex tan^2  LaTex alpha}{1 -  LaTex tan ^2 DBE  LaTex tan^2  LaTex alpha},
</cmath>
and multiplying out gives us <math>( LaTex tan^4 DBE - 1)  LaTex tan^2  LaTex alpha = 0</math>. Since <math> LaTex tan LaTex alpha  LaTex neq 0</math>, we have <math> LaTex tan^4 DBE = 1  LaTex Longrightarrow  LaTex angle DBE = 45^{ LaTex circ}</math>. 

The second condition tells us that <math>2 LaTex cot (45 -  LaTex alpha) = 1 +  LaTex cot  LaTex alpha</math>. Expanding, we have <math>1 +  LaTex cot  LaTex alpha = 2 LaTex left[ LaTex frac { LaTex cot  LaTex alpha + 1}{ LaTex cot  LaTex alpha - 1} LaTex right]  LaTex Longrightarrow ( LaTex cot  LaTex alpha - 3)( LaTex cot  LaTex alpha + 1) = 0</math>. Evidently <math> LaTex cot  LaTex alpha  LaTex neq - 1</math>, so we get <math> LaTex cot  LaTex alpha = 3</math>.

Now <math>BD = 5 LaTex sqrt {2}</math> and <math>AC =  LaTex frac {2BD} { LaTex cot  LaTex alpha} =  LaTex frac {10 LaTex sqrt {2}}{3}</math>. Thus, <math>[ABC] =  LaTex frac {1}{2}  LaTex cdot 5 LaTex sqrt {2}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac {10 LaTex sqrt {2}}{3} =  LaTex frac {50}{3} LaTex   LaTex mathrm{(B)}</math>.

prompt: Given that <math>2^{2004}</math> is a <math>604</math>-[[digit]] number whose first digit is <math>1</math>, how many [[element]]s of the [[set]] <math>S =  LaTex {2^0,2^1,2^2, LaTex ldots ,2^{2003} LaTex }</math> have a first digit of <math>4</math>?
completion: Given <math>n</math> digits, there must be exactly one power of <math>2</math> with <math>n</math> digits such that the first digit is <math>1</math>. Thus <math>S</math> contains <math>603</math> elements with a first digit of <math>1</math>. For each number in the form of <math>2^k</math> such that its first digit is <math>1</math>, then <math>2^{k+1}</math> must either have a first digit of <math>2</math> or <math>3</math>, and <math>2^{k+2}</math> must have a first digit of <math>4,5,6,7</math>. Thus there are also <math>603</math> numbers with first digit <math> LaTex {2,3 LaTex }</math> and <math>603</math> numbers with first digit <math> LaTex {4,5,6,7 LaTex }</math>. By using [[complementary counting]], there are <math>2004 - 3  LaTex times 603 = 195</math> elements of <math>S</math> with a first digit of <math> LaTex {8,9 LaTex }</math>. Now, <math>2^k</math> has a first digit of <math> LaTex {8,9 LaTex }</math> [[iff|if and only if]] the first digit of <math>2^{k-1}</math> is <math>4</math>, so there are <math> LaTex boxed{195}  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(B)}</math> elements of <math>S</math> with a first digit of <math>4</math>.

The first <math>2003</math> even counting numbers are <math>2,4,6,...,4006</math>.

<math>= 1+1+1+...+1 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(D)} LaTex  2003}</math>

prompt: Members of the Rockham Soccer League buy socks and T-shirts. Socks cost $4 per pair and each T-shirt costs $5 more than a pair of socks. Each member needs one pair of socks and a shirt for home games and another pair of socks and a shirt for away games. If the total cost is $2366, how many members are in the League?
completion:
Since T-shirts cost <math>5</math> dollars more than a pair of socks, T-shirts cost <math>5+4=9</math> dollars. 

Since each member needs <math>2</math> pairs of socks and <math>2</math> T-shirts, the total cost for <math>1</math> member is <math>2(4+9)=26</math> dollars. 

Since <math>2366</math> dollars was the cost for the club, and <math>26</math> was the cost per member, the number of members in the League is <math>2366 LaTex div 26= LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(B)} LaTex  91}</math>.

prompt: A solid box is <math>15</math> cm by <math>10</math> cm by <math>8</math> cm. A new solid is formed by removing a cube <math>3</math> cm on a side from each corner of this box. What percent of the original volume is removed?
completion:
The volume of the original box is <math>15 LaTex cdot10 LaTex cdot8=1200.</math> 

The volume of each cube that is removed is <math>3 LaTex cdot3 LaTex cdot3=27.</math>

Since there are <math>8</math> corners on the box, <math>8</math> cubes are removed. 

So the total volume removed is <math>8 LaTex cdot27=216</math>. 

Therefore, the desired percentage is <math> LaTex frac{216}{1200} LaTex cdot100 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(D)} LaTex  18 LaTex %}.</math>

prompt: It takes Mary <math>30</math> minutes to walk uphill <math>1</math> km from her home to school, but it takes her only <math>10</math> minutes to walk from school to her home along the same route. What is her average speed, in km/hr, for the round trip?
completion:
Since she walked <math>1</math> km to school and <math>1</math> km back home, her total distance is <math>1+1=2</math> km. 

Since she spent <math>30</math> minutes walking to school and <math>10</math> minutes walking back home, her total time is <math>30+10=40</math> minutes = <math> LaTex frac{40}{60}= LaTex frac{2}{3}</math> hours. 

Therefore her average speed in km/hr is <math> LaTex frac{2}{ LaTex frac{2}{3}}= LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(A)} LaTex  3}</math>.

prompt: How many non-congruent triangles with perimeter <math>7</math> have integer side lengths?
completion:
By the [[triangle inequality]], no side may have a length greater than the semiperimeter, which is <math> LaTex frac{1}{2} LaTex cdot7=3.5</math>. 

Since all sides must be integers, the largest possible length of a side is <math>3</math>. Therefore, all such triangles must have all sides of length <math>1</math>, <math>2</math>, or <math>3</math>. Since <math>2+2+2=6<7</math>, at least one side must have a length of <math>3</math>. Thus, the remaining two sides have a combined length of <math>7-3=4</math>. So, the remaining sides must be either <math>3</math> and <math>1</math> or <math>2</math> and <math>2</math>. Therefore, the number of triangles is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(B)} LaTex  2}</math>.

prompt: What is the probability that a randomly drawn positive factor of <math>60</math> is less than <math>7</math>?
completion:
=== Solution 1===
For a positive number <math>n</math> which is not a perfect square, exactly half of the positive factors will be less than <math> LaTex sqrt{n}</math>. 

Since <math>60</math> is not a perfect square, half of the positive factors of <math>60</math> will be less than <math> LaTex sqrt{60} LaTex approx 7.746</math>. 

Clearly, there are no positive factors of <math>60</math> between <math>7</math> and <math> LaTex sqrt{60}</math>. 

Therefore half of the positive factors will be less than <math>7</math>. 

So the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(E)} LaTex   LaTex frac{1}{2}}</math>.

=== Solution 2===
Testing all numbers less than <math>7</math>, numbers <math>1, 2, 3, 4, 5</math>, and <math>6</math> divide <math>60</math>. The prime factorization of <math>60</math> is <math>2^2 LaTex cdot 3  LaTex cdot 5</math>. Using the formula for the number of divisors, the total number of divisors of <math>60</math> is <math>(3)(2)(2) = 12</math>. Therefore, our desired probability is <math> LaTex frac{6}{12} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(E)} LaTex   LaTex frac{1}{2}}</math>

===Solution 3===
This is not too bad with casework. Notice that <math>1*60=2*30=3*20=4*15=5*12=6*10=60</math>. Hence, <math>60</math> has <math>12</math> factors, of which <math>6</math> are less than <math>7</math>. Thus, the answer is <math> LaTex frac{6}{12} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(E)} LaTex   LaTex frac{1}{2}}</math>.

Solution by franzliszt

===Solution 4===
This following solution isn't recommended,  but just list out all the divisors of <math>60</math> to find <math>12</math> divisors.  <math>6</math> of these are less than <math>7,</math> so the answer is <math> LaTex frac{6}{12} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(E)} LaTex   LaTex frac{1}{2}}</math>. ~Sophia866

prompt: A set <math>S</math> of points in the <math>xy</math>-plane is symmetric about the origin, both coordinate axes, and the line <math>y=x</math>. If <math>(2,3)</math> is in <math>S</math>, what is the smallest number of points in <math>S</math>?
completion: If <math>(2,3)</math> is in <math>S</math>, then <math>(3,2)</math> is also, and quickly we see that every point of the form <math>( LaTex pm 2,  LaTex pm 3)</math> or <math>( LaTex pm 3,  LaTex pm 2)</math> must be in <math>S</math>. Now note that these <math>8</math> points satisfy all of the symmetry conditions. Thus the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(D)} LaTex  8}</math>.

prompt: Al, Bert, and Carl are the winners of a school drawing for a pile of Halloween candy, which they are to divide in a ratio of <math>3:2:1</math>, respectively. Due to some confusion they come at different times to claim their prizes, and each assumes he is the first to arrive. If each takes what he believes to be the correct share of candy, what fraction of the candy goes unclaimed?
completion: Because the ratios are <math>3:2:1</math>, Al, Bert, and Carl believe that they need to take <math>1/2</math>, <math>1/3</math>, and <math>1/6</math> of the pile when they each arrive, respectively. After each person comes, <math>1/2</math>, <math>2/3</math>, and <math>5/6</math> of the pile's size (just before each came) remains. The pile starts at <math>1</math>, and at the end <math> LaTex frac{1}{2} LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{2}{3} LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{5}{6} LaTex cdot 1 =  LaTex frac{5}{18}</math> of the original pile goes unclaimed. (Note that because of the properties of multiplication, it does not matter what order the three come in.) Hence the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(D)} LaTex   LaTex dfrac{5}{18}}</math>.

prompt: A square and an equilateral triangle have the same perimeter. Let <math>A</math> be the area of the circle circumscribed about the square and <math>B</math> the area of the circle circumscribed around the triangle. Find <math>A/B</math>.
completion:
Suppose that the common perimeter is <math>P</math>.
Then, the side lengths of the square and triangle, respectively, are <math> LaTex frac{P}{4}</math> and <math> LaTex frac{P}{3}</math>
The circle circumscribed about the square has a diameter equal to the diagonal of the square, which is <math> LaTex frac{P LaTex sqrt{2}}{4}</math>
Therefore, the radius is <math> LaTex frac{P LaTex sqrt{2}}{8}</math> and the area of the circle is
<math> LaTex pi  LaTex cdot  LaTex left( LaTex frac{P LaTex sqrt{2}}{8} LaTex right)^2 =  LaTex pi  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{2P^2}{64}= LaTex frac{P^2  LaTex pi}{32}=A</math>

Now consider the circle circumscribed around the equilateral triangle. Due to symmetry, the circle must share a center with the equilateral triangle. The radius of the circle is simply the distance from the center of the triangle to a vertex.
This distance is <math> LaTex frac{2}{3}</math> of an altitude. By <math>30-60-90</math> right triangle properties, the altitude is <math> LaTex frac{ LaTex sqrt{3}}{2}  LaTex cdot s</math> where s is the side.
So, the radius is <math> LaTex frac{2}{3}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{ LaTex sqrt{3}}{2}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{P}{3} =  LaTex frac{P LaTex sqrt{3}}{9}</math>
The area of the circle is <math> LaTex pi  LaTex cdot  LaTex left( LaTex frac{P LaTex sqrt{3}}{9} LaTex right)^2= LaTex pi  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{3P^2}{81}= LaTex frac{P^2 LaTex pi}{27}=B</math>
So, <math> LaTex frac{A}{B}= LaTex frac{ LaTex frac{P^2  LaTex pi}{32}}{ LaTex frac{P^2  LaTex pi}{27}}= LaTex frac{P^2  LaTex pi}{32}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{27}{P^2 LaTex pi}= LaTex boxed{ LaTex frac{27}{32}  LaTex implies  LaTex mathrm{(C)  LaTex  }  LaTex frac{27}{32}}</math>

prompt: Sally has five red cards numbered <math>1</math> through <math>5</math> and four blue cards numbered <math>3</math> through <math>6</math>. She stacks the cards so that the colors alternate and so that the number on each red card divides evenly into the number on each neighboring blue card. What is the sum of the numbers on the middle three cards?
completion:
Let <math>R_i</math> and <math>B_j</math> designate the red card numbered <math>i</math> and the blue card numbered <math>j</math>, respectively. 

<math>B_5</math> is the only blue card that <math>R_5</math> evenly divides, so <math>R_5</math> must be at one end of the stack and <math>B_5</math> must be the card next to it. 

<math>R_1</math> is the only other red card that evenly divides <math>B_5</math>, so <math>R_1</math> must be the other card next to <math>B_5</math>. 

<math>B_4</math> is the only blue card that <math>R_4</math> evenly divides, so <math>R_4</math> must be at one end of the stack and <math>B_4</math> must be the card next to it. 

<math>R_2</math> is the only other red card that evenly divides <math>B_4</math>, so <math>R_2</math> must be the other card next to <math>B_4</math>. 

<math>R_2</math> doesn't evenly divide <math>B_3</math>, so <math>B_3</math> must be next to <math>R_1</math>, <math>B_6</math> must be next to <math>R_2</math>, and <math>R_3</math> must be in the middle. 

This yields the following arrangement from top to bottom: <math> LaTex {R_5,B_5,R_1,B_3,R_3,B_6,R_2,B_4,R_4 LaTex }</math>

Therefore, the sum of the numbers on the middle three cards is <math>3+3+6= LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(E)} LaTex  12}</math>.

prompt:
The polygon enclosed by the solid lines in the figure consists of 4 congruent squares joined edge-to-edge. One more congruent square is attached to an edge at one of the nine positions indicated. How many of the nine resulting polygons can be folded to form a cube with one face missing? 

[[Image:2003amc10a10.gif]]
completion:
===Solution 1===
[[Image:2003amc10a10solution.gif]]

Let the squares be labeled <math>A</math>, <math>B</math>, <math>C</math>, and <math>D</math>.

When the polygon is folded, the "right" edge of square <math>A</math> becomes adjacent to the "bottom edge" of square <math>C</math>, and the "bottom" edge of square <math>A</math> becomes adjacent to the "bottom" edge of square <math>D</math>. 

So, any "new" square that is attatched to those edges will prevent the polygon from becoming a cube with one face missing. 

Therefore, squares <math>1</math>, <math>2</math>, and <math>3</math> will prevent the polygon from becoming a cube with one face missing.

Squares  <math>4</math>, <math>5</math>, <math>6</math>, <math>7</math>, <math>8</math>, and <math>9</math> will allow the polygon to become a cube with one face missing when folded. 

Thus the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(E)} LaTex  6}</math>.

===Solution 2===
Another way to think of it is that a cube missing one face has <math>5</math> of its <math>6</math> faces.  Since the shape has <math>4</math> faces already, we need another face.  The only way to add another face is if the added square does not overlap any of the others.  <math>1</math>,<math>2</math>, and <math>3</math> overlap, while squares <math>4</math> to <math>9</math> do not. The answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(E)} LaTex  6}</math>

===Solution 3===
If you're good at visualizing, you can imagine each box and fold up the shape into a 3D shape. This solution is only recommended if you are either in a hurry or extremely skilled at visualizing. We find out that <math>4,5,6,7,8</math> and <math>9</math> work. Therefore, the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(E)} LaTex  6}</math>. ~Sophia866

===Solution 1===
Since the area of square <math> LaTex text{ABCD}</math> is 16, the side length must be 4. Thus, the side length of triangle AKB is 4, and the height of <math> LaTex text{AKB}</math>, and thus <math> LaTex text{DMC}</math>, is <math>2 LaTex sqrt{3}</math>. 

The diagonal of the square <math> LaTex text{KNML}</math> will then be <math>4+4 LaTex sqrt{3}</math>. From here there are 2 ways to proceed:

First: Since the diagonal is <math>4+4 LaTex sqrt{3}</math>, the side length is <math> LaTex frac{4+4 LaTex sqrt{3}}{ LaTex sqrt{2}}</math>, and the area is thus <math> LaTex frac{16+48+32 LaTex sqrt{3}}{2}= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D) } 32+16 LaTex sqrt{3}}</math>.

Second: Since a square is a rhombus, the area of the square is <math> LaTex frac{d_1d_2}{2}</math>, where <math>d_1</math> and <math>d_2</math> are the diagonals of the rhombus. Since the diagonal is <math>4+4 LaTex sqrt{3}</math>, the area is <math> LaTex frac{(4+4 LaTex sqrt{3})^2}{2}= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D) } 32+16 LaTex sqrt{3}}</math>.

===Solution 2===
Because <math>ABCD</math> has area <math>16</math>, its side length is simply <math> LaTex sqrt{16} LaTex implies 4</math>.

Angle chasing, we find that the angle of <math>KBL=360-(90+2(60))=360-(210)=150</math>.

We also know that <math>KB=4, BL=4</math>.

Using Law of Cosines, we find that side <math>(KL)^2=16+16-2(16)cos{150} LaTex implies (KL)^2=32+ LaTex frac{32 LaTex sqrt{3}}{2} LaTex implies (KL)^2=32+16 LaTex sqrt{3}</math>.

However, the area of <math>KLMN</math> is simply <math>(KL)^2</math>, hence the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D) } 32+16 LaTex sqrt{3}}</math>

===Solution 3===

First we show that <math>KLMN</math> is a square. How? Show that it is a rhombus that has a right angle.

prompt: A point P is chosen at random in the interior of equilateral triangle <math>ABC</math>. What is the probability that <math> LaTex triangle ABP</math> has a greater area than each of <math> LaTex triangle ACP</math> and <math> LaTex triangle BCP</math>?

===Solution 1===

After we pick point <math>P</math>, we realize that <math>ABC</math> is symmetric for this purpose, and so the probability that <math>ACP</math> is the greatest area, or <math>ABP</math> or <math>BCP</math>, are all the same. Since they add to <math>1</math>, the probability that <math>ACP</math> has the greatest area is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(C)} LaTex   LaTex dfrac{1}{3}}</math>

===Solution 2===

We will use geometric probability. Let us take point <math>P</math>, and draw the perpendiculars to <math>BC</math>, <math>CA</math>, and <math>AB</math>, and call the feet of these perpendiculars <math>D</math>, <math>E</math>, and <math>F</math> respectively. The area of <math> LaTex triangle ACP</math> is simply <math> LaTex frac{1}{2} * AC * PF</math>. Similarly we can find the area of triangles <math>BCP</math> and <math>ABP</math>. If we add these up and realize that it equals the area of the entire triangle, we see that no matter where we choose <math>P, PD + PE + PF</math> = the height of the triangle. Setting the area of triangle <math>ABP</math> greater than <math>ACP</math> and <math>BCP</math>, we want <math>PF</math> to be the largest of <math>PF</math>, <math>PD</math>, and <math>PE</math>. We then realize that <math>PF = PD = PE</math> when <math>P</math> is the incenter of <math> LaTex triangle ABC</math>. Let us call the incenter of the triangle <math>Q</math>. If we want <math>PF</math> to be the largest of the three, by testing points we realize that <math>P</math> must be in the interior of quadrilateral <math>QDCE</math>. So our probability (using geometric probability) is the area of <math>QDCE</math> divided by the area of <math>ABC</math>. We will now show that the three quadrilaterals, <math>QDCE</math>, <math>QEAF</math>, and <math>QFBD</math> are congruent. As the definition of point <math>Q</math> yields, <math>QF</math> = <math>QD</math> = <math>QE</math>. Since <math>ABC</math> is equilateral, <math>Q</math> is also the circumcenter of <math> LaTex triangle ABC</math>, so <math>QA = QB = QC</math>. By the Pythagorean Theorem, <math>BD = DC = CE = EA = AF = FB</math>. Also, angles <math>BDQ, BFQ, CEQ, CDQ, AFQ</math>, and <math>AEQ</math> are all equal to <math>90^ LaTex circ</math>. Angles <math>DBF, FAE, ECD</math> are all equal to <math>60</math> degrees, so it is now clear that quadrilaterals <math>QDCE, QEAF, QFBD</math> are all congruent. Summing up these areas gives us the area of <math> LaTex triangle ABC</math>. <math>QDCE</math> contributes to a third of that area so <math> LaTex frac{[QDCE]}{[ABC]}= LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(C)} LaTex   LaTex dfrac{1}{3}}</math>.

Let <math>D</math> be the origin. <math>A</math> is the point <math>(0,4)</math> and <math>M</math> is the point <math>(2,0)</math>. We are given the radius of the quarter circle and semicircle as <math>4</math> and <math>2</math>, respectively, so their equations, respectively, are:

<math>x^2 + (y-4)^2 = 4^2</math>

<math>(x-2)^2 + y^2 = 2^2</math>

Subtract the second equation from the first:

<math>x^2 + (y - 4)^2 - (x - 2)^2 - y^2 = 12</math>

<math>4x - 8y + 12 = 12</math>

<math>x = 2y.</math>

Then substitute:

<math>(2y)^2 + (y - 4)^2 = 16</math>

<math>4y^2 + y^2 - 8y + 16 = 16</math>

<math>5y^2 - 8y = 0</math>

<math>y(5y - 8) = 0.</math>

Thus <math>y = 0</math> and <math>y =  LaTex frac{8}{5}</math> making <math>x = 0</math> and <math>x =  LaTex frac{16}{5}</math>.

The first value of <math>0</math> is obviously referring to the x-coordinate of the point where the circles intersect at the origin, <math>D</math>, so the second value must be referring to the x coordinate of <math>P</math>. Since <math> LaTex overline{AD}</math> is the y-axis, the distance to it from <math>P</math> is the same as the x-value of the coordinate of <math>P</math>, so the distance from <math>P</math> to <math> LaTex overline{AD}</math> is <math> LaTex frac{16}{5}  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex boxed{B}.</math>

For each of the <math>9 LaTex cdot10 LaTex cdot10=900</math> possible values of <math>q</math>, there are at least <math> LaTex left LaTex lfloor  LaTex frac{100}{11}  LaTex right LaTex rfloor = 9</math> possible values of <math>r</math> such that <math>q+r  LaTex equiv 0 LaTex pmod{11}</math>. 

Since there is <math>1</math> "extra" possible value of <math>r</math> that is congruent to <math>0 LaTex pmod{11}</math>, each of the <math> LaTex left LaTex lfloor  LaTex frac{900}{11}  LaTex right LaTex rfloor = 81</math> values of <math>q</math> that are congruent to <math>0 LaTex pmod{11}</math> have <math>1</math> more possible value of <math>r</math> such that <math>q+r  LaTex equiv 0 LaTex pmod{11}</math>. 

Therefore, the number of possible values of <math>n</math> such that <math>q+r  LaTex equiv 0 LaTex pmod{11}</math> is <math>900 LaTex cdot9+81 LaTex cdot1=8181  LaTex Rightarrow LaTex boxed{(B)} </math>.

prompt: A parabola with equation <math>y=ax^2+bx+c</math> is reflected about the <math>x</math>-axis. The parabola and its reflection are translated horizontally five units in opposite directions to become the graphs of <math>y=f(x)</math> and <math>y=g(x)</math>, respectively. Which of the following describes the graph of <math>y=(f+g)(x)</math>?
completion:
If we take the parabola <math>ax^2 + bx + c</math> and reflect it over the x - axis, we have the parabola <math>-ax^2 - bx - c</math>. Without loss of generality, let us say that the parabola is translated 5 units to the left, and the reflection to the right. Then:
 
<cmath>  LaTex begin{align*} f(x) = a(x+5)^2 + b(x+5) + c = ax^2 + (10a+b)x + 25a + 5b + c  LaTex  LaTex   g(x)  = -a(x-5)^2 - b(x-5) - c = -ax^2 + 10ax -bx - 25a + 5b - c  LaTex end{align*} </cmath> 

Adding them up produces: 
<cmath>  LaTex begin{align*} (f + g)(x) = ax^2 + (10a+b)x + 25a + 5b + c - ax^2 + 10ax -bx - 25a + 5b - c = 20ax + 10b  LaTex end{align*}</cmath> 

This is a line with slope <math>20a</math>. Since <math>a</math> cannot be <math>0</math> (because <math>ax^2 + bx + c</math> would be a line) we end up with <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(D)}  LaTex text{ a non-horizontal line }}</math>

If there are <math>k</math> B's in the first five letters, then there must be <math>5-k</math> C's in the first five letters, so there must be <math>k</math> C's and <math>5-k</math> A's in the next five letters, and <math>k</math> A's and <math>5-k</math> B's in the last five letters. Therefore the number of each letter in each group of five is determined completely by the number of B's in the first 5 letters, and the number of ways to arrange these 15 letters with this restriction is <math> LaTex binom{5}{k}^3</math> (since there are <math> LaTex binom{5}{k}</math> ways to arrange <math>k</math> B's and <math>5-k</math> C's). prompt:

<math>P(x) = x^5 + ax^4 + bx^3 + cx^2 + dx + e</math>

has five distinct <math>x</math>-intercepts, one of which is at <math>(0,0)</math>. Which of the following coefficients cannot be zero?
completion:
=== Solution 1 ===
Let the roots be <math>r_1=0, r_2, r_3, r_4, r_5</math>. According to [[Vieta's formulas | Viète's formulae]], we have <math>d=r_1r_2r_3r_4 + r_1r_2r_3r_5 + r_1r_2r_4r_5 + r_1r_3r_4r_5 + r_2r_3r_4r_5</math>. The first four terms contain <math>r_1=0</math> and are therefore zero, thus <math>d=r_2r_3r_4r_5</math>. This is a product of four non-zero numbers, therefore <math>d</math> must be non-zero <math> LaTex Longrightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(D)}</math>.

=== Solution 2 ===
Clearly, since <math>(0,0)</math> is an intercept, <math>e</math> must be <math>0</math>. But if <math>d</math> was <math>0</math>, <math>x^2</math> would divide the polynomial, which means it would have a double root at <math>0</math>, which is impossible, since all five roots are distinct.

The function <math>f(x) =  LaTex sqrt{x(ax+b)}</math> has a [[codomain]] of all non-negative numbers, or <math>0  LaTex le f(x)</math>. Since the domain and the range of <math>f</math> are the same, it follows that the domain of <math>f</math> also satisfies <math>0  LaTex le x</math>.

Since the domain and the range are the same set, it follows that <math> LaTex frac{-b}{a}</math> is in the codomain of <math>f</math>, or <math>0  LaTex le  LaTex frac{-b}{a}</math>. This implies that one (but not both) of <math>a,b</math> is non-positive. <center><math>0  LaTex le x  LaTex le  LaTex frac{-b}{a}.</math></center>

[[Completing the square]], <math>f(x) =  LaTex sqrt{a LaTex left(x +  LaTex frac{b}{2a} LaTex right)^2 -  LaTex frac{b^2}{4a}}  LaTex le  LaTex sqrt{ LaTex frac{-b^2}{4a}}</math> by the [[Trivial Inequality]] (remember that <math>a  LaTex le 0</math>). Since <math>f</math> is continuous and assumes this maximal value at <math>x =  LaTex frac{-b}{2a}</math>, it follows that the range of <math>f</math> is 

<center><math>0  LaTex le f(x)  LaTex le  LaTex sqrt{ LaTex frac{-b^2}{4a}}.</math></center>

As the domain and the range are the same, we have that <math> LaTex frac{-b}{a} =  LaTex sqrt{ LaTex frac{-b^2}{4a}} =  LaTex frac{b}{2 LaTex sqrt{-a}}  LaTex Longrightarrow a(a+4) = 0</math> (we can divide through by <math>b</math> since it is given that <math>b</math> is positive).
