Using that here, the arc of circle A has length <math> LaTex frac{45}{360} LaTex cdot2 LaTex pi{r_1}= LaTex frac{r_1 LaTex pi}{4}</math>. The arc of circle B has length <math> LaTex frac{30}{360}  LaTex cdot 2 LaTex pi{r_2}= LaTex frac{r_2 LaTex pi}{6}</math>. We know that they are equal, so <math> LaTex frac{r_1 LaTex pi}{4}= LaTex frac{r_2 LaTex pi}{6}</math>, so we multiply through and simplify to get <math> LaTex frac{r_1}{r_2}= LaTex frac{2}{3}</math>. As all circles are similar to one another, the ratio of the areas is just the square of the ratios of the radii, so our answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A) } 4/9}</math>.

The blue that's touching the center red square makes up 8 triangles, or 4 squares. Each of the corners is 1 square and each of the edges is 1, totaling 12 squares. There are 12 white squares, thus we have <math> LaTex boxed{B=W LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex text{(A)}}</math>.

prompt: Jamal wants to save 30 files onto disks, each with 1.44 MB space. 3 of the files take up 0.8 MB, 12 of the files take up 0.7 MB, and the rest take up 0.4 MB. It is not possible to split a file onto 2 different disks. What is the smallest number of disks needed to store all 30 files?
completion:
A <math>0.8</math> MB file can either be on its own disk, or share it with a <math>0.4</math> MB. Clearly it is better to pick the second possibility. Thus we will have <math>3</math> disks, each with one <math>0.8</math> MB file and one <math>0.4</math> MB file.

We are left with <math>12</math> files of <math>0.7</math> MB each, and <math>12</math> files of <math>0.4</math> MB each. Their total size is <math>12 LaTex cdot (0.7 + 0.4) = 13.2</math> MB. The total capacity of <math>9</math> disks is <math>9 LaTex cdot 1.44 = 12.96</math> MB, hence we need at least <math>10</math> more disks. And we can easily verify that <math>10</math> disks are indeed enough: six of them will carry two <math>0.7</math> MB files each, and four will carry three <math>0.4</math> MB files each.

Thus our answer is <math>3+10 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B) }13 }</math>.

prompt: Sarah places four ounces of coffee into an eight-ounce cup and four ounces of cream into a second cup of the same size. She then pours half the coffee from the first cup to the second and, after stirring thoroughly, pours half the liquid in the second cup back to the first. What fraction of the liquid in the first cup is now cream?
completion:
We will simulate the process in steps.

In the beginning, we have:
* <math>4</math> ounces of coffee in cup <math>1</math>
* <math>4</math> ounces of cream in cup <math>2</math>

In the first step we pour <math>4/2=2</math> ounces of coffee from cup <math>1</math> to cup <math>2</math>, getting:
* <math>2</math> ounces of coffee in cup <math>1</math>
* <math>2</math> ounces of coffee and <math>4</math> ounces of cream in cup <math>2</math>

In the second step we pour <math>2/2=1</math> ounce of coffee and <math>4/2=2</math> ounces of cream from cup <math>2</math> to cup <math>1</math>, getting:
* <math>2+1=3</math> ounces of coffee and <math>0+2=2</math> ounces of cream in cup <math>1</math>
* the rest in cup <math>2</math>

Hence at the end we have <math>3+2=5</math> ounces of liquid in cup <math>1</math>, and out of these <math>2</math> ounces is cream. Thus the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex text{(D) }  LaTex frac 25}</math>.

prompt: Mr. Earl E. Bird gets up every day at 8:00 AM to go to work. If he drives at an average speed of 40 miles per hour, he will be late by 3 minutes. If he drives at an average speed of 60 miles per hour, he will be early by 3 minutes. How many miles per hour does Mr. Bird need to drive to get to work exactly on time?
completion:
===Solution 1===
Let the time he needs to get there in be <math>t</math> and the distance he travels be <math>d</math>. From the given equations, we know that <math>d= LaTex left(t+ LaTex frac{1}{20} LaTex right)40</math> and <math>d= LaTex left(t- LaTex frac{1}{20} LaTex right)60</math>. Setting the two equal, we have <math>40t+2=60t-3</math> and we find <math>t= LaTex frac{1}{4}</math> of an hour. Substituting t back in, we find <math>d=12</math>. From <math>d=rt</math>, we find that <math>r</math>, our answer, is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B) }48 }</math>.

===Solution 2===
Since either time he arrives at is <math>3</math> minutes from the desired time, the answer is merely the [[harmonic mean]] of 40 and 60. 
Substituting <math>t= LaTex frac ds</math> and dividing both sides by <math>d</math>, we get <math> LaTex frac 2s =  LaTex frac 1{40} +  LaTex frac 1{60}</math> hence <math>s= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B) }48}</math>.

(Note that this approach would work even if the time by which he is late was different from the time by which he is early in the other case - we would simply take a weighted sum in step two, and hence obtain a weighted harmonic mean in step three.)

prompt: Both roots of the quadratic equation <math>x^2 - 63x + k = 0</math> are prime numbers. The number of possible values of <math>k</math> is
completion:
Consider a general quadratic with the coefficient of <math>x^2</math> being <math>1</math> and the roots being <math>r</math> and <math>s</math>. It can be factored as <math>(x-r)(x-s)</math> which is just <math>x^2-(r+s)x+rs</math>. Thus, the sum of the roots is the negative of the coefficient of <math>x</math> and the product is the constant term. (In general, this leads to [[Vieta's Formulas]]).

We now have that the sum of the two roots is <math>63</math> while the product is <math>k</math>. Since both roots are primes, one must be <math>2</math>, otherwise, the sum would be even. That means the other root is <math>61</math> and the product must be <math>122</math>. Hence, our answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex text{(B)} LaTex  1 }</math>.

prompt: Two different positive numbers <math>a</math> and <math>b</math> each differ from their reciprocals by <math>1</math>. What is <math>a+b</math>?
completion:
Each of the numbers <math>a</math> and <math>b</math> is a solution to <math> LaTex left| x -  LaTex frac 1x  LaTex right| = 1</math>.

Hence it is either a solution to <math>x -  LaTex frac 1x = 1</math>, or to <math> LaTex frac 1x - x = 1</math>. Then it must be a solution either to <math>x^2 - x - 1 = 0</math>, or to <math>x^2 + x - 1 = 0</math>.

There are in total four such values of <math>x</math>, namely <math> LaTex frac{ LaTex pm 1  LaTex pm  LaTex sqrt 5}2</math>. 

Out of these, two are positive: <math> LaTex frac{-1+ LaTex sqrt 5}2</math> and <math> LaTex frac{1+ LaTex sqrt 5}2</math>. We can easily check that both of them indeed have the required property, and their sum is <math> LaTex frac{-1+ LaTex sqrt 5}2 +  LaTex frac{1+ LaTex sqrt 5}2 =  LaTex boxed{(C)  LaTex sqrt 5}</math>.

prompt: For all positive integers <math>n</math>, let <math>f(n)= LaTex log_{2002} n^2</math>. Let <math>N=f(11)+f(13)+f(14)</math>. Which of the following relations is true?
completion:
First, note that <math>2002 = 11  LaTex cdot 13  LaTex cdot 14</math>.

Using the fact that for any base we have <math> LaTex log a +  LaTex log b =  LaTex log ab</math>, we get that <math>N =  LaTex log_{2002} (11^2  LaTex cdot 13^2  LaTex cdot 14^2) =  LaTex log_{2002} 2002^2 =  LaTex boxed{(D) N=2}</math>.

prompt: The mean, median, unique mode, and range of a collection of eight integers are all equal to 8. The largest integer that can be an element of this collection is
completion:
As the unique mode is <math>8</math>, there are at least two <math>8</math>s.

As the range is <math>8</math> and one of the numbers is <math>8</math>, the largest one can be at most <math>16</math>.

If the largest one is <math>16</math>, then the smallest one is <math>8</math>, and thus the mean is strictly larger than <math>8</math>, which is a contradiction.

If we have 2 8's we can add find the numbers 4, 6, 7, 8, 8, 9, 10, 12.
This is a possible solution but has not reached the maximum.

If we have 4 8's we can find the numbers 6, 6, 6, 8, 8, 8, 8, 14.

We can also see that they satisfy the need for the mode, median, and range to be 8. This means that the answer will be
<math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex text{(D)} LaTex  14 }</math>. ~By QWERTYUIOPASDFGHJKLZXCVBNM

prompt: Tina randomly selects two distinct numbers from the set <math> LaTex {1, 2, 3, 4, 5 LaTex }</math>, and Sergio randomly selects a number from the set <math> LaTex {1, 2,  LaTex ldots, 10 LaTex }</math>. What is the probability that Sergio's number is larger than the sum of the two numbers chosen by Tina?
completion:
=== Solution 1 ===

This is not too bad using casework. 

Tina gets a sum of 3: This happens in only one way <math>(1,2)</math> and Sergio can choose a number from 4 to 10, inclusive. There are 7 ways that Sergio gets a desirable number here.

Tina gets a sum of 4: This once again happens in only one way <math>(1,3)</math>. Sergio can choose a number from 5 to 10, so 6 ways here.

Tina gets a sum of 5: This can happen in two ways <math>(1,4)</math> and <math>(2,3)</math>. Sergio can choose a number from 6 to 10, so <math>2 LaTex cdot5=10</math> ways here.

Tina gets a sum of 6: Two ways here <math>(1,5)</math> and <math>(2,4)</math>. Sergio can choose a number from 7 to 10, so <math>2 LaTex cdot4=8</math> here.

Tina gets a sum of 7: Two ways here <math>(2,5)</math> and <math>(3,4)</math>. Sergio can choose from 8 to 10, so <math>2 LaTex cdot3=6</math> ways here.

Tina gets a sum of 8: Only one way possible <math>(3,5</math>). Sergio chooses 9 or 10, so 2 ways here.

Tina gets a sum of 9: Only one way <math>(4,5)</math>. Sergio must choose 10, so 1 way.

In all, there are <math>7+6+10+8+6+2+1=40</math> ways. Tina chooses two distinct numbers in <math> LaTex binom{5}{2}=10</math> ways while Sergio chooses a number in <math>10</math> ways, so there are <math>10 LaTex cdot 10=100</math> ways in all. Since <math> LaTex frac{40}{100}= LaTex frac{2}{5}</math>, our answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex text{(A)} LaTex frac{2}{5}}</math>.

=== Solution 2 ===
We invoke some symmetry. Let <math>T</math> denote Tina's sum, and let <math>S</math> denote Sergio's number. Observe that, for <math>i = 2, 3,  LaTex ldots, 10</math>, <math> LaTex text{Pr}(T=i) =  LaTex text{Pr}(T=12-i)</math>.

If Tina's sum is <math>i</math>, then the probability that Sergio's number is larger than Tina's sum is <math> LaTex frac{10-i}{10}</math>. Thus, the probability <math>P</math> is

<cmath>P =  LaTex text{Pr}(S>T) =  LaTex sum_{i=2}^{10}  LaTex text{Pr}(T=i)  LaTex times  LaTex frac{10-i}{10}</cmath>

Using the symmetry observation, we can also write the above sum as
<cmath> P =  LaTex sum_{i=2}^{10}  LaTex text{Pr}(T=12-i)  LaTex times  LaTex frac{10-i}{10} =  LaTex sum_{i=2}^{10}  LaTex text{Pr}(T=i)  LaTex times  LaTex frac{i-2}{10}</cmath>
where the last equality follows as we reversed the indices of the sum (by replacing <math>12-i</math> with <math>i</math>). Thus, adding the two equivalent expressions for <math>P</math>, we have

<cmath>
 LaTex begin{align*}
2P &=  LaTex sum_{i=2}^{10}  LaTex text{Pr}(T=i)  LaTex times  LaTex left( LaTex frac{10-i}{10} +  LaTex frac{i-2}{10} LaTex right)  LaTex  LaTex 
&=  LaTex sum_{i=2}^{10}  LaTex text{Pr}(T=i)  LaTex times  LaTex frac{4}{5}  LaTex  LaTex 
&=  LaTex frac{4}{5}  LaTex sum_{i=2}^{10}  LaTex text{Pr}(T=i)  LaTex  LaTex 
&=  LaTex frac{4}{5}
 LaTex end{align*}
</cmath>

Since this represents twice the desired probability, the answer is <math>P =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A)}  LaTex frac{2}{5}}</math>. -scrabbler94

prompt: Several sets of prime numbers, such as <math> LaTex {7,83,421,659 LaTex }</math> use each of the nine nonzero digits exactly once. What is the smallest possible sum such a set of primes could have?
completion:
Neither of the digits <math>4</math>, <math>6</math>, and <math>8</math> can be a units digit of a prime. Therefore the sum of the set is at least <math>40 + 60 + 80 + 1 + 2 + 3 + 5 + 7 + 9 = 207</math>.

We can indeed create a set of primes with this sum, for example the following sets work: <math> LaTex { 41, 67, 89, 2, 3, 5  LaTex }</math> or <math> LaTex { 43, 61, 89, 2, 5, 7  LaTex }</math>.

Thus the answer is <math>207 LaTex implies  LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(B)}}</math>.

prompt:
Let <math>C_1</math> and <math>C_2</math> be circles defined by <math>(x-10)^2 + y^2 = 36</math> and <math>(x+15)^2 + y^2 = 81</math>
respectively. What is the length of the shortest line segment <math>PQ</math> that is tangent to <math>C_1</math> at <math>P</math> and to <math>C_2</math> at <math>Q</math>?

Suppose that <math>a</math> and <math>b</math> are digits, not both nine and not both zero, and the repeating decimal <math>0. LaTex overline{ab}</math> is expressed as a fraction in lowest terms. How many different denominators are possible?
completion:
=== Solution 1 ===

The repeating decimal <math>0. LaTex overline{ab}</math> is equal to 
<cmath>
 LaTex frac{10a+b}{100} +  LaTex frac{10a+b}{10000} +  LaTex cdots
=
(10a+b) LaTex cdot LaTex left( LaTex frac 1{10^2} +  LaTex frac 1{10^4} +  LaTex cdots  LaTex right)
= 
(10a+b)  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac 1{99}
=
 LaTex frac{10a+b}{99}
</cmath>

When expressed in the lowest terms, the denominator of this fraction will always be a divisor of the number <math>99 = 3 LaTex cdot 3 LaTex cdot 11</math>. This gives us the possibilities <math> LaTex {1,3,9,11,33,99 LaTex }</math>. As <math>a</math> and <math>b</math> are not both nine and not both zero, the denominator <math>1</math> can not be achieved, leaving us with <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex mathrm{(C) }5}</math> possible denominators.

(The other ones are achieved e.g. for <math>ab</math> equal to <math>33</math>, <math>11</math>, <math>9</math>, <math>3</math>, and <math>1</math>, respectively.)

=== Solution 2 ===

Another way to convert the decimal into a fraction (simplifying, I guess?). We have <cmath>100(0. LaTex overline{ab}) = ab. LaTex overline{ab}</cmath> <cmath>99(0. LaTex overline{ab}) = 100(0. LaTex overline{ab}) - 0. LaTex overline{ab} = ab. LaTex overline{ab} - 0. LaTex overline{ab} = ab</cmath> <cmath>0. LaTex overline{ab} =  LaTex frac{ab}{99}</cmath>
where <math>a, b</math> are digits. Continuing in the same way by looking at the factors of 99, we have 5 different possibilities for the denominator. <math> LaTex boxed{(C)}</math>

~ Nafer
~ edit by SpeedCuber7
~ edit by PojoDotCom

=== Solution 3 ===
Since <math> LaTex frac{1}{99}=0. LaTex overline{01}</math>, we know that <math>0. LaTex overline{ab} =  LaTex frac{ab}{99}</math>. From here, we wish to find the number of factors of <math>99</math>, which is <math>6</math>. However, notice that <math>1</math> is not a possible denominator, so our answer is <math>6-1= LaTex boxed{5}</math>.
<cmath></cmath>
~AopsUser101
=== Solution 4 (Alcumus) ===
Since <math>0. LaTex overline{ab} =  LaTex frac{ab}{99}</math>, the denominator must be a factor of <math>99 = 3^2  LaTex cdot 11</math>. The factors of <math>99</math> are <math>1,</math> <math>3,</math> <math>9,</math> <math>11,</math> <math>33,</math> and <math>99</math>. Since <math>a</math> and <math>b</math> are not both nine, the denominator cannot be <math>1</math>. By choosing <math>a</math> and <math>b</math> appropriately, we can make fractions with each of the other denominators.

Thus, the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{5}</math>.

prompt: Consider the sequence of numbers: <math>4,7,1,8,9,7,6, LaTex dots</math> For <math>n>2</math>, the <math>n</math>-th term of the sequence is the units digit of the sum of the two previous terms. Let <math>S_n</math> denote the sum of the first <math>n</math> terms of this sequence. The smallest value of <math>n</math> for which <math>S_n>10,000</math> is:
completion: The sequence is infinite. As there are only 100 pairs of digits, sooner or later a pair of consecutive digits will occur for the second time. As each next digit only depends on the previous two, from this point on the sequence will be periodic. (Additionally, as every two consecutive digits uniquely determine the previous one as well, the first pair of digits that will occur twice must be the first pair 4,7.) Hence it is a good idea to find the period. Writing down more terms of the sequence, we get: 4,7,1,8,9,7,6,3,9,2,1,3,4,7, LaTex dots and we found the period. The length of the period is 12, and its sum is 4+7+ LaTex cdots+1+3 = 60. Hence for each k we have S_{12k} = 60k. We have LaTex lfloor 10000/60 LaTex rfloor = 166 and 166 LaTex cdot 12 = 1992, therefore S_{1992} = 60 LaTex cdot 166 = 9960. The rest can now be computed by hand, we get S_{1998} = 9960+4+7+1+8+9+7= 9996, and S_{1999}=9996 + 6 = 10002, thus the answer is LaTex boxed{ LaTex text{(B) }1999}.

prompt: Triangle <math>ABC</math> is a right triangle with <math> LaTex angle ACB</math> as its right angle, <math>m LaTex angle ABC = 60^{ LaTex circ}</math>, and <math>AB = 10</math>. Let <math>P</math> be randomly chosen inside <math> LaTex triangle ABC</math>, and extend <math> LaTex overline{BP}</math> to meet <math> LaTex overline{AC}</math> at <math>D</math>. completion: Clearly <math>BC=5</math> and <math>AC=5 LaTex sqrt{3}</math>. Choose a <math>P'</math> and get a corresponding <math>D'</math> such that <math>BD'= 5 LaTex sqrt{2}</math> and <math>CD'=5</math>. For <math> BD > 5 LaTex sqrt2 </math> we need <math>CD>5</math>, creating an isosceles right triangle with hypotenuse <math>5 LaTex sqrt {2}</math> . Thus the point <math>P</math> may only lie in the triangle <math>ABD'</math>. The probability of it doing so is the ratio of areas of <math>ABD'</math> to <math>ABC</math>, or equivalently, the ratio of <math>AD'</math> to <math>AC</math> because the triangles have identical altitudes when taking <math>AD'</math> and <math>AC</math> as bases. This ratio is equal to <math> LaTex frac{AC-CD'}{AC}=1- LaTex frac{CD'}{AC}=1- LaTex frac{5}{5 LaTex sqrt{3}}=1- LaTex frac{ LaTex sqrt{3}}{3}=  LaTex frac{3- LaTex sqrt{3}}{3}</math>. Thus the answer is <math> LaTex boxed{C}</math>.

prompt: In triangle <math>ABC</math>, side <math>AC</math> and the perpendicular bisector of <math>BC</math> meet in point <math>D</math>, and <math>BD</math> bisects <math> LaTex angle ABC</math>.  If <math>AD = 9</math> and <math>DC = 7</math>, what is the area of triangle <math>ABD</math>?
completion:
<asy>
unitsize(0.25 cm);
pair A, B, C, D, M;
A = (0,0);
B = (88/9, 28*sqrt(5)/9);
C = (16,0);

</asy>
Looking at the triangle <math>BCD</math>, we see that its perpendicular bisector reaches the vertex, therefore implying it is isosceles. Let <math>x =  LaTex angle C</math>, so that <math>B=2x</math> from given and the previous deducted. Then <math> LaTex angle ABD=x,  LaTex angle ADB=2x</math> because any exterior angle of a triangle has a measure that is the sum of the two interior angles that are not adjacent to the exterior angle. That means <math>  LaTex triangle ABD</math> and <math> LaTex triangle ACB</math> are [[Similarity (geometry)|similar]], so <math> LaTex frac {16}{AB}= LaTex frac {AB}{9}  LaTex Longrightarrow AB=12</math>.

Then by using [[Heron's Formula]] on <math>ABD</math> (with sides <math>12,7,9</math>), we have <math>[ LaTex triangle ABD]=  LaTex sqrt{14(2)(7)(5)} = 14 LaTex sqrt5  LaTex Longrightarrow  LaTex boxed{ LaTex text{D}}</math>.

prompt: Find the number of ordered pairs of real numbers <math>(a,b)</math> such that <math>(a+bi)^{2002} = a-bi</math>.
completion:
Let <math>s= LaTex sqrt{a^2+b^2}</math> be the magnitude of <math>a+bi</math>. Then the magnitude of <math>(a+bi)^{2002}</math> is <math>s^{2002}</math>, while the magnitude of <math>a-bi</math> is <math>s</math>. We get that <math>s^{2002}=s</math>, hence either <math>s=0</math> or <math>s=1</math>.

For <math>s=0</math> we get a single solution <math>(a,b)=(0,0)</math>.

Let's now assume that <math>s=1</math>. Multiply both sides by <math>a+bi</math>. The left hand side becomes <math>(a+bi)^{2003}</math>, the right hand side becomes <math>(a-bi)(a+bi)=a^2 + b^2 = 1</math>. Hence the solutions for this case are precisely all the <math>2003</math>rd complex roots of unity, and there are <math>2003</math> of those.

The total number of solutions is therefore <math>1+2003 =  LaTex boxed{2004}</math>.

prompt: Let <math>v, w, x, y, </math> and <math>z</math> be the degree measures of the five angles of a pentagon. Suppose that <math>v < w < x < y < z</math> and <math>v, w, x, y, </math> and <math>z</math> form an arithmetic sequence. Find the value of <math>x</math>.
completion:
=== Solution 1 ===

The sum of the degree measures of the angles of a pentagon (as a pentagon can be split into <math>5- 2 = 3</math> triangles) is <math>3  LaTex cdot 180 = 540^{ LaTex circ}</math>. If we let <math>v = x - 2d, w = x - d, y = x + d, z = x+2d</math>, it follows that 

<cmath>(x-2d)+(x-d)+x+(x+d)+(x+2d) = 5x = 540  LaTex Longrightarrow x = 108  LaTex   LaTex mathrm{(D)}</cmath>

If there are five Mondays, there are only three possibilities for their dates: <math>(1,8,15,22,29)</math>, <math>(2,9,16,23,30)</math>, and <math>(3,10,17,24,31)</math>.

The only day of the week that is guaranteed to appear five times is therefore <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textrm{(D)} LaTex   LaTex text{Thursday}}</math>.

=== Solution 1 ===
We can let <math>a=1</math>, <math>b=2</math>, <math>c=3</math>, and <math>d=4</math>. <math> LaTex frac{a}{d}= LaTex boxed{ LaTex frac{1}{4}}   LaTex Longrightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(C)}</math>

=== Solution 2 ===

As <math>a, b, d</math> is a geometric sequence, let <math>b=ka</math> and <math>d=k^2a</math> for some <math>k>0</math>. 

Now, <math>a, b, c, d</math> is an arithmetic sequence. Its difference is <math>b-a=(k-1)a</math>. Thus <math>d=a + 3(k-1)a = (3k-2)a</math>.

Comparing the two expressions for <math>d</math> we get <math>k^2=3k-2</math>. The positive solution is <math>k=2</math>, and <math> LaTex frac{a}{d}= LaTex frac{a}{k^2a}= LaTex frac{1}{k^2}= LaTex boxed{ LaTex frac{1}{4}}  LaTex Longrightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(C)}</math>.

=== Solution 3 ===
Letting <math>n</math> be the common difference of the arithmetic progression, we have
<math>b = a + n</math>, <math>c = a + 2n</math>, <math>d = a + 3n</math>. We are given that <math>b / a</math> = <math>d / b</math>, or
<cmath> LaTex frac{a + n}{a} =  LaTex frac{a + 3n}{a + n}.</cmath>
Cross-multiplying, we get 
<cmath>a^2 + 2an + n^2 = a^2 + 3an</cmath>
<cmath>n^2 = an</cmath>
<cmath>n = a</cmath>
So <math> LaTex frac{a}{d} =  LaTex frac{a}{a + 3n} =  LaTex frac{a}{4a} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex frac{1}{4}}   LaTex Longrightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(C)}</math>.

prompt: Juan rolls a fair regular octahedral die marked with the numbers <math>1</math> through <math>8</math>. Then Amal rolls a fair six-sided die. What is the probability that the product of the two rolls is a multiple of 3?
completion:
=== Solution 1 ===
On both dice, only the faces with the numbers <math>3,6</math> are divisible by <math>3</math>. Let <math>P(a) =  LaTex frac{2}{8} =  LaTex frac{1}{4}</math> be the probability that Juan rolls a <math>3</math> or a <math>6</math>, and <math>P(b) =  LaTex frac{2}{6} =  LaTex frac 13</math> that Amal does. By the [[Principle of Inclusion-Exclusion]],

<cmath>P(a  LaTex cup b) = P(a) + P(b) - P(a  LaTex cap b) =  LaTex frac{1}{4} +  LaTex frac{1}{3} -  LaTex frac{1}{4}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{1}{3} =  LaTex frac{1}{2}  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(C)}</cmath>

Alternatively, the probability that Juan rolls a multiple of <math>3</math> is <math> LaTex frac{1}{4}</math>, and the probability that Juan does not roll a multiple of <math>3</math> but Amal does is <math> LaTex left(1 -  LaTex frac{1}{4} LaTex right)  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{1}{3} =  LaTex frac{1}{4}</math>. Thus the total probability is <math> LaTex frac 14 +  LaTex frac 14 =  LaTex frac 12</math>.

=== Solution 2 ===
The probability that neither Juan nor Amal rolls a multiple of <math>3</math> is <math> LaTex frac{6}{8}  LaTex cdot  LaTex frac{4}{6} =  LaTex frac{1}{2}</math>; using [[complementary counting]], the probability that at least one does is <math>1 -  LaTex frac 12 =  LaTex frac 12  LaTex Rightarrow  LaTex mathrm{(C)}</math>.

=== Solution 3 (Alcumus) ===
The product will be a multiple of 3 if and only if at least one of the two rolls is a 3 or a 6. The probability that Juan rolls 3 or 6 is <math>2/8 = 1/4</math>. The probability that Juan does not roll 3 or 6, but Amal does is <math>(3/4) (1/3) = 1/4</math>. Thus, the probability that the product of the rolls is a multiple of 3 is <cmath> LaTex frac{1}{4} +  LaTex frac{1}{4} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex frac{1}{2}}.</cmath>
~aopsav (Credit to AoPS Alcumus)

=== Solution 2 ===

In this case, the region for <math>P</math> to be closer to the origin than to point <math>(3,1)</math> occupies exactly <math> LaTex frac{1}{2}</math> of the area of the rectangle, or <math>1.5</math> square units.

Thus the probability that <math>P</math> is closer to <math>(3.1)</math> is <math> LaTex frac{0.5}{2}= LaTex frac{1}{4}</math> and that of <math>P</math> is closer to the origin is <math>1- LaTex frac{1}{4}= LaTex frac{3}{4}</math>. <math> LaTex mathrm{(C)}</math>

prompt: A charity sells <math>140</math> benefit tickets for a total of <math> LaTex textdollar 2001</math>. Some tickets sell for full price (a whole dollar amount), and the rest sells for half price. How much money is raised by the full-price tickets?
completion:
Let's multiply ticket costs by <math>2</math>, then the half price becomes an integer, and the charity sold <math>140</math> tickets worth a total of <math>4002</math> dollars.

Let <math>h</math> be the number of half price tickets, we then have <math>140-h</math> full price tickets. The cost of <math>140-h</math> full price tickets is equal to the cost of <math>280-2h</math> half price tickets. 

Hence we know that <math>h+(280-2h) = 280-h</math> half price tickets cost <math>4002</math> dollars. Then a single full price ticket costs <math> LaTex frac{4002}{280-h}</math> dollars, and this must be an integer. Thus <math>280-h</math> must be a divisor of <math>4002</math>. Keeping in mind that <math>0 LaTex leq h LaTex leq 140</math>, we are looking for a divisor between <math>140</math> and <math>280</math>, inclusive.

The prime factorization of <math>4002</math> is <math>4002=2 LaTex cdot 3 LaTex cdot 23 LaTex cdot 29</math>. We can easily find out that the only divisor of <math>4002</math> within the given range is <math>2 LaTex cdot 3 LaTex cdot 29 = 174</math>. 

This gives us <math>280-h=174</math>, hence there were <math>h=106</math> half price tickets and <math>140-h = 34</math> full price tickets.

In our modified setting (with prices multiplied by <math>2</math>) the price of a half price ticket is <math> LaTex frac{4002}{174} = 23</math>. In the original setting this is the price of a full price ticket. Hence <math>23 LaTex cdot 34 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(A) }782}</math> dollars are raised by the full price tickets.

<asy>

The blue lines will be joined together to form a single blue line on the surface of the cone, hence <math>10</math> will be the slant height of the cone.

The red line will form the circumference of the base. We can compute its length and use it to determine the radius.

The length of the red line is <math> LaTex dfrac{252}{360} LaTex cdot 2 LaTex pi  LaTex cdot 10 = 14 LaTex pi</math>. This is the circumference of a circle with radius <math>7</math>.

Therefore the correct answer is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{C}}</math>.

prompt: A box contains exactly five chips, three red and two white. Chips are randomly removed one at a time without replacement until all the red chips are drawn or all the white chips are drawn. What is the probability that the last chip drawn is white?

prompt: How many positive integers not exceeding <math>2001</math> are multiples of <math>3</math> or <math>4</math> but not <math>5</math>?
completion:
Out of the numbers <math>1</math> to <math>12</math> four are divisible by <math>3</math> and three by <math>4</math>, counting <math>12</math> twice.
Hence <math>6</math> out of these <math>12</math> numbers are multiples of <math>3</math> or <math>4</math>. 

The same is obviously true for the numbers <math>12k+1</math> to <math>12k+12</math> for any positive integer <math>k</math>.

Hence out of the numbers <math>1</math> to <math>60=5 LaTex cdot 12</math> there are <math>5 LaTex cdot 6=30</math> numbers that are divisible by <math>3</math> or <math>4</math>.
Out of these <math>30</math>, the numbers <math>15</math>, <math>20</math>, <math>30</math>, <math>40</math>, <math>45</math> and <math>60</math> are divisible by <math>5</math>.
Therefore in the set <math> LaTex {1, LaTex dots,60 LaTex }</math> there are precisely <math>30-6=24</math> numbers that satisfy all criteria from the problem statement.

Again, the same is obviously true for the set <math> LaTex {60k+1, LaTex dots,60k+60 LaTex }</math> for any positive integer <math>k</math>.

We have <math>1980/60 = 33</math>, hence there are <math>24 LaTex cdot 33 = 792</math> good numbers among the numbers <math>1</math> to <math>1980</math>. At this point we already know that the only answer that is still possible is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B)}}</math>, as we only have <math>20</math> numbers left.

By examining the remaining <math>20</math> by hand we can easily find out that exactly <math>9</math> of them match all the criteria, giving us <math>792+9= LaTex boxed{ LaTex textbf{(B) }801}</math> good numbers.
This is correct.

prompt: The parabola with equation <math>y=ax^2+bx+c</math> and vertex <math>(h,k)</math> is reflected about the line <math>y=k</math>. This results in the parabola with equation <math>y=dx^2+ex+f</math>. Which of the following equals <math>a+b+c+d+e+f</math>?
completion: We write <math>p(x)</math> as <math>a(x-h)^2+k</math> (this is possible for any parabola). Then the reflection of <math>p(x)</math> is <math>q(x) = -a(x-h)^2+k</math>. Then we find <math>p(x) + q(x) = 2k</math>. Since <math>p(1) = a+b+c</math> and <math>q(1) = d+e+f</math>, we have <math>a+b+c+d+e+f = 2k</math>, so the answer is <math> LaTex fbox{E}</math>.

prompt: An insect lives on the surface of a regular tetrahedron with edges of length 1. It wishes to travel on the surface of the tetrahedron from the midpoint of one edge to the midpoint of the opposite edge. What is the length of the shortest such trip? (Note: Two edges of a tetrahedron are opposite if they have no common endpoint.)

A spider has one sock and one shoe for each of its eight legs. In how many different orders can the spider put on its socks and shoes, assuming that, on each leg, the sock must be put on before the shoe?
completion:
=== Solution 1 ===

Let the spider try to put on all <math>16</math> things in a random order. Each of the <math>16!</math> permutations is equally probable. For any fixed leg, the probability that he will first put on the sock and only then the shoe is clearly <math> LaTex frac{1}{2}</math>. Then the probability that he will correctly put things on all legs is <math> LaTex frac{1}{2^{8}}</math>. Therefore the number of correct permutations must be <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex frac {16!}{2^8}}</math>.

=== Solution 2 ===

Each dressing sequence can be uniquely described by a sequence containing two <math>1</math>s, two <math>2</math>s, ..., and two <math>8</math>s -- the first occurrence of number <math>x</math> means that the spider puts the sock onto leg <math>x</math>, the second occurrence of <math>x</math> means he puts the shoe onto leg <math>x</math>. 
If the numbers were all unique, the answer would be <math> 16! </math>. However, since 8 terms appear twice, the answer is <math>  LaTex frac{16!}{(2!)^8} =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex dfrac {16!}{2^8}}</math>.

=== Solution 3 (Bashy Solution)=== 
You can put all <math>8</math> socks on first for <math>8!</math> ways and then all <math>8</math> shoes on next for <math>8!</math> more ways. This is not the only possibility, so the lower bound is <math>(8!)^2</math>. Here is the reason why this is not the only possibility: You could for example put on 3 socks and then 1, 2, or 3 shoes before moving on and putting more socks on. Clearly this is not accounted for if you put on 8 socks right away and then 8 shoes. You don't have to put on 8 socks and then 8 shoes. You can choose all <math>16</math> in a random fashion, but some combinations would violate the rules, so the upper bound is <math>16!</math>. <math> LaTex text{(C)}</math> & <math> LaTex text{(E)}</math> are the lower and upper bounds, so the answer is in between them, <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex frac {16!}{2^8}}</math>.

=== Solution 4 ===
Pretty clearly, if we choose each sock-shoe pair individually, they will automatically align themselves.

<math> LaTex binom{16}{2} LaTex binom{14}{2} LaTex cdots LaTex binom{2}{2} =  LaTex frac{16  LaTex cdot 15  LaTex cdots 2}{2  LaTex cdot 2  LaTex cdots 2} =  LaTex frac{16!}{2^8}</math>

These also tell us that <math> LaTex frac{-a}{3}</math> is the average of the zeros, so <math> LaTex frac{-a}3=-2  LaTex implies a = 6</math>. We are also given that the sum of the coefficients is <math>-2</math>, so <math>1+6+b+2 = -2  LaTex implies b=-11</math>. So the answer is <math> LaTex fbox{A}</math>.

prompt:
Four positive integers <math>a</math>, <math>b</math>, <math>c</math>, and <math>d</math> have a product of <math>8!</math> and satisfy:

<cmath>
 LaTex begin{align*}
ab + a + b & = 524
 LaTex  LaTex  
bc + b + c & = 146
 LaTex  LaTex  
cd + c + d & = 104
 LaTex end{align*}
</cmath>

What is <math>a-d</math>?
completion:
Using Simon's Favorite Factoring Trick, we can rewrite the three equations as follows:

<cmath>
 LaTex begin{align*}
(a+1)(b+1) & = 525
 LaTex  LaTex  
(b+1)(c+1) & = 147
 LaTex  LaTex  
(c+1)(d+1) & = 105
 LaTex end{align*}
</cmath>

Let <math>(e,f,g,h)=(a+1,b+1,c+1,d+1)</math>. We get:

<cmath>
 LaTex begin{align*}
ef & = 3 LaTex cdot 5 LaTex cdot 5 LaTex cdot 7
 LaTex  LaTex  
fg & = 3 LaTex cdot 7 LaTex cdot 7
 LaTex  LaTex  
gh & = 3 LaTex cdot 5 LaTex cdot 7
 LaTex end{align*}
</cmath>

Clearly <math>7^2</math> divides <math>fg</math>. On the other hand, <math>7^2</math> can not divide <math>f</math>, as it then would divide <math>ef</math>. Similarly, <math>7^2</math> can not divide <math>g</math>. Hence <math>7</math> divides both <math>f</math> and <math>g</math>. This leaves us with only two cases: <math>(f,g)=(7,21)</math> and <math>(f,g)=(21,7)</math>.

The first case solves to <math>(e,f,g,h)=(75,7,21,5)</math>, which gives us <math>(a,b,c,d)=(74,6,20,4)</math>, but then <math>abcd  LaTex not= 8!</math>. We do not need to multiply, it is enough to note e.g. that the left hand side is not divisible by <math>7</math>. (Also, a - d equals <math>70</math> in this case, which is way too large to fit the answer choices.)

The second case solves to <math>(e,f,g,h)=(25,21,7,15)</math>, which gives us a valid quadruple <math>(a,b,c,d)=(24,20,6,14)</math>, and we have <math>a-d=24-14 = LaTex boxed{10}</math>.

prompt: In rectangle <math>ABCD</math>, points <math>F</math> and <math>G</math> lie on <math>AB</math> so that <math>AF=FG=GB</math> and <math>E</math> is the midpoint of <math> LaTex overline{DC}</math>. completion:
<asy>
unitsize(0.5cm);
defaultpen(0.8);
pair A=(0,0), B=(10,0), C=(10,7), D=(0,7), E=(C+D)/2, F=(2*A+B)/3, G=(A+2*B)/3;

draw(A--B--C--D--cycle);

label("$C$",C,NE);

label("$F$",F,S);

draw(H--D, dashed);
</asy>
Note that the triangles <math>AFH</math> and <math>CEH</math> are similar, as they have the same angles. Hence <math> LaTex frac {AH}{HC} =  LaTex frac{AF}{EC} =  LaTex frac 23</math>.

Also, triangles <math>AGJ</math> and <math>CEJ</math> are similar, hence <math> LaTex frac {AJ}{JC} =  LaTex frac {AG}{EC} =  LaTex frac 43</math>.

We can now compute <math>[EHJ]</math> as <math>[ACD]-[AHD]-[DEH]-[EJC]</math>. We have:

* <math>[ACD]= LaTex frac{[ABCD]}2 = 35</math>. 
* <math>[AHD]</math> is <math>2/5</math> of <math>[ACD]</math>, as these two triangles have the same base <math>AD</math>, and <math>AH</math> is <math>2/5</math> of <math>AC</math>, therefore also the height from <math>H</math> onto <math>AD</math> is <math>2/5</math> of the height from <math>C</math>. Hence <math>[AHD]=14</math>.
* <math>[HED]</math> is <math>3/10</math> of <math>[ACD]</math>, as the base <math>ED</math> is <math>1/2</math> of the base <math>CD</math>, and the height from <math>H</math> is <math>3/5</math> of the height from <math>A</math>. Hence <math>[HED]= LaTex frac {21}2</math>.
* <math>[JEC]</math> is <math>3/14</math> of <math>[ACD]</math> for similar reasons, hence <math>[JEC]= LaTex frac{15}2</math>.

Therefore <math>[EHJ]=[ACD]-[AHD]-[DEH]-[EJC]=35-14- LaTex frac {21}2- LaTex frac{15}2 =  LaTex boxed{3}</math>.

prompt: A polynomial of degree four with leading coefficient 1 and integer coefficients has two real zeros, both of which are integers. Which of the following can also be a zero of the polynomial?
completion:
Let the polynomial be <math>P</math> and let the two integer zeros be <math>z_1</math> and <math>z_2</math>. We can then write <math>P(x)=(x-z_1)(x-z_2)(x^2+ax+b)</math> for some integers <math>a</math> and <math>b</math>.

If a complex number <math>p+qi</math> with <math>q LaTex not=0</math> is a root of <math>P</math>, it must be the root of <math>x^2+ax+b</math>, and the other root of <math>x^2+ax+b</math> must be <math>p-qi</math>.

We can then write <math>x^2+ax+b = (x-p-qi)(x-p+qi) = (x-p)^2 - (qi)^2 = x^2 - 2px + p^2 + q^2</math>. 

We can now examine each of the five given complex numbers, and find the one for which the values <math>-2p</math> and <math>p^2+q^2</math> are integers. This is <math> LaTex boxed{ LaTex frac {1 + i  LaTex sqrt {11}}{2}}</math>, for which we have <math>-2p = -2 LaTex cdot LaTex frac 12 = -1</math> and <math>p^2+q^2 =  LaTex left(  LaTex frac 12  LaTex right)^2 +  LaTex left(  LaTex frac { LaTex sqrt{11}}2  LaTex right)^2 =  LaTex frac 14 +  LaTex frac {11}4 =  LaTex frac {12}4 = 3</math>.

(As an example, the polynomial <math>x^4 - 2x^3 + 4x^2 - 3x</math> has zeroes <math>0</math>, <math>1</math>, and <math> LaTex frac {1  LaTex pm i  LaTex sqrt {11}}{2}</math>.)

prompt: In <math> LaTex triangle ABC</math>, <math> LaTex angle ABC=45^ LaTex circ</math>. Point <math>D</math> is on <math> LaTex overline{BC}</math> so that <math>2 LaTex cdot BD=CD</math> and <math> LaTex angle DAB=15^ LaTex circ</math>. Find <math> LaTex angle ACB</math>.
completion:
<asy>
unitsize(2cm);
defaultpen(0.8);
pair A=(0,0), B=(4,0), D=intersectionpoint( A -- (dir(15)*100), B -- (B+100*dir(135)) ), C=B+3*(D-B);
pair ortho=rotate(-50)*(D-A);
pair E=extension(C, ortho, A, D);
draw(A--B);
draw(B--C);
draw(A--C);
draw(C--E);
draw(E--D);
draw(A--D);
draw(B--E, dotted);

label("$A$",A,SW);
label("$B$",B,SE);
label("$C$",C,N);
label("$D$",D,NE);
label("$E$",E,S);
</asy>

We start with the observation that <math> LaTex angle ADB = 180^ LaTex circ - 15^ LaTex circ - 45^ LaTex circ = 120^ LaTex circ</math>, and <math> LaTex angle ADC = 15^ LaTex circ + 45^ LaTex circ = 60^ LaTex circ</math>.

We can draw the height <math>CE</math> from <math>C</math> onto <math>AD</math>. In the triangle <math>CED</math>, we have <math> LaTex frac {ED}{CD} =  LaTex cos EDC =  LaTex cos 60^ LaTex circ =  LaTex frac 12</math>. Hence <math>ED = CD/2</math>.

By the definition of <math>D</math>, we also have <math>BD=CD/2</math>, therefore <math>BD=DE</math>. This means that the triangle <math>BDE</math> is isosceles, and as <math> LaTex angle BDE=120^ LaTex circ</math>, we must have <math> LaTex angle BED =  LaTex angle EBD = 30^ LaTex circ</math>. 

Then we compute <math> LaTex angle ABE = 45^ LaTex circ - 30^ LaTex circ = 15^ LaTex circ</math>, thus <math> LaTex angle ABE =  LaTex angle BAE</math> and the triangle <math>ABE</math> is isosceles as well. Hence <math>AE=BE</math>.

Now we can note that <math> LaTex angle DCE = 180^ LaTex circ - 90^ LaTex circ - 60^ LaTex circ = 30^ LaTex circ</math>, hence also the triangle <math>EBC</math> is isosceles and we have <math>BE=CE</math>.

Combining the previous two observations we get that <math>AE=EC</math>, and as <math> LaTex angle AEC=90^ LaTex circ</math>, this means that <math> LaTex angle CAE =  LaTex angle ACE = 45^ LaTex circ</math>.

Finally, we get <math> LaTex angle ACB =  LaTex angle ACE +  LaTex angle ECD = 45^ LaTex circ + 30^ LaTex circ = 75^ LaTex circ  LaTex boxed{D}</math>.

prompt: Consider sequences of positive real numbers of the form <math>x, 2000, y,  LaTex dots</math> in which every term after the first is 1 less than the product of its two immediate neighbors. For how many different values of <math>x</math> does the term 2001 appear somewhere in the sequence?

In the year <math>2001</math>, the United States will host the International Mathematical Olympiad. Let <math>I,M,</math> and <math>O</math> be distinct positive integers such that the product <math>I  LaTex cdot M  LaTex cdot O = 2001 </math>. What is the largest possible value of the sum <math>I + M + O</math>?
completion:
First, we need to recognize that a number is going to be lowest only if, of the <math>3</math> [[factor]]s, two of them are small. If we want to make sure that this is correct, we could test with a smaller number, like <math>30</math>. It becomes much more clear that this is true, and in this situation, the value of <math>I + M + O</math> would be <math>18</math>. Now, we use this process on <math>2001</math> to get <math>667 * 3 * 1</math> as our <math>3</math> factors.
Hence, we have <math>667 + 3 + 1 =  LaTex boxed{ LaTex text{(E) 671}}</math>

Solution By: armang32324

We can use an elementary exponents rule to solve our problem.
We know that <math>a^b LaTex cdot a^c = a^{b+c}</math>. Hence,

*If the median is <math>x</math> (<math>2  LaTex le x  LaTex le 4</math>), we must have the arithmetic progression <math>2, x,  LaTex frac{25+x}{7}</math>.  Thus, we find that <math>2x=2+ LaTex frac{25+x}{7}</math> so <math>x=3</math>.

prompt: A checkerboard of <math>13</math> rows and <math>17</math> columns has a number written in each square, beginning in the upper left corner, so that the first row is numbered <math>1,2, LaTex ldots,17</math>, the second row <math>18,19, LaTex ldots,34</math>, and so on down the board. If the board is renumbered so that the left column, top to bottom, is <math>1,2, LaTex ldots,13</math>, the second column <math>14,15, LaTex ldots,26</math> and so on across the board, some squares have the same numbers in both numbering systems. Find the sum of the numbers in these squares (under either system).
completion:
Index the rows with <math>i = 1, 2, 3, ..., 13</math>
Index the columns with <math>j = 1, 2, 3, ..., 17</math>

For the first row number the cells <math>1, 2, 3, ..., 17</math>
For the second, <math>18, 19, ..., 34</math>
and so on

So the number in row = <math>i</math> and column = <math>j</math> is
<math>f(i, j) = 17(i-1) + j = 17i + j - 17</math>

Similarly, numbering the same cells columnwise we
find the number in row = <math>i</math> and column = <math>j</math> is
<math>g(i, j) = i + 13j - 13</math>

So we need to solve

<math>f(i, j) = g(i, j)</math>

<math>17i + j - 17 = i + 13j - 13</math>

<math>16i = 4 + 12j</math> 

<math>4i = 1 + 3j</math>

<math>i = (1 + 3j)/4</math>

We get
<math>(i, j) = (1, 1), f(i, j) = g(i, j) = 1</math>

<math>(i, j) = (4, 5), f(i, j) = g(i, j) = 56</math>

<math>(i, j) = (7, 9), f(i, j) = g(i, j) = 111</math>

<math>(i, j) = (10, 13), f(i, j) = g(i, j) = 166</math>

<math>(i, j) = (13, 17), f(i, j) = g(i, j) = 221</math>

<math> LaTex boxed{D}</math> <math>555</math>

prompt: Professor Gamble buys a lottery ticket, which requires that he pick six different integers from <math>1</math>  through <math>46</math>, inclusive. He chooses his numbers so that the sum of the base-ten logarithms of his six numbers is an integer. It so happens that the integers on the winning ticket have the same property— the sum of the base-ten logarithms is an integer. What is the probability that Professor Gamble holds the winning ticket?
completion:
The product of the numbers has to be a power of <math>10</math> in order to have an integer base ten logarithm. Thus all of the numbers must be in the form <math>2^m5^n</math>. Listing out such numbers from <math>1</math> to <math>46</math>, we find <math>1,2,4,5,8,10,16,20,25,32,40</math> are the only such numbers. Immediately it should be noticed that there are a larger number of powers of <math>2</math> than of <math>5</math>. Since a number in the form of <math>10^k</math> must have the same number of <math>2</math>s and <math>5</math>s in its factorization, we require larger powers of <math>5</math> than we do of <math>2</math>. To see this, for each number subtract the power of <math>5</math> from the power of <math>2</math>. This yields <math>0,1,2,-1,3,0,4,1,-2,5,2</math>, and indeed the only non-positive terms are <math>0,0,-1,-2</math>. Since there are only two zeros, the largest number that Professor Gamble could have picked would be <math>2</math>. 

Thus Gamble picks numbers which fit <math>-2 + -1 + 0 + 0 + 1 + 2</math>, with the first four having already been determined to be <math> LaTex {25,5,1,10 LaTex }</math>. The choices for the <math>1</math> include <math> LaTex {2,20 LaTex }</math> and the choices for the <math>2</math> include <math> LaTex {4,40 LaTex }</math>. Together these give four possible tickets, which makes Professor Gamble’s probability <math>1/4 LaTex   LaTex mathrm{(B)}</math>.
